PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Governor-General has today appointed the Hon. John Kerin as Treasurer, following the resignation on 3 June 1991 of the Hon. Paul Keating from that office, the Hon. Simon Crean as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and the Hon. Ross Free as Minister for Science and Technology, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Treasurer. Mr Roger Price has been appointed as Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: On another matter, I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, will be absent from the chamber for the remainder of this week. Senator Evans is overseas on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Social Security and his Department on withstanding the best efforts of Senator Bolkus to wrest this Department from him for recent services rendered. Having regard to the importance of integrity in ministerial office and in the wake of the Prime Minister's admission that he lied to the Australian electorate and/or the Treasurer over his prime ministerial intentions, does the Minister regard integrity as an important quality for the leader of the Government and his appointed Ministers? If so, how does he explain his own conduct over the last few weeks in saying that a leadership challenge would have no hope, that he would second the motion of confidence in the incumbent, that the Hawke-Keating leadership team is the one that ought to be kept and that it is the one which will give Labor the best chance of winning next time, when he was actively undermining his own Prime Minister? Finally, does the Minister agree with Senator Robert Ray that in politics no promise is absolute?
—Quite clearly, the questions being asked of me are outside my portfolio responsibilities.

—I am patient. The clock ticks on. I do not mind how much time honourable senators opposite want to waste. If they want to listen, I will talk; otherwise I will wait. I will be doing an interview tomorrow morning for an hour on this question, where I will no doubt answer all the questions that Senator Alston asked and more. I do not believe that it is my responsibility to answer them in the chamber.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is Senator Richardson seriously telling the Australian community that he believes there is more political advantage in giving an interview outside this chamber than in confronting the representatives of the Australian community and putting the facts on the table, where they ought to be, and explaining up front why he has dissembled in the same manner and to the same extent as the Prime Minister in recent days?

—I raise a point of order. The Opposition attempted to raise this matter yesterday. It botched the opportunity then. It is not within the Minister's portfolio responsibilities. It is certainly part of his political life and all our political lives, but it is not--
—Integrity in public administration is quite important.

—Senator Hill interrupts my point of order. I do not want to delay the Senate. We have had many points of order from those opposite about the relevance of questions, et cetera. For instance, comment on this side about the relevance of Opposition policy has been ruled out of order time and time again because it is not relevant to the Minister's portfolio. Hypocrisy is shown here today by those opposite when they say that these questions should be answered in the Parliament when Senator Richardson and any other Minister here are responsible for the portfolios we represent. In my view, it should be ruled out of order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: what has just been said by the former Manager of Government Business in the Senate is that somehow the timing is not right and that these matters can be discussed elsewhere. I ask Senator Ray to make the position perfectly clear: is the Government saying that this Parliament has no business concerning itself with the integrity of Ministers? On that basis, when we know the Government can refuse to answer any question that it likes, does it choose not to pursue a matter which has been pursued exhaustively in this place and the other place on previous occasions?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to speak to that section of the point of order. No-one is arguing that any of these questions cannot in some form or other be raised in this Parliament. What we are taking about is Question Time and portfolio responsibility at Question Time. The broader questions on matters concerning the Prime Minister and other matters are generally handled in the Senate by the Minister representing the Prime Minister. But this is not a portfolio matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: If the Opposition's motion for the suspension of Standing Orders had been successful yesterday, all these things would have been canvassed, but the Opposition was not successful. There are many other forums and opportunities in the Parliament for Senator Alston and others to canvass these matters whenever they like. There is no choice at all for this chamber to make whether Senator Richardson talks on internal party matters at a media conference or anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We are not having a debate on this. The supplementary question was clearly out of order. Senator Richardson can answer it or not answer it. He has that prerogative.
—I am not answering it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the commitment by the Australian Government of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel to Iraq on humanitarian duties. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the current position regarding this deployment of ADF personnel to assist Kurdish refugees in that country? Has the Government made certain determinations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I agreed to withdraw the Australian Defence Force contingent from Operation Habitat in northern Iraq. Our forces have been serving with those from other nations, particularly the United Kingdom, to provide security and emergency relief for the displaced Kurdish population returning from Turkey. They were initially deployed for 30 days with the possibility of an extension of up to three months if required.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that in our area of operations the task is almost complete, with 90 per cent of humanitarian relief now being handled by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and other non-government organisations. Australia has joined the other major coalition commanders in developing a withdrawal plan to take effect shortly. It is anticipated that the Australian contingent will return home shortly after its withdrawal from Iraq. I am sure that all honourable senators will join me in thanking the Australian force for a job well done. Like all the other Australians who served in the Gulf, the forces who served in Operation Habitat have done us proud.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY: OVERSEAS TRIP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Why was it necessary for the Minister to spend six days in Ireland in January this year when he told the Senate more than 12 months ago that the social security agreement with Ireland was about to be signed? Can the Minister tell the Senate what proportion of the six days spent in Ireland he and members of his party spent with Ambassador Burke and what proportion of the total trip was devoted to business?
—I do not have a day by day breakdown of my time in Ireland, but I will give Senator Campbell my best recollection.
—Did you like the climate?
—It was pretty cold at the time, actually.
—Fishing?
—It was too cold for fishing; it was snowing half the time.
—It is still a lovely country.

—I will not deny that it is still a beautiful country. I think that I was in Ireland for five or six days; I do not recall exactly. Obviously on the two days when one is arriving and departing nothing very much occurs. I was there over the New Year holiday, so I did not find too many Ministers in the Irish Government prepared to interview me at the time. As soon as the New Year holiday was over, the talks occurred with the Irish Government. The talks occurred on two days and took place on the west coast of Ireland at the suggestion of the Irish Government. That is about all there is to say. In terms of what I told the Senate before, I included Ireland in the list of countries with which we were negotiating. I would have hoped to have signed the agreement with Portugal much earlier than I did; I signed it only on the last trip. One does not always sign them as quickly as one would like.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Last month the Minister told the Senate that a memorandum of understanding had been signed with Boeing International Corporation relieving Boeing of offsets obligations in return for allowing Australian aerospace companies fair access to Boeing contracts. Have any agreements been reached with other airlines and, if so, what are the benefits to local industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Beahan for reminding me of this matter. In fact, last week I announced a 10-year agreement which clears the way for Australian companies to bid for work with the European aircraft manufacturing consortium, Airbus Industrie. This agreement removes Airbus from current and future civil offsets obligations and provides for existing work programs to be extended with competitive Australian firms and it secures long term opportunities for Australian companies to bid for and participate in new multimillion dollar projects on a competitive basis.

ANSWER.PARA: The first of the new programs under the agreement is a follow-on order for A320 wing ribs to be supplied by Hawker de Havilland Ltd. In addition, Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd is to design and supply optional fuel tanks for the A310-300 series of aircraft. The agreement provides Australian industry with the opportunity to share in the success of Airbus and to work at the forefront of aerospace technology.

The relationship with Airbus on the advanced A330 aircraft has already put Australian industry at the forefront of materials technology. This can be seen in areas such as the use of lithium aluminium alloys by Hawker de Havilland and the design and manufacture of complex composite structures by Aerospace Technologies of Australia.

The 10-year agreement represents an important step in the Government's growth strategy for the aerospace industry announced in the 12 March statement. This statement was based on the formation of commercial strategic partnerships with the world's major aerospace companies. Officers from my Department are currently overseas negotiating agreements with other major aerospace companies and I am confident that other agreements will be signed by the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to scrap civil offsets altogether?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. The question is about the new model photocopiers which are designed to make double-sided copies on recycled paper. The Minister would be aware that some of these copiers have been installed in some honourable senators' offices, and I must say that that is a welcome replacement for some of the second-hand copiers that have been salvaged from other offices. I ask: given the Government's commitment to the environment, will the Minister now undertake, firstly, to encourage and enable all members of parliament to install similar machines without delay and, secondly, to take whatever steps are necessary to ensure that all copiers in Parliament House are upgraded to a similar environmentally friendly standard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bell knows, my Department is making continual efforts to update and improve the equipment provided to senators, and as part of that I recently put in place a trial of a range of photocopiers, in anticipation of requests for upgrades in the next financial year. Any changes in photocopiers in members' offices would be part of the normal upgrade which will take place in 1991-92 and thereafter.

ANSWER.PARA: The photocopiers that have been put in place have additional features, including the device that Senator Bell referred to, the automatic duplexing device, which allows the easy production of double-sided photocopies. The benefits of that are obvious. The consumption of paper is reduced and also those photocopiers have the capacity to use recycled paper. Some eight members will be involved in the trial, and already we have had a response from one of them saying, not surprisingly, that he felt that the duplex device was essential and not just a fancy option.

This is part of an overall commitment to recycling and, in that respect, the Department of Administrative Services has introduced a number of initiatives in recent days to encourage the use and reuse of paper. These include the publication of a guide for the use of recycled paper, seminars on recycling, some of which have been conducted in Parliament House and, of course, assessing and supplying technology to encourage proper use of recycled material.

Also, as part of the overall approach we are taking in this area, the Environmental Futures Group, which has been set up in the Department of Administrative Services to advise me on a range of environmental issues, has taken, as a priority, the issue of investigating the reuse of a number of consumables in offices, ranging from paper and paper products to things such as typewriter ribbons. Obviously we are encouraging members in other parts of the Federal Government system to use recycled material. With respect to the part of the honourable senator's question concerning Parliament House, that probably would be better directed to the President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the light of the Minister's answer and also having regard to the fact that tomorrow is to be observed as World Environment Day, will the Minister make some tangible and direct commitment towards expediting as soon as possible the introduction of machines similar to those that have been successfully trialled so far? Also, will he provide some degree of explanation to those who are continually hamstrung by the idea that this would be an additional expense rather than actually saving money and increasing productivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points there. We are at the start of the trial and, as Senator Bell would realise, the question of the availability of recyclable photocopier paper has been an issue for some time. It has been one that has been difficult to grapple with, but we are very close now to having recycled paper that can be used in photocopiers, and this trial will be extremely important in assessing whether that can be done successfully. In terms of giving greater priority to this issue, I think the mere fact that we have brought on the trial and have made a commitment to try to get the results before the 1991-92 expenditure program is commenced underlines the priority we have given the matter already.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the part of the question concerning savings, I think that is one of those hidden issues when addressing environmental matters, namely, the question of costs. It is always presumed that it is more costly to do things in an environmentally friendly way, whereas quite often the reverse is the case. That is obviously one consideration that we will be taking into account when looking at photocopiers using recycled paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—The job Bolkus wanted.

—I refer to reports that scientists have called for $1m a year to study the effects of nutrient run-off and other pollutants on the Great Barrier Reef. Is the Government concerned at such run-offs and pollutants degrading the reef and, if so, has the Government considered any request for funding further scientific studies on this subject?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not quite aware of the voraciousness of Senator Bolkus's appetite for all his neighbour's goods; I keep hearing he wants every job in the place! I for one want to go on record and say that Senator Bolkus is worthy of promotion. I want to say that very early.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to answer this question on the Great Barrier Reef. It was asked by Senator Colston who, of course, has had a continuing interest in the problems of the reef. Water quality would probably have to be the critical management issue that we face on the reef because the damage that degraded water can do is pretty obvious. The only trouble is that often the damage is not obvious at the time that it is being done; it is only obvious later on. That makes it, perhaps, the most difficult to undo. Therefore, we have to attempt to analyse the causes and change the practices which bring about the damage.

The main concerns are the potential effects of nutrients on corals, enhanced levels of phosphorous and their association with the weakening of the coral skeleton. The nutrients I refer to, of course, include nitrogen. Increased nitrogen stimulates the growth of algae and that competes with the coral. We have had an enormous problem in recent years right along the Queensland coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you pay attention over there to what the Minister is saying? None of you know anything about the growth of algae, and you are not listening.
—Order!
—Mr President, I apologise for the long delay in continuing my answer.
—Order! I think that was advice that I did not need. Please continue, Senator Richardson.

—The main human caused sources of pollutants that have caused the concern are, obviously, soil erosion, which along various areas of the Queensland coast has been an enormous problem; chemical fertilisers, which have been used increasingly in a range of farming activities along the coast; the discharge of waste from the island resorts and, of course, there are more island resorts now than there have ever been; discharge from the coastal cities of Queensland, pretty well all of which are growing; the dredging of harbours; and the construction of marinas which has taken place all the way up the coast.
—You left out breathing.

—I do not regard any of those things as a joke. If Senator Parer were to go to any of the scientists who study the area, he would understand the problems. Of course, the Opposition would develop anything at any time and at any cost, and that is the difference between us. Thank God the difference exists.

ANSWER.PARA: However, developments are occurring to try to address the problem. The first has been the establishment by the Ministry for Primary Industries of Queensland of a broadly based advisory committee on the effects of agricultural practice. Most people tend to think that that particular problem is the greatest one. There is a workshop on land use patterns and nutrient loadings of the Great Barrier Reef region, which will pool the results of research into agricultural fertiliser use, land use practices and the effect of nutrients. There is the adoption of a new and more stringent policy by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority on the control of wastes.

Approximately $110,000 per annum-which is 25 per cent of the Authority's basic research budget-is currently directed at water quality issues. The question, of course, of the long term funding for the Great Barrier Reef includes improved funding for research into problems such as nutrients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think what the Minister is telling the chamber is very interesting and very important. I suggest that he table his reply. He is reading from copious notes and, as this is so important, we could then actually see the result of all of the research he has put into it and we would not have to listen to his voice any more.
—It has been a long answer, but I think the Minister is concluding.

—I am, as a matter of fact, Mr President. I can assure Senator Colston that this particular proposal, which has the support of the ministerial council which is comprised of representatives of both governments, will be given the most careful consideration by each.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY: OVERSEAS VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —I again refer the Minister for Social Security to his visit to Ireland in January this year. He said earlier that some of the talks were held on the west coast. What were the nature and extent of those talks? Where were they held and for what length of time? Why could they not have been held in Dublin? Was Ambassador Burke a member of the group? Apart from Ashford Castle, the original home of the Guinness family, the Connemara Hills and the beautiful shores of Lake Corrib, where did the Minister go on the scenic west coast?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a slight difficulty with the scenic west coast at the time, which involved a gale that killed five people in one incident and quite a few in others. I would have to say that there were not too many people in Ireland at the time keen to go anywhere.
—And your car broke down.

—No, my car did not but the car carrying the officials did. They finished up being driven to Cong in a school bus but, fortunately, I was not in the bus. I stayed in the car. The talks were held in a castle next door to the village of Cong, which I point out for Senator Calvert's interest is where The Quiet Man was filmed. It is a very picturesque little village nestled on the shores of the lake. The talks were held there because that is where the Irish Government wanted them to be held.

ANSWER.PARA: Never having been to those places, if that is where the Irish Government asked for the discussions to be held, why would I say no? One would imagine that the same argument could be applied to the national conference. We are going to have it in Hobart but, if we could say that everything ought to happen on the east coast in the centre of activity, we could hold everything in Sydney or Canberra, but we do not. The Australian Government also goes to other places, just as the Irish Government does. Because the Minister had an electorate on that coast, he did not mind being there. In terms of what other places I visited during the gale and the storm, I drove through a number. I cannot remember their names because I could not see them at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Inadvertently, I hope, the Minister failed to answer the question I asked: was former Ambassador Burke a member of the party?
—Ambassadors almost always accompany Ministers on these talks. Yes, he was there.
—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the Senate of progress in the national housing strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am able to inform Senator Childs and other interested senators about the housing strategy to be pursued most vigorously by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Brian Howe, who has taken responsibility for the whole of the housing sector in so far as the Federal Government can influence its development. He understands very well, Mr President, as I know you would, that the housing stock throughout Australia does not match the needs of Australian households in the way it used to because the types of households in which Australians live have changed quite dramatically over the past several years.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Howe is therefore taking charge of the national housing strategy. Its primary objective is to enable the development of housing which will be affordable and appropriate for all Australians. He is also most concerned that that housing should be linked to the services which people need. This comes particularly from his experience in the inner city of Melbourne, where he has his electorate, and also flows from his understanding of the needs of the outer suburbs of our vast capital cities, so widespread as they are in the provision of housing on single house blocks. He is also concerned about provincial centres.

Basically, Mr Howe's emphasis will be on the provision of affordable and appropriate housing for Australians living in families and other combinations, and as single people, in housing units which at the moment are inappropriate for those different households.

As for affordable housing, it is clear that Mr Howe will be pursuing the need to encourage higher density housing in established suburbs in our cities. For that he will need to have the cooperation of State and local governments because of the major responsibilities which those levels of government have for regulations covering appropriate density of housing, for example, and for service delivery.

Mr Howe has also taken a consultative approach, talking to all the main players in the national housing strategy consultations. He will certainly be hosting the Australian Housing Research Council meeting in early July, which will be attended by State housing Ministers and representatives of the housing industry, finance industry bodies, local government, community organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I believe that this consultative process will be a hallmark of Mr Howe's concerns in this area. It will lead to a situation where, as the strategy is developed and implemented, there will be better-in the sense of more affordable and more appropriate-housing available for all Australians in the decades to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that charges of conspiracy to cheat and defraud have been laid against his New South Wales Australian Labor Party factional colleague, former Senator John Morris, arising from actions allegedly undertaken during his term as a senator along with his assistant, Mr Peter James, and former union secretary Mr Ken Jeffrey. Will Mr Peter James be required by the Minister to step down from the position he was appointed to by this Government, at the insistence of former Senator Morris, as a director of the Australian Tourist Commission, until these charges of conspiracy to cheat and defraud have been dealt with?
—The latter part of that question is clearly in order.
—I know nothing of the incidents of which Senator Baume speaks. I shall make some inquiries and I will try to let him know tomorrow.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPRESENTATION OF WOMEN ON GOVERNMENT BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women inform the Senate about measures the Government is taking to increase and to monitor the representation of women on government boards and commissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Giles raises an extremely important issue. In doing so, I think she recognises full well that an objective of the Government and of the National Agenda for Women is the achievement of equal representation of both men and women on boards of the Commonwealth by the year 2000. To this effect, we are taking a number of steps. In fact, three are most important in our pursuit of this goal. Firstly, as the Senate may know, the Government maintains a register of women database, which contains information on women with expertise in particular areas. Of course, we encourage its use by government departments and authorities.
—Who set that up?

—As to who set the system up, the point is that the system is currently being updated. I take this opportunity to make it known that the Office of the Status of Women would welcome further nominations from suitable women for registration on the database. As well as that, a monitoring system has been set up to track all Cabinet appointments. As a consequence of the information obtained from that system, it is seen that the total number of women on statutory boards as at February 1991 was 18 per cent. Though this is nowhere near good enough, it does compare favourably with the 12 per cent which was the estimate as at June 1988. So there has been an increase over the last three years in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: However, a new system called `Appoint' has been put in place. It was launched in March and is currently being installed in Commonwealth departments. The aim of the system is to allow accurate measurement of all appointments to Commonwealth bodies. It will enable the tracking and monitoring of the rate of appointment to Commonwealth bodies of not just women but all equal employment opportunity target groups. The system will provide quarterly monitoring reports, and they will be made available both to interested Ministers and to central monitoring points which have an interest in the appointment of the particular groups involved. The central monitoring points will be the Office of the Status of Women, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Office of Multicultural Affairs and the Office of Disability in the Department of Community Services and Health. The first quarterly reports from Appoint will be due in September this year.

It should also be mentioned that from next year-that is, the 1991-92 financial year-departmental annual report guidelines are expected to ask for portfolio appointment rates to be included as well. This will assist the Government to measure progress in fulfilling our objectives in this area as part of our commitment to social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to Appoint, and despite the harassment from the other side, I should mention that the system is exciting and has potential. Its potential has been recognised by a number of State governments and internationally. We look forward to providing a comprehensive system of monitoring on which government can plan its future appointments.

—My question is directed to the current Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why did the Prime Minister ask him yesterday, as reported, to step down as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Senate Leader? In view of his reported refusal to step down until it suited him, when is it likely to suit him?

—The only conversation I have had with the Prime Minister on this issue was a couple of weeks ago, when I think he said that he hoped I would stay on to join him in the next government. This question is revealing about the level of genuine understanding of any of these issues which the Opposition has. It is a stupid piece of scuttlebutt and the question is entirely misplaced.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, because we are very interested in who leads the rabble that is called the Government for the next short period of time. Can the Minister confirm to us that he intends to serve out his term as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Leader of the Government in the Senate? Has he done any secret deals about this? If so, who witnessed them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald should be more concerned about who leads the Opposition into the next election. That should be his concern. I am surprised by all this. After all, here is a party of experts on leadership changes. Look at them all. Look at the unhappy Dr Hewson, the reluctant leader. Why is he the reluctant leader?-because he saw what happened to his predecessors. Look at them all on the Opposition front bench: Mr Peacock, stabbed in the front; Mr Howard, stabbed in the back; and former Senator Chaney, stabbed back and front-Red Fred became Dead Fred very quickly. Have a look at them all on the Opposition front benches.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only that, but also the Opposition's only policy on any of these issues is one of recycling. Look at the situation in my State of Victoria. The Victorian Opposition did exactly the same as the Federal Opposition did. Up here it got rid of John Howard and recycled Andrew Peacock. In Victoria it got rid of whatever his name was and recycled boofhead Kennett. He has been there one month and the Opposition is thinking about recycling him again. It really has problems in all of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the deals.

—As for this wimp on the front bench of the Senate who interjects all the time-and the rest of them on the front bench of the Senate-I think Senator Macdonald ought to give some thought to this. Senator Macdonald has a lean and hungry look: such men are dangerous. The danger lies here and for all these others on the front bench.
—Order! I point out to the Senate that the expression `the rabble opposite' was asked to be withdrawn yesterday. I do not consider it to be unparliamentary, but I remind honourable senators of it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support-another dynamic Minister. It concerns the progress of micro-economic reform in New Zealand as compared with Australia. In particular, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of recent media reports of reforms being highlighted in the New Zealand shipping industry. Does the Government have any plans to make similar changes to improve Australian shipping?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were Prime Minister I would not have anyone in the Cabinet who weighed under 16 stone. These lean and hungry fellas cannot be trusted. I have noted these media reports. I must say that they are welcome, but I cannot understand--
—What is wrong with them?

—There is nothing wrong with them; they are welcome indeed. Opposition senators are pretty fond of citing New Zealand, so one would have thought that they would have been at least slightly interested in hearing about this recent reform in its maritime sector. As press reports have indicated, agreement has been reached with the maritime unions in New Zealand for a new core maritime award which will provide for what we in Australia call multiskilling.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry asked whether we would adopt those changes here in Australia. No, we will not. We do not need to adopt them in Australia; we adopted them in 1988. They have been advanced for some time now. In fact, the shipping reform program of this Government has been so successful that Australian shipping interests have engaged on an unprecedented program of currently some $1 billion worth of investment in new ships in Australia because of the savings that they are achieving as a result of the Government's shipping reform program.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you say it often enough, someone will believe it.

—In response to the interjections from those opposite-of course, it falls on deaf ears as being a matter of no account-let me stress that the difference between the New Zealand reforms which are being instituted and the Australian reforms that are already instituted is that we have introduced these significant reforms in an unprecedented climate of industrial peace.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, it might be worth while to have a look at how successful that completely unpublicised regime of reform has been. Lost time in the Australian shipping industry due to industrial action has been reduced from 1,593 ship days in 1982, that is, 4 per cent of the total time worked, to 48 ship days, or 0.1 per cent of time lost in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. What was the real reason for appointing Mr Crean, the former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, given that in his previous capacity as Secretary of the Storemen and Packers Union and as President of the ACTU--
—At least he has a portfolio. What are you allocated? You are on the front bench with nothing.

—Senator Ray should calm down and take it easy. He had a win. During Mr Crean's previous capacity as Secretary of the Storemen and Packers Union and as the former President of the ACTU, he took sides against the farmers in the following disputes: Mudginberri, the Portland live sheep issue and the Storemen and Packers wool bale dispute. On what basis does the Prime Minister believe that Mr Crean can have the support of primary industry? Can Senator Button assure the Senate that Mr Crean will support farmers against unfair union demands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell is not interested in the answer, of course. He is more interested in getting half a page of Hansard to send to some of his silly constituents.
—That is the statement of someone who has been in office too long.
—I know what Senator Boswell's mailing list is. I know whom he sends them to.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I point out to you that that was most unparliamentary and it is a reflection on the farmers and the primary industry constituents of Australia. I ask Senator Button to withdraw that implication.
—Order! It is not unparliamentary.

—Listen to the assumption in Senator Boswell's explanation that, because he belongs to the National Party of Australia, he represents farmers here and represents them better than anybody else. That is a ridiculous assumption. He has not represented them on tariffs; he has not represented them on sugar; he has not represented them on taxes; he has not represented them on half the issues which have come before this Parliament. There is a complacent assumption that, because those opposite call themselves the National Party of Australia, the successor to the Country Party, they somehow represent farmers better than anybody else.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me give Senator Boswell the answer to his particular question. Mr Crean will be a good Minister for primary industry and agriculture because he is competent and he is honest. Who was the National Party's last Minister for primary industry? Tell us about what happened to him. Where is he now? What was the saying-let him who is without Sinclair cast the first stone. That is what they used to say about him.

He was the Opposition's last representative of the farmers and look what the National Party did for farmers in its seven years in government. Senator Boswell is in here dealing with perceptions which are based on the lowest common denominator of the intelligence of the National Party-which is pretty low indeed. Mr Crean will be an excellent Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Whether the honourable senator likes it or not, this Government, and the Whitlam Government for that matter, have supplied the best Ministers for primary industry that this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —One does not ask those opposite or the National Party about that, one asks the farmers. Senator Wriedt was a great Minister for primary industry and Mr Kerin has been a great Minister for primary industry. This Government has supplied great Ministers for agriculture in this country and will continue to do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Federal Government still committed to completing the National Museum of Australia by the year 2001 on the centenary of Australian federation? Does the Minister believe the continuing delays in construction of the museum are unacceptable? What is the effect of these delays on the maintenance of the museum's existing collection and on the museum's ability to conserve and display properly historical material relating to Aboriginal and cultural heritage? Can the Minister give an indication of whether the 1991-92 Budget will contain additional funding for the National Museum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bourne would be aware, the Government announced some time ago its commitment to the long term development of the National Museum of Australia-quite long term development as a matter of fact. We said that we, as a nation, ought to be aiming to open it by the year 2001 on the centenary of Australian federation. It has been the case, of course, that in the last few years, as the budgetary situation has been tight, we did not think it was appropriate to be allocating money, but we did want to set a target so that Australia knew that it was not on the never-never and that there was a date.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has taken action to provide substantial funding for the museum to preserve and document its national historical collection. The museum has received this special allocation since 1989-90 and $900,000 was provided in the 1990-91 Budget. Obviously, I am not able to pre-empt what might happen in the next Budget-I wish I could on a few issues, but I am afraid I cannot. No detailed discussions about the Budget have yet occurred and, in any event, I could not reveal them until Budget night.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Prime Minister has confessed that he believed it was acceptable for him to mislead the people of Australia about his leadership deal with Mr Keating otherwise, according to the Prime Minister, `We would not have won the election'. The former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has acknowledged that he considers that the Prime Minister's behaviour in that regard was acceptable. Now the new Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, has also acknowledged that he considers that the Prime Minister's behaviour in that regard was acceptable. Throughout all of this Senator Button has been the third most senior Minister of the Hawke Government and I ask him: does he believe that behaviour was acceptable?

—Mr Keating is in a much better position than I to comment on that matter because he understood what the nature of the alleged agreement between Mr Hawke and himself was. I am not in a position to understand the detailed nature of that agreement. With the wisdom of hindsight, I see the situation as understandable on the basis of the information which I currently have from reading newspapers and things of that kind. That is the only observation I am able to make from my knowledge.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Just a few moments ago in the House of Representatives I heard the Prime Minister acknowledge once again that he deliberately misled the people of Australia.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators-Lied.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am attempting not to use the word `lie' because I understand that it may be unparliamentary. What he has in effect said to the House of Representatives is that, in an election for the Federal Government, the end justifies the means. As a man of integrity who relies on his own integrity, does Senator Button agree that in an election the end justifies the means?
—Without referring to the original question which Senator Lewis asked me, let me say that, in the context of an election, politics is not a fine art in which the truth is always paramount.

—Just a minute! There are stacks of examples in Australian political life of people making misleading statements in the course of an election campaign. That has been apparent in each of the recent elections with which I have been associated and remains so.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of some particularly disturbing unemployment figures in rural Australia, will the Minister ensure that future debate on job generation in capital cities also focuses creatively on strengthening regional economies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very complex question and one which has bedevilled the Australian political process for a long time. Certainly at times of previous governments there has been a much greater focus on job creation, decentralisation and the building up of regional centres in Australia. At other times that has happened as an organic thing in some particular areas where there have been natural resources or particular skills, and growth has occurred for those reasons. This is often considered by governments in relation to the migration program. Whether one can take steps to encourage migration to particular areas of the country, the answer seems to be no in terms of providing an effective inducement to people to move to and remain in regional areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Reynolds's question was probably directed more to future policy and how we might approach some of these issues. It is best for me to say that these issues are within the agenda of government at present, but it is too early for me to make any pronouncements about them at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware that there is legislation before the Senate on the export of education services which has been deemed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to be urgent and which must be finalised this session? Is the Minister also aware that the Industry Commission issued a draft report today on the export of education services, but there will be no formal public hearings before July? Can the Minister explain why the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is trying to rush a very badly drafted Bill through the Senate this session while the Treasurer has authorised the Industry Commission to conduct an inquiry into the same matter, and the timetable of the final report is not until the end of July?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of aspects of the Industry Commission's report need to be taken into account. I do have some information from the Minister and it basically goes to the point of whether the Government will be proceeding with the legislation. We obviously will be.
—Every time you get up they go out.

—If I were successful, the honourable senator would as well, but obviously I am not. There are some suggestions in the press that the Department of Employment, Education and Training may have mishandled the whole industry and so on. The Minister's position is that we will go ahead with the legislation. The Industry Commission report is a draft report and it will form the basis for further consultation and hearings.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the proposed recommendations are not supported. The Minister is of the view that it would not be credible in international education markets, nor among education institutions and authorities in Australia, to so support them. He is concerned that the international education community is particularly sensitive about quality assurance matters and would reject Australia as a study destination were we to appear less than interested in accreditation and other educational quality issues. Accreditation is a critical factor in the United States of America, which has 30 per cent of the world's foreign students.

The Minister further informs me that the Government is fully committed to maintaining the high quality of Australia's education system. Existing accreditation arrangements are a crucial part of systems to assure quality. He is of the opinion that the Industry Commission appears to ignore the very important historical and constitutional roles played by the States and Territories, not only in educational provision but also in accreditation and quality assurance generally. I suppose that is one fault that the Industry Commission has from time to time.

International students are important to us in many ways. They enrich our educational systems with cultural diversity and intelligence. They assist our research efforts and strengthen our educational institutions. In summary, the Government does not accept the proposed recommendations and is proceeding with the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree that the usual procedure is to conduct an inquiry and then to legislate? Does this mean that the Government at this point is back to front as well as upside down?
—The Opposition might be into the process of paralysis by analysis but this Government is not.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in that capacity and probably also in his capacity of Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Given that this country is still lacking in good private sector managers, especially in financial areas, and given that the second round of applications for collaborative research centres is currently being developed, does the Minister think it would be a good idea for one of those research institutes to focus on research into management and finance? Will he consider writing to large financial houses and relevant university departments to suggest that they develop such an application?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assumption in the question is that there is a lack of good private sector managers. That is a view which I largely share, certainly in relation to management innovation, research and development and so on. It is certainly a view which I share in relation to the forward horizons of businesses and much of management in that they seem to be directed to the very short term rather than the medium to long term.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as collaborative research centres are concerned, applications are called for and the projects are then selected by a committee. I have no ministerial input into that committee. We have an extraordinary number of management schools and management courses in Australia, but whether we are getting quantity or quality is an issue about which I am not quite sure. I would certainly embrace the idea which is inherent in Senator Crowley's question and encourage business to consider approaches for a collaborative research centre grant, but it is not something on which I would have any direct influence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Minister will be aware that the Queensland Government has come out strongly opposed to the foreign takeover bid by Tate and Lyle for the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd because, in the Queensland Government's own words, the bid failed `to demonstrate benefits with the degree of certainty necessary to satisfy Queensland's guidelines'. Those guidelines include import replacement, the introduction of new manufacturing technology, increased access to export markets, employment generation and maintenance or establishment of new industry. Will the Commonwealth now move to end the worrying speculation created by the takeover bid and act to support Australia's sugar industry by rejecting this bid, which is not in the national interest?

—I do not presume to say whether it is in the national interest or not because I honestly do not know enough about the circumstances. I have read the reports in the newspapers, and so on. Of course, I have views about that matter, but it is dealt with by the Foreign Investment Review Board on the basis of a number of criteria. I will direct Senator MacGibbon's question to the new Treasurer and try to obtain an answer as quickly as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to the case of a South Australian woman, Mrs Ellie Herbert, who has recently returned to Australia after a trip to the United States to recover her two children following their abduction by her former husband. I ask the Minister: what steps did the Federal Government take to assist Mrs Herbert to recover her children? In what ways can the Australian Government assist people, such as Mrs Herbert, in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question. As a senator from South Australia he would, of course, be particularly concerned about Mrs Herbert's story which is indeed a shocking one where, no doubt with a very profound sense of horror and in a very traumatic experience, she found that her husband, while enjoying access to his two children pursuant to an order of the Family Court of Australia, unlawfully removed them from this country and took them to the United States. Such abductions are not uncommon. Fortunately, however, the Federal Government is in a position to help in these sorts of situations. We were able to come to Mrs Herbert's assistance and to bring the case to a happy end.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to pay particular tribute to the honourable member for Adelaide, Dr Bob Catley, who has championed Mrs Herbert's cause. His office got in contact with my office and arrangements were quickly set in place to process Mrs Herbert's application for financial assistance under the overseas custody child removal scheme which I administer. The result was that at short notice we were able to provide $10,000 to Mrs Herbert to enable her and a companion to travel to the United States to commence legal proceedings for the recovery of her children. Her lawyer was successful in the Californian court which ruled that her children should be returned to her custody in Australia.

Indeed, I have granted some financial assistance to about 13 cases in the past 12 months relating to abduction of children from Australia to overseas destinations by one of the parents exercising rights in relation to access or custody. It is gratifying that in these cases, as in Mrs Herbert's, we have been able to minimise the trauma caused to the parent with the lawful custody of those children and, of course, the children themselves are then brought into the relationship which the Family Court has decided ought to be theirs with the custodial parent. I believe that money spent in this particular assistance scheme is money very well spent on behalf of these Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGER OF GOVERNMENT BUSINESS IN THE SENATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement.
—What is it about-your demotion?

—Yes, Senator Alston. It is with enormous regret and with tears in my eyes that I inform honourable senators that from today Senator Bob McMullan will take over my role as Manager of Government Business in the Senate. As the Opposition indicated, this is a bitter moment in my life when I have to give up this prestigious and highly paid job; but I am sure that Senator McMullan is the sort of person-I will get a little serious-who will help with the management of this chamber and who will have the time to devote to it. I wish him well in the job. I am sure that everyone in the chamber hopes that he will do a better job than I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, and on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Boswell moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of the former Minister for the Environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under my previous responsibility I had to make the decision on this matter. The Government will not oppose this suspension of Standing Orders to enable the debate to proceed straight away.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Boswell) agreed to:

That a motion to censure Senator Richardson, the former Minister for the Environment, for failing properly to supervise the actions of his department, may be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Richardson as the former Minister for the Environment for failing to supervise actions of his department which have resulted in:
(a) the payment of $968,841 to National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd, a company not a party to the assistance agreement;
(b) the payment of that sum without first obtaining proper financial accounts for the company;
(c) the payment of that sum upon the terms in variance with the agreement;
(d) the payment of that sum in circumstances in which the company had breached the assistance agreement by failing to preserve its assets; and
(e) failing to ensure that the payment was applied for the purposes contained in the agreement.

I move this censure against Senator Richardson in relation to an agreement that he as Minister for the Environment signed on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia with the company Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: it would be very helpful if we had a copy of Senator Boswell's motion.
—That can be arranged.

—The agreement related to the provision of financial assistance to re-equip the company's mill at Ravenshoe, Queensland, so that it could continue to operate for at least 10 years using plantation timber supplies from outside the nominated World Heritage area. That agreement was for strictly limited purposes, including retooling the Ravenshoe mill so that it continued to operate following the World Heritage listing. It provided for an interest free loan of $4.5m, repayable over 10 years, an annual subsidy, totalling $2.125m per year, payable on 1 July in years 1989 to 1992. An amount of $7.6m was allocated through that agreement to the Ravenshoe mill.

SPEECH.PARA: It has now become obvious that this agreement has been breached in many respects and that a huge sum of money has never been used for the proper purposes as specified in the agreement, to retool the mill and provide an iron lung for Ravenshoe. Instead, large sums have been siphoned off from Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd to an associated company, National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd and its plywood mill in Kyogle-not the mill in Ravenshoe. They are two completely different companies. Not only was the money misdirected but this occurred while Senator Richardson was the responsible Minister or, should I say, the irresponsible Minister.

The Minister must explain to the satisfaction of this Senate how the final payment of the $968,841 was paid earlier than the agreement stated and why it was paid to Timbertech Group, not a party to the agreement with the Commonwealth. The Minister should have understood that, because he signed the agreement.

On 15 May, Senator Richardson, in answer to my question, told the Senate that a payment of $968,841 had been made to Timbertech, the trade name of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, and that the payment in question was authorised by the agreement that was signed on behalf of the Commonwealth by himself on 29 June 1988.

We are also told that the third payment was an advance agreed departmentally. I have a copy of the agreement between Plywood and Plastic and the Commonwealth which clearly states that the payments were to be made on 1 July in the years 1989, 1990, 1991 and 1992. Last week I tabled a business and consumer affairs search that conclusively proved that Timbertech was not the trade name of Plywood and Plastic but of National Associated Plywood.

In his answer on 29 May, Senator Richardson said that his Department had given him a briefing on the payment and he had concurred, on the basis of that information, that a payment should be made. Ten minutes later, at the end of Question Time, he said that the Department had just advised him that he had not been informed that the payment was being made or to whom, yet on 16 May Senator Richardson told the Senate that he recalled simply authorising a payment but, off the top of his head, could not remember to whom. I think, at that stage, he said that he simply ticked the appropriation.

On Thursday, Senator Richardson informed the Senate of a meeting held the week before with his former Department to discuss the payment being made to the wrong company. I would have thought that at the meeting with his former Department Senator Richardson would have been informed by the head of that Department that he had not been a party to knowing who actually had made the payment, instead of being allowed to continue to tell the Senate, as late as last week, that he had given his authority to the payment.

This is in complete contradiction to the agreement made with the Minister that payments would be made on 1 July. Surely an advance payment six months earlier, in January, would need the Minister's approval as he had originally signed the agreement for the Government and was Minister at the time. Surely an agreement cannot be altered by someone ringing up and simply saying, `We are running out of money. We have a cash flow problem. Send us a cheque for another million dollars' then sending a letter saying, `Pay it to Plywood and Plastic', and the Department paying it to the name on the letterhead-Timbertech-a company with no responsibility to the mill at Ravenshoe. That is what Senator Richardson is asking the Senate to believe.

There are mistakes and there are mistakes, but this is a million-dollar mistake and it has hit not only the Senate, which has to accept it, but also the people of Ravenshoe who were supposed to receive the $968,841 to help them out. Senator Richardson cannot just get up in the Senate and say that he was not informed and absolve himself of all responsibility. That is against the Westminster--

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Durack did. I am about to read it.

—I am not interested in what Peter Durack did. This was another contradiction, because we were told on 16 October 1990 that until the company went into receivership on 20 April it was trading profitably. Companies do not trade profitably and then just go broke on a given day.

SPEECH.PARA: There are too many contradictions and Senator Richardson has not explained them. He was responsible for the Department when it breached the agreement by paying an early advance to the wrong company-a company that went into receivership three months after the Department paid it. The Department that Senator Richardson was responsible for did not get a set of audited accounts or a deed of release from the correct company, as advised by Price Waterhouse-advice which the Government had paid for and had sought.

I have already told the Senate that the only audited accounts ever received by the Commonwealth related to the 1987-88 financial year. Senator Richardson, in his answer on 16 October, advised that audited accounts had been requested in December 1989 and early 1990. The Senate learned last Thursday in the Estimates debate that Timbertech, in its letter to the Department requesting early payment, said that audited accounts would be completed on 15 December 1989 and would be forwarded to the Department forthwith.

Why did the Department not pursue the company so it could check on the company's financial position before the payment? The audited accounts were available. In the letters tabled by the Minister last week, a letter from Timbertech read, `The audited accounts will be available'. Instead, the Minister told us that he sought accounting, not legal, advice on whether the early payment could be made by the Department.

Part of the accounting advice was that the Commonwealth should obtain a deed of release from the company for the amount of the early payment. That was the advice the Minister paid for. Why did he not take any notice of it? The Government did not do this. The Department should also have investigated whether it could rightly make a payment six months before the clause in the contract said it was to be made and, to make matters worse, the Department then sent the cheque to the wrong company.

If this deed of release had been obtained as advised, this would never have happened. The Minister has revealed that the early payment was requested because of the short term cash flow problems with the mill. As we learned last week, Price Waterhouse advised the Department that before any payment was made the company should supply its most recent management accounts and projections to support its cash flow need. Again, this was never done. Why was it not done? Senator Richardson was the Minister responsible at the time and he never checked on his Department.

It was not done, contrary to the advice given by Price Waterhouse. Considering the cash flow problems, the Department should have been particularly vigilant to obtain the audited accounts, which we know were available, before making payment, and to follow the accounting advice it paid for and get a deed of release from the correct company for the early payment and the cheque so that it could legally make advance payments.

However, by this payment being made to the wrong company and not to the Ravenshoe mill, the tradespeople of Ravenshoe who were owed money by the company were not able to be paid, despite this being the reason for the request for the questionable advance payment. Certainly the Ravenshoe company was not being helped with its cash flow problems by the Government sending the money to Kyogle when it should have been sending it to Ravenshoe.

Senator Richardson was further negligent in that his Department did not keep sufficient checks to monitor the agreement, and that is where I hold Senator Richardson responsible. He just cannot hand out $7.6m of government money, slap everyone on the back and say, `I've done my job' and walk away from it.

He was not aware of machinery and equipment being sold out the back door. In a question on 17 October 1990, I asked Senator Richardson whether it was true that a boiler purchased with Commonwealth loan money was sold and leased back by the company. I also asked whether the sale of a veneer mill was a breach of the terms of the loan agreement, which stated that the company was not to dispose of the assets of the company without the Commonwealth's permission. Senator Richardson did not even understand or know about it at the time.

On 18 October 1990, the Minister admitted that a wood fired boiler worth approximately $412,000 and purchased by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd with Commonwealth assistance had been sold to AGC Ltd and leased back to the company. At the same time, he also admitted to the Senate that a $425,000 veneer hardwood timber plant was sold without his permission. Another $837,000 of taxpayers' money gone in breach of the agreement!

He told us the Government did not know anything about it, and he did not know anything about it. Why did he not know anything about it? In an answer to a question on 16 October 1990, the Minister said-and this has to be the greatest laugh of all time- `Like any good business manager the Commonwealth did not let its loans go unwatched'. That is one that will haunt Senator Richardson for the rest of his life.

Everyone in Ravenshoe knew that the veneer mill had been flogged out the back door. It was the talk of the town. Yet the Minister admits that he only became aware of the disappearance of the veneer mill when he was advised by a letter on 19 September 1990 from the receiver-manager. It is a clear indication, if any further indication is needed, that Senator Richardson and his Department, which he was supposed to administer, was not monitoring the agreement that Senator Richardson signed.

We are told by the Minister that officers of the Department regularly telephoned the manager of the mill; that the mill was visited by representatives on several occasions; and that the Department's financial advisers on this issue, Price Waterhouse, also monitored the operation of the mill. They probably did but Senator Richardson took no notice of them.

The present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, cannot be blamed for the Ravenshoe fiasco, but Senator Richardson has to take full responsibility for the huge amounts of money that were misdirected in breach of the agreement and for the missing machinery that was sold out the back door. I visited the mill on about 13 occasions. The plywood mill that disappeared took up about half of an 8,000 square foot shed. It would have been impossible to miss it, had there been a proper inspection by Commonwealth officers to monitor the Government grants. It was not something one could put in one's lunch box and walk out the door with.
On 16 October, in answer to questions from Senator O'Chee, Senator Macdonald and me, Senator Richardson provided a very long answer to the overall position in Ravenshoe. I quote:
The assistance package was to benefit not only the sawmill but the Ravenshoe community and all North Queenslanders.

Senator Richardson also made the statement that no-one would be worse off under World Heritage listing. That was a brave statement, but the truth is that very little of the money stayed in Ravenshoe. If the agreement had been supervised properly by Senator Richardson and the money had gone to retool the Ravenshoe mill and had not been paid to the wrong company thousands of miles away, the devastation that has been caused in Ravenshoe would never have occurred.

The situation in Ravenshoe is desperate. The mill is bankrupt and is being sold off. It may even be sold off in pieces. The town is bankrupt because many of the tradespeople believed that the money allocated by the Government would actually be spent on retooling. All the timber workers who had jobs in the mill or in the field either are on the dole or have been forced to move away from Ravenshoe and to seek work elsewhere.

This once proud little town has become a social security town, a dole town-and that need never had happened if Senator Richardson had administered his Department instead of running around here, counting numbers and doing other things to protect his back in the Party. Senator Richardson cannot do a Pontius Pilate and wash his hands of the whole issue. It just will not wear any more. He had the responsibility of providing the people of the north Queensland timber industry with a job. It was his Government's decision to list the wet tropics in the World Heritage listing. I disagreed with that at the time, but I did not have the numbers. But that is not the issue that we are debating at the moment. The matter is clearly where the $7.6m of grants and subsidies, of taxpayers' funds, was put and why they were not put to their proper use. Senator Richardson's 16 October statement says:
. . . the core debt to unsecured creditors . . . is in fact somewhere between $122,000 to $150,000.

Senator O'Chee tabled in the Senate an inter-office memo from a senior officer in Ravenshoe desperately calling for the head office to make available funds of $192,000 to local contractors just for the April purchases. This document demonstrates that, as far back as 7 June 1989, the company was in financial difficulty. Signals were going out all over north Queensland about the company not paying its debts and its credit being stopped by the business community. It appears that everyone in north Queensland knew it, except the Minister and his Department in Cairns.

Why did the Department not tell the Minister? It was up in Cairns. He had a branch of the Department up there to administer the World Heritage area. There were a number of people up there. He has told us that they visited the mill three times. What were they doing? Senator Richardson, in answer to a question by me on 15 October 1990, said that the conditions placed by the Commonwealth on the company had been met up until the company had gone into receivership.

Let me tell Senator Richardson that that is wrong. The conditions of the contract were never met. Money was not going to the mill at Ravenshoe. Machinery and stock were being flogged out the back door. Senator Richardson and his Department must have been the only people involved in Ravenshoe, or even in north Queensland, who believed that everything was above board.

As early as 17 May, and again on 18 May, I warned Senator Richardson and Senator Collins that there could have been misappropriation of at least $4.6m. Senator Richardson went into his normal huffing and puffing and bullying tactics that we are so used to in the Senate. He said, `On what basis do you make that statement? Back it up. Do not just criticise people. Back it up. Give me one shred of evidence. Come on, one. You don't have to give me two'. I am giving him $7.6m worth today. In the same Estimates Committee Senator Macdonald suggested that the funding for the Ravenshoe mill was not terribly well supervised. That was an understatement. Senator Richardson's reply was:
Every time either you or Senator Boswell suggests that I am going to reject it.
He did reject it. In the Estimates Committee on 18 September Senator Richardson stated:

. . . there are a whole lot of questions we can get answered, a whole lot of questions, that you asked earlier on-we can have answered when we get the receivers report. Not only can we answer them, Senator Boswell, we should.

To this date none of these questions have ever been answered. We were told later that the receiver's reports had reached Mrs Kelly on 19 September and 25 September 1990. Despite this, on 11 October-nearly one month later-Senator Richardson said that he was unaware of the receiver's reports. It was only after I questioned Senator Richardson on 15 October 1990, and after Senator O'Chee tabled annual reports for Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd showing misappropriation had taken place, that Senator Richardson finally admitted that Commonwealth assistance had not yet been satisfactorily accounted for and that the matter had been referred to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for investigation. That was an admission on the Minister's part that the assistance agreement for which he was responsible was not honoured and that the conditions may not have been met. Five minutes earlier he had told the Senate that the conditions placed upon the Commonwealth had been met. After he heard that statement, he did a turn around. This is another indication that the Minister did not have a clue about what was happening in his Department. He was not running it: it was running him. No-one was running anyone.

It is now seven months later and the Senate still does not have answers, despite continued demands from Senator O'Chee, Senator Macdonald and myself. Every question is dead-batted away. The Minister says that he cannot table the receiver's documents or any other documents because charges may be laid. I suggest that is a cop-out. The Government must explain where the $7.6m went and why it did not reach its destination to help the disadvantaged people of Ravenshoe to help sustain the town's economy. If the Minister cannot explain, he must either table the documents or tell us that there are going to be charges laid and when they are going to be laid. This is a massive scandal and that is why the censure motion has been brought forward today. It has not been done lightly. It is the highest reprimand that a member of parliament can receive.

On top of this, we are told that the last payment of $968,841 was paid to the wrong company six months earlier than the agreement stated and that the payment was not based on properly validated financial statements. By the recklessness and negligent actions of the Minister in disregarding the use of public moneys appropriated in support of the Ravenshoe sawmill, the people of Ravenshoe now find themselves without a sawmill, without jobs and without payments for their services. Despite the promises of the Government that World Heritage listing would cost the people of north Queensland nothing, it has cost the people of Ravenshoe everything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally with censure motions a government spokesman precedes the one at whom the censure motion is aimed so that that person has the opportunity of hearing two or three speakers before he or she responds, rather than not being able to reply to other speakers. Senator Boswell said that this motion was the highest possible reprimand available to this chamber. I think that historically that was right, but there is no doubt that the offhand use of censure motions and the way they have been put together without any relationship to ministerial responsibility has made them a very devalued commodity in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a matter for regret, because when this Senate carries a censure motion for either trivial or serious reasons, we cannot sort out which is which in terms of its having any effect at all. As a couple of trivial censure motions have been carried over the past few years, it means that Ministers do not take them as seriously as they should. So when the Senate carries a motion in a chamber in which the Government does not have a majority, the reaction tends to be, `So what?'. I still take it seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is: your standards are so low.

—Senator Walters is going to sit there and interject on a censure motion and interrupt the flow of debate. She is not going to listen to the debate and she is going to vote in a tribal way without listening to any of the rational arguments. That is just absolutely typical of her attitude. The reason I admire Senator Walters is that she is a party loyalist who never deviates. She is a mirror image of that. That is something that I admire absolutely-I have never been any different. But when she comes out with pompous statements about fairness and all the rest of it, we all know what a joke it is. I want to finish on the point of whether censure motions have been totally devalued.
—Which ones?
—There have been many over the years.
—I got censured for misrepresenting the Department of Defence because they did not answer questions on time.
—That is the sort of example that I am thinking of.
—Order! Honourable senators should address their remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise because I have been distracted and have forced you to make that ruling. The second point is that one always looks at the motive behind a censure motion. Is Senator Boswell coming to this particular issue thinking that he is the great defender of public money, or is he simply doing this out of malice? He took the attitude that we should never ban logging in north Queensland. Chainsaw Ron takes the attitude that, `Well, we will just try to get even on this particular question'.

SPEECH.PARA: He made some disparaging remarks about Senator Richardson in the course of his address. And I made some disparaging remarks in response to that by way of interjection.
