Senator Boswell sits there on the front bench but he is not trusted to have a front bench portfolio. No amount of glossing that up will help the situation; that is the view of his colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister misrepresents me. At the time when the shadow Cabinet Ministers' responsibilities were handed out, the leader of my Party said publicly that I did not seek a shadow portfolio. Therefore, to say that I wanted to up the profile of the National Party and to say that I was not trusted is quite erroneous.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, you are quite correct. Senator Boswell seeks to engage in a debate across the chamber. I did not take any points of order when he was making outrageous comments, which I will come to in a moment. I repeat the point-which I only make because we are looking at motive in terms of the censure-that Senator Boswell always opposed the Government's action not to log in north Queensland. He did not really mention that here today at all. So anyone listening to this debate or reading the Hansard would not understand where Senator Boswell is coming from. I am about to put on the record where in fact Senator Boswell is coming from-that he is a chainsaw supporter.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is making misleading statements.
—Order! Senator Boswell, please be seated.
—Mr President, you have not heard my point of order.
—Please be seated. Senator Boswell, if you are going to make a point of order, you should do it concisely. So far you are not making any progress in terms of the point of order and I find none.

—We will move on. In summary, we are entitled to know whether this censure motion today is simply Senator Boswell saying that he is concerned about public money or whether it is part of a crusade on a broader issue; it clearly is the latter.

SPEECH.PARA: But the difficulty with this issue, if I may say so to honourable senators here as I look around the chamber, is that probably only the aficionados who have followed this matter from the start to the finish will master the detail of this debate today-and I am not one of them. I doubt that more than five or six people in this room have followed the debate in detail as this company went broke or this company did this and so on. I am not saying, by the way, that Senator Boswell, Senator O'Chee and Senator Macdonald have not followed the debate, because I have heard them ask questions and I take them at their word that they have followed it through. But it is a very difficult debate to come to grips with in terms of the sequence of events. So when they come into this chamber most people will vote along tribal lines without having listened to the debate. Again, regrettably-through no fault of Senator Boswell-it devalues any censure motion when the majority of voters in this chamber will not follow it in any detail.

Before I go to the question of ministerial responsibility-which is the main reason why I am on my feet-I do take up Senator Boswell on the point when he said, `Well, if Senator Richardson wasn't running around counting the numbers he would have supervised this particular matter'. I remind people of the time. We are talking about 9 January 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was going on since 1988.

—Senator Walters is trivialising again. I could come in here and make all sorts of comments about royal commissions in Tasmania and the Liberal Party down there. But I have not made one comment because I will wait for the decision, unlike Senator Walters's side of politics. I am trying to recall the ballot that took place on 9 January 1990 and I am trying to recall where I was. Does Senator Boswell know where he was on 9 January 1990? Can he tell the Senate? He might like to interrupt me with a point of order telling me where he was on that day and what he was doing. Absolute silence. I cannot remember what I was doing either. I hope I was at a one-day match.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the broader question. There can be two issues here. The first is whether the actions taken in regard to Ravenshoe were correct or incorrect. I will allow Senator Richardson and other honourable senators to debate that. It will be a complex issue and in my office I will have to listen to the arguments in order to try to understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't act tribally.

—In response to Senator Hill, there is always a temptation to do so. When in doubt I know which side of this chamber I trust. I always know. There is no-one on this side of the chamber whom I have ever had reason to distrust. The second more important question--
—It's a wonder you're not struck down.
—When I am, Foghorn Leghorn's absence from my sight, sound and senses will be one thing I appreciate. I was not saying in a very unkind way--
—It's a wonder your mother didn't teach you better manners.

—One of the things I was taught when I was a child was not to interrupt everyone every five seconds. I was trying to make a serious point. Once we establish whether in fact the actions were correct or incorrect, we then move to the next stage: should the Minister take responsibility for that and is he responsible for those correct or incorrect actions? A fair bit has been written about this and I will not bore the Senate for too long. Fairly early on in an article by Geoffrey Marshall in 1986 about ministerial responsibility and individual responsibility, it is said:

SPEECH.PARA: `The concept that because somebody whom the minister has never heard of has made a mistake means that the minister should resign-
I think we can substitute `be censured' for that because it is the same principle-
is out of date and rightly so.'
More specifically, I will read from page 64 which says:

The other category is that in which the chain of command or accountability is extended either geographically or administratively, and mistakes have been made by someone of whom the Minister either has not heard or over whom he could not be expected to exert control or surveillance.
It then goes on to another paragraph:

From these cases of non-resignation the current rules of individual ministerial responsibility can be summarised. Sir Thomas Dugdale's resignation over the mishandling of his Department's policy towards the disposal of land revealed in the 1954 Crichel Down case, though it was accompanied by subordinate errors, was an assumption of personal responsibility by the Minister who had himself been involved in the particular misjudgment and who was held by his colleagues to have failed to organize his Department efficiently. He was not, as many alleged at the time, a Minister sacrificed in accordance with the hard doctrine that a ministerial head must roll for civil service error. No post-war case has involved such an assumption and it can be said with confidence that the convention of ministerial responsibility contains no requirement of any such vicarious accountability.
It goes on to say:

But the conclusions of Sir David Maxwell Fyfe in the Crichel Down debate in 1954 and the similar conclusions of the then Opposition spokesman Mr Herbert Morrison may still be taken to state the present position. When action is taken of which a Minister disapproves and of which he has no prior knowledge, there is no obligation on his part to endorse it, to defend the errors of his officers, or to resign.

In summary, what we are saying about ministerial responsibility is that the second leg has to be established. It has to be established, firstly, that the actions of the Department in the circumstances were wrong-and then debate that out-and, secondly, whether it was the Minister's duty to have been directly supervising that action. What were the stages involved? Was it a case of the Minister approving overall policy requirements and global money and the Department then following that through case by case and step by step? If that is the case, no Minister is responsible to that level.

In his 1988 Garran Oration, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) put several points. These are not thoughts made up afterwards; they are thoughts laid down to guide Senator Richardson, myself and other Ministers throughout Australia:
The true measure of ministerial accountability, here and in Britain, has never been the tally of ministerial resignations.
I think we can again fairly substitute `censures by the chambers'. It continues:

Even in the slower and simpler formative period of our system of Government, the strict theory that Ministers were fully accountable for every act or omission of their departmental officers was, simply, far-fetched. In today's environment the traditional hypothesis just cannot be reconciled with political and administrative realities. The relationship between ministers and officials is far more complex than the hypothesis, with its all-too-neat dichotomy between policy and administration, permits.
It goes on to say:
In other words, ministers must, of course, continue to be answerable to the Parliament and to take any necessary corrective action. But the truth is that there is no requirement for them to resign-
for example, or be censored-
except where a significant act or omission was theirs, or taken at their personal direction, or was a matter about which they obviously should have known, and done something.
When we listen to what Senator Boswell has said today, we find that the only leg he has to stand on is that last point I made:
or was a matter about which they obviously should have known, and done something.

When this Senate debates the censure motion, it has to establish whether Senator Richardson knew of that detailed administrative task. Senator Boswell nods his head and says yes. Why does not Senator Boswell come over to my office one day and, on the basis of confidentiality, sit with me for a day and administer a budget of $9 billion with 69,000 full time servicemen, 24,000 civilians, representatives right throughout the world, and two massive industries like Australian Defence Industries Ltd and Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd, with the complexity of all that decision making throughout the breadth of Australia and tell me that I am supposed to know of every administrative detail and be responsible--

TALK.START.PARA: —For every payment.

—For every error or payment that my Department makes. That is a good theory, but no-one realistically expects that that situation still exists. A Minister is expected to correct mistakes when they are discovered-if there are mistakes, and I do not see any in this case-and to establish a sort of administrative authority so that every section of his Department knows that he will be tough on things such as fraud, inefficiency and misadvice-all of which Ministers get lumbered with at some stage-and will eradicate them. That is the essentiality of this debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Two issues have to be established: were the actions right or wrong and is the Minister properly responsible for those actions? If Opposition senators are not convinced on the second issue, they should not devalue the censure motion by nodding it through on some tribal reaction. To do so would devalue censure motions. The question of ministerial responsibility will hinge on the detail of the debate. Should Minister Richardson at the time have been signing cheques or supervising that level, or was the decision making such that the broad guidelines had been given and public servants were supposed to carry out the details properly? That is what has to be established.

I regret that I do not know all the details of this case, but I do know the philosophy behind the censure motion and ministerial responsibility. Those issues have to be seriously addressed, and not just in a partisan way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the censure motion and, I must say at the outset, with some regret because in many respects we have found Senator Richardson a very good Minister in the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories portfolio. In this instance, and with respect to these activities, we find the evidence is that, firstly, mistakes were made and, secondly, that he should have been aware of them and acted differently. In our view, both the criteria just outlined by Senator Robert Ray have indeed been established.

SPEECH.PARA: We are approaching this matter from a somewhat different position. I take it up, first of all, by pointing out that there have been two Opposition motions in recent days for the suspension of Standing Orders, neither of which we supported. I point out that the difference between the former two matters and this one lies in the belief of the Democrats that, on the two previous occasions, a debate would have occupied a great deal of time and would not have resulted in any significant change.

In this case, as I hope to establish through the course of the debate on this censure motion, we would like to draw attention to the very serious longer term consequences of the defects which have been exposed here, and have them corrected. Although this Minister is not the present Minister, we are moving forward into other situations which bear very considerable similarities to the declaration of the wet tropics and the undertaking to support the Ravenshoe mill.

I will pick up another remark of Senator Robert Ray when he accused Senator Boswell of perhaps having a hidden agenda and being opposed to the declaration of the wet tropics area. That may or may not be true in the case of Senator Boswell, but I do not think that the same claim could be made against the Democrats. We strongly supported the declaration of that wet tropics area for World Heritage purposes. That is the very point on which I rest the whole case that I want to make.

Throughout a number of years there had been a very active campaign by a number of conservation bodies to ensure that the remaining and rapidly decreasing area of tropical rainforest was protected and was protected from further logging. Eventually, the Government agreed to that call by the conservation movement. That was something that we very strongly applauded at the time. We felt that the Government was perhaps tardy over those moves but, nonetheless, when it did move, we strongly supported its action.

I recall seeing some television footage of Senator Richardson, who was the relevant Minister at the time, going up to Ravenshoe and being quite vigorously jostled by angry workers concerned about the problem of jobs-well they might be. That is the very point on which our support for this censure motion rests. The whole basis of the contractual arrangements which were entered into to support the Ravenshoe mill was precisely to address and defuse that problem; to supply economic support for the people of Ravenshoe so that the mill could continue to employ people and the objections to the declaration of the wet tropics area as a World Heritage area would be defused.

That is the relevance which it bears right to this day, when the Queensland Government is now looking to establish a hydro-electric scheme in the same area-which includes part of the World Heritage area-by damming the Tully and Millstream rivers. This would damage the World Heritage area and, in the process, provide a few jobs. I can well understand that, with the experience of the failure of the undertakings which were given in relation to the mill and the experience of the proven unreliability of the Government in addressing the problem of jobs in relation to environmental protection, the actions of the former Minister for the environment have made it more difficult for the objection to the construction of the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme to be seriously considered and given effect, and that is therefore less likely.

If we look at the economic background to this situation, we find that there was a mill in Ravenshoe at the time. When one looks at the balance sheet for 30 June 1988-and this was the mill which the Minister was looking at-under the heading `Profit and loss account for the year ended 30th June 1988' we find that:

The company did not trade during the period. There were no items of income or expense, or transfers to or from reserves and provisions required to be disclosed in accordance with the Seventh Schedule of the Companies Regulations, as in force on 30th September, 1987.

In other words, the Government knew at the time that it was dealing with a mill which potentially could have provided employment, which could have addressed those very real and serious concerns by workers in the Ravenshoe area over the declaration of the World Heritage area, and which required a considerable amount of support to ensure that it became viable and would provide the necessary employment.

The Government proceeded to enter into an undertaking with the company Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. In the agreement drawn up between the Government and Plywood and Plastic, again dated June 1988-at the same time as the relevant balance sheet which I have just mentioned-the Government undertook to provide:
(a) an interest free loan of $4.5 million on or before 30 June 1988; and

(b) a subsidy for each of the years 1989, 1990, 1991 and 1992, payable by advance on the first day of July of each such year, of an amount which bears the same proportion to $2,125,000 as the number of days on which the mill is operating, or would but for the effects of a cyclone be operating, in the relevant year bears to the total number of the working days in the relevant year.

The agreement goes on to state that the working days shall not exceed 120 days. What all that means is that in the event that the mill worked 120 days-and note the past tense-the company would be paid $2,125,000. If it worked less than that, for reasons other than cyclones or various other conditions mentioned elsewhere, the company would get a proportion of that amount which related to the number of days worked. Clearly, the year had to be completed and the number of days known so that the subsidy, either the whole or part of that $2,125,000, could be calculated. The agreement which the company entered into set out a number of conditions:
The company shall until at least 30 June 1988 use the amount of the loan and the amounts of the subsidy to . . .

do various things. As we heard from Senator Boswell, there is considerable evidence now that the company misapplied the grants which were made to it and did not carry out its undertakings. The undertakings were, among other things, to:
(b) maintain a work force of at least 40 persons-
we know that did not happen-and:
(c) carry out its operations at the mill in accordance with good mill practice-
we know that did not happen-and:
(d) carry out its timber extraction operations so as to minimise environmental impacts.

It seems that the company did not do a great deal of work and so it probably would not have had a very great environmental impact one way or the other. The next one is a rather amusing one which reads:
(e) make good operating losses; . . .

I guess that the emphasis should be on the words `make good'. If one places the emphasis in the first sense, it certainly made good operating losses; there is no doubt about that at all. The agreement goes on:
(f) equip the mill to enable it to operate with respect to timber, other than timber obtained from within the region; and
(g) pay any stamp duty . . .

et cetera. Those were the conditions in the agreement, as far as I can see, which the Government entered into with the company. It was precisely the sort of agreement which, looking at it at the time, I am sure the Democrats would have had no complaint about and therefore would have strongly supported. The whole point I want to keep stressing is that, because of the sensitivity of the issue of declaration of this area as a world heritage area, this was an agreement which should have been incredibly closely supervised. The failure to supervise this particular agreement jeopardises every other like agreement with respect to protecting the environment and any measures which the Government may make to offset any concerns which those people directly affected by the decision are likely to express.

We move on then to the director's report, which was dated 1 September 1989. This report deals, of course, with a year later than the report I mentioned a moment ago, the annual report to the end of June 1988. In this report, Plywood and Plastic reports:
The year under review is one of rapid growth and significant development for the joint venture.
It goes on:

The signing of a long-term timber supply agreement with the New South Wales Forestry Commission led to the approval for capital expenditure of $5 million for the establishment of a veneer mill at Kyogle.
This is the first mention that this company was interested in a mill elsewhere in northern New South Wales. The report continues:
This mill-
referring to the Kyogle mill-
will be amongst the most modern in the world and certainly more advanced than any in Australia. The projected commissioning date is July, 1989.

That should have alerted anybody who was looking at that report that something was a little amiss, with the company Plywood and Plastic referring to building a mill elsewhere and drawing timber supplies from elsewhere and mentioning a commissioning date which is so near into the future. It talks about excellent growth having been experienced in the divisions and so on. Then, incredibly facetiously in retrospect, the report says:

None of this could have been achieved without the loyalty and commitment of our employees. Our people are our strength and our most important resource. The Directors gratefully acknowledge the contribution made by all employees.

That was a particularly cynical statement coming at that time, as we know what was already developing in relation to the employment of people in that mill and the way in which these directors were evidently misappropriating the grants from government to the Kyogle mill to which they have actually referred in that report.

We then move on to a report from the Managing Director, Mr Fergus Macdonald, to the Assistant Secretary of the National Heritage Branch of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and to a letter dated 13 December 1989, just before the date on which the cheque to which Senator Boswell has referred was paid. That was paid in January 1990. This report from the Managing Director refers to a number of actions which were going on in the mill at the time. It refers to retooling, audit accounts and capital expenditure overruns. That is where we pick up slightly over $1m of capital expenditure overrun and a request for early payment.

We then find that an amount equivalent to half of the $2.125m per year, less interest which would be payable on that amount, was paid six months early and was paid not to the company to which it should have been paid but rather to another company, and that money was simply lost. That is the story. We then find that the company was in receivership. As Senator Boswell has pointed out, there was little left for the workers, for the people of Ravenshoe, in terms of employment.

I return to the matter that I really do wish to stress. We supported very strongly the declaration of this World Heritage area. We recognise that when decisions such as this are made, some of them are very sensitive in terms of their impact on the local people. It is absolutely appropriate that under those circumstances the Government should not be expecting the local people to pick up the tab for the welfare of all the people of Australia; indeed, in this case for the people of the whole world because it is a World Heritage area. Everybody should contribute to the welfare of those who are directly and adversely affected by the decision to declare the area a World Heritage area.

The Government was correct in its decision. It contracted a very reasonable arrangement with the mill; but from that point onwards the Minister failed to properly supervise that agreement, knowing how sensitive it was and how there would surely be similar situations-we are faced with one right now in relation to the Tully-Millstream decision-in which the failure of this undertaking would jeopardise later undertakings with respect to the protection of the environment.

For that reason we believe that the second leg of Minister Ray's assertion has been established-that the Minister must accept responsibility. This was not an ordinary contractual arrangement. The responsibility goes far beyond the actual amount of money; it goes to the whole question of the proper supervision of environmentally sensitive decisions by this Government, both now and in the future. We believe that the Minister has not handled the situation competently. The Minister has handled it quite inadequately. For that reason, unfortunately, because in other respects the Minister was a good Minister, on this occasion we believe we have no choice but to support, and support quite strongly, this censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 October 1990, Senator Richardson told the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The main point made in the answer is that what has happened with those creditors is not as a result of World Heritage listing, but of what has occurred at the mill since. There is a big difference.

How true that statement was, and how relevant it was, in fact, to the points made earlier by Senator Ray on the Government side in seeking to defend Senator Richardson's negligence and failure to properly supervise the operations of his then Department-the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-and his failure to ensure that the Commonwealth assistance agreement intended for the sawmill and the people of Ravenshoe was applied to that purpose.

Senator Ray attempted to state that Senate Boswell had misrepresented his position on this whole matter. Nothing could be further from the truth. But this is not about whether one supports World Heritage listing or otherwise; this is about ministerial conduct and ministerial responsibility. Therefore, I feel it is important that I address the matters raised by Senator Ray in defence of Senator Richardson.

Senator Ray quoted an article by Dr Geoffrey Marshall in 1986 which said that it was absurd for someone, whom the Minister has never heard of but who has made a mistake, to see the Minister censured. Indeed, I would agree with that statement. Unfortunately, from the evidence that Senator Richardson was forced to provide to the Committee of the Whole on 30 May this year, the man responsible, in fact, sat next to Senator Richardson during the Estimates.

When we look at the Westminster principle of ministerial responsibility, we see there is a grave difference between the practice of this Parliament and the practice of Westminster. In this Parliament, we have a process of Estimates committees. At that time, Senator Richardson was not only the Minister who attended the Estimates committees but also he was the Minister responsible for the portfolio. There is no doubt that on any reasonable test Senator Richardson should not only have known about what went on with regard to these payments but also, as the responsible Minister, he had to know.

It is Senator Richardson's irresponsibility, Senator Richardson's failure to properly manage his Department, which causes this censure motion to be brought before us today. As Senator Ray has said, `Censure motions have often been debased, more so at the other end of the building than here'. This is not a debased censure motion; this is a motion that goes right to the heart of Senator Richardson's conduct as a Minister. This is why Senator Richardson deserves to be censured.

There are two legs of responsibility that Senator Ray said had to be established: the first was that something had to have been done wrongly-we will get on to that later-and the second leg, he said, was that the Minister had to be directly responsible. We have already seen that in all probability the officer who approved this payment outside the terms of the Commonwealth's agreement sat in Estimates with Senator Richardson. But even if that is not the case, as Senator Coulter has so ably pointed out, this was a very special agreement. This was not just an ordinary departmental act. Senator Richardson, on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia, signed an assistance agreement with Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, the company which operated the Ravenshoe mill.

Senator Richardson made the people of Ravenshoe a very particular promise; it was that no-one would be disadvantaged by a World Heritage listing of the area. For that reason, Senator Richardson as Minister also carried with him a very particular responsibility, one that arose from his promise and from the agreement which he as a Minister signed and which he as a Minister failed to oversee.

On 30 May this year, what we heard from Senator Richardson was that an agreement that he had signed as Minister had been varied by a departmental officer, he told us, without any advice to him. Of course, the problem with this is very simple, that the company that received the payment was not the company which was entitled to receive the money under the terms of the Commonwealth's agreement. So, in effect, the Commonwealth has failed to keep its obligations under the agreement, by paying the money to the wrong company. Of course, this is an area of grave responsibility. It is absurd for Senator Richardson to come before this place and say that he can delegate-or rather, that he can allow a departmental officer to vary the terms of an agreement that he has made on behalf of the Commonwealth. That is extraordinary, to say the least, but that is what Senator Richardson is trying to tell this Senate he has allowed. By allowing that to occur, by failing to exercise a proper managerial role in respect of his Department, Senator Richardson makes himself culpable and makes himself subject to the censure that is being moved here today.

That is the first area of concern that we have. The money did not go to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, the company with whom the Commonwealth made the deal, but instead it went to National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd, a company in Kyogle. As a result, this payment may well have been unlawful. It was advanced, by both myself and Senator Spindler on 30 May, that the officer who approved the payment had no authority to approve it. A contract signed by a Minister clearly needs a Minister's signature if the terms of that contract are to be varied. Moreover, it is very doubtful that this payment could have been lawful. There is no way in which this payment could have been authorised by the agreement if in fact it was not paid to the company with which the Commonwealth had the agreement. It is just preposterous for Senator Richardson to try to maintain anything else.

Further along in this four-year saga involving Senator Richardson, his Department and their incompetence, we see the failure to adequately supervise what was happening at the mill, manifested in particular by a failure to obtain proper financial accounts for the company at the time at which the payment was made. This is very interesting. Here are the documents that Senator Richardson tabled in the Senate on 30 May. The letter that was written to his Department said, at point 9:
Audited accounts.
These will be completed on Friday, 15 December 1989 and forwarded to you forthwith.

This is what the Department was told on 13 December 1989. Furthermore, the Minister's Department had correspondence with Price Waterhouse. What did Price Waterhouse tell the Government? What did it say was a reasonable thing for the Minister and his Department to do? Price Waterhouse said, at point 3 of its letter of 21 December 1989:
Also you should obtain from the company a deed of release stating that the net amount received is for full discharge of the amount contractually agreed upon, i.e. $1,062,500.
The letter goes on to say, at point 4:
. . . we believe the company should supply their most recent management accounts and projections to support their cash flow need before any payment is made.

This is, of course, 21 December. A further letter was written on 28 December and, as a result of that, the Government or the Department approved-or somebody approved-late in December 1989 the payment of those moneys. But at no time has the Minister been able to show the Senate that either he or his departmental officers even sighted the appropriate financial accounts to which Price Waterhouse had referred. At no time has he been able to show that either he or his Department exercised the usual degree of prudence and caution which a normal commercial party would exercise. In other words, there was a manifest failure to supervise what was going on at Ravenshoe mill. There was a total neglect of the recommendations received by the Commonwealth's financial advisers in respect of this payment, and that neglect falls fairly and squarely at the doorstep of the Minister who was responsible. Senator Richardson told the Senate, in one of his frequent discourses, in October 1989:
I accept that as a matter of course in this business one has to cop flak.

We have been very, very careful in the case that we have brought forward. We have waited some seven months. We have amassed the evidence. We have looked in detail and with care and consideration to the matters of which Senator Richardson should have been apprised. We have moved this censure motion only as a matter of last resort, because we feel without a doubt that Senator Richardson really does deserve to cop the flak.

There is a third area in which Senator Richardson has been negligent, in which Senator Richardson has failed in his responsibility as a Minister, namely, that the payment was allowed to be paid before the due date and at variance with the terms of the agreement. In doing so, no legal advice was obtained at the time and the deed of release, to which I have previously referred, was not obtained from the company, even though this was recommended by Price Waterhouse. The essential thing to note here is that the payment due on 1 July 1990 was a payment in advance for the 1990-91 financial year. So, not only was the payment made in the wrong financial year-and there is an argument that it may have been made without an appropriation, but I do not wish to canvass that issue here-but, importantly, it was clearly not in accordance with the terms of the agreement. In making the payment early, neither Senator Richardson nor his Department bothered to demean themselves so much as to obtain legal advice.

In fact, the reason that Senator Richardson gave to the Senate on 30 May was, roughly, that the Department thought that the payment was within the ambit of the agreement and therefore it did not need to obtain legal advice. Therefore, Senator Richardson and his departmental officers get very close to putting themselves above the constraints of the law, above the constraints that reasonably prudent people would follow and above the normal course of care and consideration that we would expect of a Minister. This attitude was allowed to flourish in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories under Senator Richardson's management.

Now we come to what would be, if it were not so tragic, the hilarious case of $837,000 worth of machinery being sold from the mill. It appears that neither Senator Richardson nor his Department knew about this until Senator Boswell raised the matter in October 1990. As Senator Boswell said, it is not as though $837,000 of machinery is something that one can pack up in one's lunch bag. It involved a veneer mill and a boiler. One of those items of plant and equipment was half the size of an 8,000-square foot shed. Yet, Senator Richardson and his Department did not seem to know about it, which is really quite extraordinary, because Senator Richardson told the Senate on 16 October-and I love this quote:

Like any good business manager the Commonwealth did not let its loan go unwatched. Officers of the Department regularly telephoned the manager of the mill to seek information on progress with the retooling.

Maybe if they had shown a little more care and consideration they might have known that all the machinery was going out the back door but, of course, they did not. As Senator Boswell has said, Senator Richardson failed to adequately supervise it, his Department failed to adequately supervise it and in so doing, they became culpable for the failure of the Ravenshoe mill.

Now there is the matter of the payment of the cheque to the wrong company. We have already canvassed this issue before, but there is a special significance to this. I want to quote again from an answer that Senator Richardson gave to the Senate on 16 October 1990-we are not damning him by our words, we are damning his by his own words. His statement, which is a great one, was:
The assistance package was to benefit not only the sawmill but the Ravenshoe community and all North Queenslanders.

Of course, the company to which this $968,000 cheque was paid-it is almost a million dollars-was not Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, the operator of the Ravenshoe mill, but Timbertech which, as Senator Boswell has proved, is the trade name of a company called National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd. What does National Associated Plywood do? Does it run a mill at Ravenshoe? No. Does it have an interest in north Queensland? No. What does National Associated Plywood do? It runs a veneer mill in Kyogle.

By allowing this money to be paid to the wrong company, Senator Richardson has deprived the people of Ravenshoe and all north Queenslanders of their due. The claim that was made to the Department was on the basis that the mill at Ravenshoe needed the money for cash flow difficulties-and goodness gracious, did it need the money for cash flow difficulties! I have already shown the Senate that as early as 7 June 1989 this company had grave difficulty in paying its unsecured creditors. We saw $230,000 of overdue payments to creditors stacked up at that mill. We saw people cutting off credit to the mill. We saw one poor electrician, who was owed $16,000 in June 1989 ultimately being owed $60,000 when the mill finally collapsed in April 1990.

If this payment had gone to the right company, the people who were owed money by the company-that is, the people of Ravenshoe and all north Queenslanders, to whom Senator Richardson referred-would have been paid. But the Department paid the money to the wrong company and those people were not paid. This is the extent of the negligence and the irresponsibility that has flourished under Senator Richardson and in his Department.

The money that was intended for these people, as Senator Coulter has said, to give them confidence in what the Commonwealth was doing with regard to the World Heritage listing, never made it to the right place because the Government sent it somewhere else. That is the core of what Senator Richardson has done. It is not just an academic exercise. We are talking about real people and real lives- the lives of a town of 2,200 people in an area which has been devastated and shell shocked by this Government's incompetence, and its failure to honour its promise that nobody in Ravenshoe would be worse off as a result of World Heritage listing. Senator Richardson quite correctly said that it had everything to do with what went on with the mill and nothing at all to do with World Heritage listing. What he did not say on 16 October was that it also had a lot to do with what was going on in his office.

What we have seen, basically, is Senator Richardson making a grandiose promise, signing an agreement, taking upon himself a special responsibility towards the people of Ravenshoe and then being especially negligent in the discharge of his responsibility and allowing his Department to do things that it should never have been allowed to do. In short, Senator Richardson presided over a rotten house where sloth and indifference were allowed to substitute for caution, thoroughness and responsibility.

It is Senator Richardson's culpability, Senator Richardson's key role in allowing all of these things to happen, that bring him before the Senate today and cause this censure motion. Senator Richardson has brought it upon himself. From the very start, from the shoddy assistance agreement that Senator Richardson signed, through his failure to adequately monitor what was going on, right up to the payment of $968,000-the almost a million dollars from the million dollar man to the wrong company-is all Senator Richardson's doing.

Senator Richardson fumbled around time and time again trying to explain what happened. One of the best explanations that I like was given on 29 May-less than a month ago. Senator Richardson first told the Senate that he approved the payment. Then, after Question Time, he told the Senate:

the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirmed in my office during Question Time that I was not informed of that payment to the company or that the payment was being made at all before it was made.

At one point in the day he said, `Yes, I authorised the payment'. Then he said, `Not only did I not authorise the payment, I didn't even know it happened', and he was the Minister. That is the sort of thing that has gone on. The only problem is that it is lives-good, hard working Australian citizens-that have been affected by what Senator Richardson and his Department have failed to do.

For these manifold reasons and these manifold condemnations of Senator Richardson, this censure motion has been brought before the chamber today. We have done it reluctantly. We waited for seven months, hoping that Senator Richardson might find an explanation for the files in my office-papers over a foot thick of answers, correspondence and documents that we have tabled here, every single one of them forcing Senator Richardson to make yet another admission to the Senate. The admission that he must now make is that his negligence and incompetence caused the suffering at Ravenshoe. That is why this censure motion is being moved against him today. That is why I urge all honourable senators to support this motion and show Senator Richardson that he must exercise proper responsibility as a Minister when he makes promises to people, and that when he signs agreements he has to ensure that they are kept. Senator Richardson did not do so and that is why we seek to censure Senator Richardson today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is actually the second time that I will have been censured-on the assumption that the Australian Democrats support the motion. The first time that I was censured was fairly interesting. I was in this chamber representing the then Minister for Defence. The then Minister for Defence had allowed a number of questions to go past the requisite period of time without being answered, and these questions on the Notice Paper, which were not my responsibility, were the cause of my censure. So I learned fairly early on in my career as a Minister in the Senate that censure motions mean very little, because the idea of censuring me for the failure of another Minister in another place was ridiculous. But the Senate did so and I accepted it. I think I learned to live with it relatively quickly. We all got on with business.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not spoken to the Australian Democrats about this. I understand that Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have. I have not. I am told they are voting for the motion, and that is Senator Coulter's inclination. It is disappointing only in the sense that they have not heard a response and I will endeavour to give them one. I hope they at least keep their minds open enough to listen to it.

There would appear to be, about this exercise, a couple of points upon which Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee continually rely. The first, it would appear, is that the advance payment was made. Senator O'Chee was at least kind enough not to go on with the notion that, because there is not an appropriation in one financial year, the next payment could not be made, and I am glad he did not, because that it would have been a waste of everyone's time. He knows it and that is why he did not.

Let us look at whether the Commonwealth, be that a Minister or officers acting on behalf of the Minister and the Commonwealth, makes advance payments. Under what circumstances can or should they make such payments? As all honourable senators would be aware, I hope, the Commonwealth enters into many financial assistance agreements with private enterprises for all sorts of purposes. It has done so for decades. There is nothing new in this. There are many, many cases where a schedule of payments has been agreed to and, later, that schedule has been varied by either bringing forward or postponing a payment. There is nothing unusual in it. It happens all the time. The Office of Commercial Law in the Attorney-General's Department has confirmed that advice to the Department. It is a frequent occurrence. So officers dealing with these matters, knowing it to be a frequent occurrence, do not need to seek legal opinion on whether it is possible to do it; it is done all the time.

The original agreement in this case is between the Commonwealth and the company. Each has acted through agents in the making of the agreement and each acts through agents in the carrying out of the agreement. I was the Commonwealth's agent in the making of it, obviously, as the person who signed the agreement. Departmental officers were the Commonwealth's agents in agreeing with the company to make an advance payment of part of the money. There is nothing unusual about that situation-nothing. It happens not only in my then Department but also in a whole number of departments right across the whole sphere of government.

In most cases departmental officers, with appropriate authority, might equally have made an original agreement of the kind that I made. In this case I happened to have made it, but that was because there were no officers in the Department at the time with sufficient delegations to sign an agreement of that kind for the amount of money included in the agreement. So the idea that there is anything unusual in this situation is simply wrong. At the time of the advance payment for assistance in January 1990 there were officers with the right kind of appropriate delegation.

The only other point to make about the administration of these agreements is that, subject to such issues as formal delegated authority, judgments on whether Ministers or their departmental officers act for the Commonwealth in making agreements are policy issues for responsible Ministers. Responsible Ministers take the view that those officers within a department who are dealing with a matter with the right kind of delegation can go forward and do it.

Anyone who wants to examine the question of the advance payments made in government, to make sure that we understand that there is nothing unusual, should look at the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories portfolio where payments can be and have sometimes been made in advance, such as grants to voluntary conservation organisations; assistance to the Australian Conservation Foundation for ecologically sustainable development; payments to Greening Australia Pty Ltd, a company to conduct community tree planting programs; funding for the Australian Opera, another company; the Australian Ballet School; the National Institute of Dramatic Art; and funding to the Film Finance Corporation. All of these bodies regularly have advance payments made when a case is established.

It goes on even more in other portfolios. Programs administered by the Industry Research and Development Board, in Senator Button's portfolio, include grants for industrial research and development; the national procurement and development program; the national teaching company scheme; grants provided by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; and payments for the States, Territories and local government for legal aid, hospital funding, health services and government schools. Agreements are made in a whole range of things between government and private companies or between government and other spheres and levels of government where, once a case is made out, the payment can be made in advance or postponed. That happens not only occasionally but regularly.

So the idea that Senator O'Chee in particular has attempted to push in the last few days that in some way a mistake has been made, that in some way it is unlawful-to use one of the words he used here the other day-that this payment was made in advance, is plain wrong. I know it suits the politics, it makes everyone in the Opposition happy and apparently it has succeeded today in titivating the odd Democrat. But it does not mean anything; that is the problem.

The mistake made here-and there is no denying that a mistake was made-is in what name was written on the cheque. It is appropriate for honourable senators to examine what my responsibility was or should have been in respect of the making out that cheque. As I told the Senate the other day, I was not informed at all of the payment-not at all-and I was not informed that that payment was being made in advance or the reasons for it. That is because the Department was administering the agreement and did not believe it was necessary to do so. Certainly there was no requirement on it to do so.

Looking at the making of the advance, it beggars the imagination that today I can be held responsible and held up to censure for my actions. The first point to make is that the officer who signed the authorisation that went over to the Department of Finance-an officer who is no longer with the Public Service-was someone I had never heard of and never met. The senior officer who authorised that officer was sitting in the chamber the other day and is here. Suppose it is accepted that I should have received a briefing on this from the Department, and I do not, but let us work on the basis that I should have; had I received a briefing and had I approved the payment, there was no way in the world I would have known that the cheque was made out to the wrong company. I could not because such a briefing would never be included for a Minister. It cannot be. I do not think people understand the system. I would, naturally enough, have approved a payment to the right company, as the Department did. But when it went to the person to actually fill out a form to go to the Department of Finance for a cheque to be made out, a more junior officer made an error. I could not possibly have been expected, even if I was being fully briefed at the time, to have ever seen that piece of paper. No Minister does.

It may be that people are titivated by this and think that it is a decent headline and is a good way to give me a kicking. Fair enough. I will learn to live with it. I do not think the letter of resignation will go in this afternoon and we will all go on about our business. However, we ought to understand the principle we are trying to establish. The Opposition parties are trying to set a standard for me that no Minister can ever possibly meet, that Opposition senators would not meet if they were in government and that no-one here can meet now. But I go further. I say that even if I--

TALK.START.PARA: —A Minister should resign when he is censured. Why won't you?
—I am going to get into the attitude of Opposition senators about this. I am glad Senator Knowles has raised this. I will quote from a great authority on the matter in Senator Durack.
—It is the second time you were censured. Why won't you resign?

—Just a moment. Others have been censured more than I. Some around here wear it as a badge of honour to be censured by Senator Knowles. We will hear later the words of the very great Senator Peter Durack, who did have time to reflect upon this matter. I noted that Senator Boswell was rather unkind to him in saying he did not care what Senator Durack thought. But I do.
—Oh, well--

—That will be in Hansard. It will be a bit hard to deny that one. It will be in Hansard. Senator Boswell will not be able to fix Hansard, either. That will be in it, so he will have to live with that one. I will have some fun with it later on.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that Senator Boswell is setting a standard I cannot possibly meet, let us then go to the issue of what would have happened had I been briefed. Had the responsible senior officer in the Department administering the agreement come to my office and briefed me about this matter, had he actually sat there and said, `Here is the letter from the company which requests an advance payment for these reasons. Here is our view on that. Here is what Price Waterhouse has said on that.', I have no doubt at all that I would have said, `Okay, if that is the case, make the advance payment'. I would have done so because any perfunctory calculation of the cost of employing 50-odd employees in an enterprise-even if we average it out at $30,000-works out to a lot of money each month. Obviously, that would have been causing the company some troubles, and it had short term cash flow problems for the reasons that were outlined in the documents that I presented last week.

Given all that Senator O'Chee said about the reasons why this agreement was signed in the first place, I would have gone to every length possible to advance money to the company to keep it going, because the whole exercise was about keeping the mill open and functioning and maintaining the employment of people in Ravenshoe-not only the direct employment of those who were in the mill, but also, of course, the employment of others in the town who indirectly benefited from it, be they shopkeepers, tradesmen or anybody else.

At the time of the World Heritage decisions in north Queensland, of which I think I can be justifiably proud, there was obviously a huge problem in the town of Ravenshoe. I understood that. I went there twice. The first time there was a small demonstration as I was blockaded on a forest road. The second time, as everyone knows, there was a very big demonstration in which I received a bit of a buffeting. I did not act on this because of that incident, but it was obvious that the fear and the trepidation of people in Ravenshoe about the effects of World Heritage listing were real. Even if the fears were not based on reality, they were real fears. I believe that the Government had an obligation, in setting up an assistance package for all those in north Queensland affected by rainforest logging cessation, to look particularly at towns such as Ravenshoe.

So I took the decision that, if the mill could be retooled and could gain access to a secure pine resource, it could go on for decades-I suppose that one hesitates to say `forever', but hopefully it will be forever-and that, even if the employment in the mill was not as great as it was before, it would still be significant and substantial. So, naturally enough, I took the view that we ought to be advancing sufficient money to the company to bring that change about. That is what the Government set about doing.

The original intention, which was not mentioned in the debate here today, was to make a gift to the company, to simply give it the money and say, `Go for it. You buy the machines and see what you can do'. In fact, the only reason we got any sort of look in for any kind of monitoring, the only reason we got any opportunity to see what was going on over a period of time, was that the company did not want all of the money in gift form. The company, largely for taxation reasons, preferred to receive part of the money in the form of a loan. It is because of the loan that the Commonwealth got a look in at all. I would not claim for a second that the loan was my idea. That came straight from the company. When that occurred, it was up to us to come to a formal agreement. That took some time. I finally signed it. Then we were to make payments as a result of that agreement.

Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have repeatedly asserted here that money was not spent for the right purpose, that money was diverted and that in some way that is our responsibility. It should be obvious enough to all Australians, and in particular all honourable senators, that one cannot guarantee the commercial honesty and probity of every person with whom one deals. If Senators O'Chee and Boswell are right about where the money might have gone, action must be taken on that score.

By the way, in accordance with the undertaking I gave the Senate last week, I have a meeting this evening with the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on this question to try to sort out how far I can go in informing the Senate of the progress of Commonwealth action. I will attempt to report tomorrow if the Attorney-General tells me whether there is anything that I can usefully add in that way. I am at a disadvantage because I cannot comment on those matters, but it is pretty obvious to all concerned that it is not a matter of suggesting even for a second that, if the wrong thing was being done, it occurred suddenly, beginning with the payment of the cheque to Timbertech. If what the honourable senators are alleging is true, it had been going on for a long time before that. It did not suddenly start with the third cheque.

As far as the third cheque is concerned, as honourable senators can see from the documents tabled last week, it was made out to the wrong name. It is not as though a cheque meant for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd went to the Western Mining Corporation. It went to a business name within a complex web of companies, and it went for the purposes that were outlined in the letter. I believe, and certainly the legal section of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is of this view, that the Commonwealth's position is not weakened because of it.

But I do not deny for a second that an error was made in the making out of the cheque. What I have tried to explain to the Senate, however, is that, even if I had been fully briefed on the reasons for an advance payment and had agreed to that payment, I still would not have seen the bit of paper that went across to the Department of Finance from a more junior officer whom I did not know and had not heard of, and I could not have been held responsible for it. The basis of the motion before us today is that I should have got a briefing on something about which I could not have had a briefing anyway, and that I should be censured for not getting it. Is it any wonder that the currency of censure motions is being devalued because of this?

Senator Boswell continually refers to audited statements. The audited statements to which he refers, unfortunately for him, relate to the financial year that ended on 30 June 1989. They were going to bear little relation to a short term cash flow problem that was occurring during the next financial year six months on. I am afraid that, had we received them, that could not have been used as the basis upon which a decision would have been made. Again, I think Senator Boswell would dip out if there were an assumption that I had a further responsibility on that matter. I could not have.

Given the explanation that I have given about the chain of events within the Department-that is, a senior officer giving an authorisation for a cheque to be drawn and then a junior officer, in making out the form to the Department of Finance, getting the name wrong-and given that I did not know the officer who made that error at the time and had not heard of her, to use phrases that have been quoted from articles today, I find it difficult to believe that I would be censured, but not too difficult, knowing the numbers and knowing that apparently the minds of the Australian Democrats were made up before they heard that.

But I would like to refer to an authority on the question-that is, Senator Durack, who, before I came here, had to face a motion on the bottom of the harbour schemes and other related schemes. He went through quite some difficulties because in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth a number of opinions had been given on a bottom of the harbour tax matter of which he had not been made aware. I want to quote from what Senator Durack said, as recorded on page 632 of Hansard on 7 September 1982. I will not read the whole quote but, in referring to why he did not know about a number of opinions, he said:

The reason is that the officers of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, although within my Department, deal with a large number of cases. That is the business of the officers; they do not keep telling me what they are doing from day to day or from week to week. This is the most childish conception of ministerial responsibility. How on earth does anybody believe in this day and age, with departments as large as they are and with the enormous activities of government, that Ministers can know or ought to know of all the ramifications of the actions of their departments. I find it utterly incredible that anybody would have such a notion. Yet here we have people who masquerade as an alternative government believing that this is the way modern government operates.
Finally, in the last words of his speech, talking about how a Minister is to be judged, he said:

I believe as I said before, that the Minister should be judged on the response that is made when there is mismanagement or when bungling occurs in his department, and that he cannot be expected to know, in this day and age about all the matters taking place in his department. He is to be judged by the way in which he acts and the way that the Government acts when such a matter is brought to his attention and I believe the Government's record in response to this matter should find favour with the Senate.

I was on leave when the decision was made to make this payment. I was not even on duty: I was on holidays. Apparently, the point is lost on everyone-although I am surprised that it is lost on all the Democrats-that, even if I were supposed to have been briefed, I was on leave and could not have been. I was on holidays in Queensland. I was in Surfers Paradise with my family but, apparently, that is no excuse-I still should have been briefed. Apparently, officers should have jumped on a plane, stuck on a swimsuit and met me at Surfers. At that point, I would have been briefed and all would have been well.

Today there is before the Senate a motion censuring me, firstly, for a decision taken when I was on leave; secondly, for a cheque being made out in a wrong name that I could not possibly have been briefed on anyway, as it was a mistake that would have occurred after the briefing point; and, thirdly, for being responsible, apparently, for a fabled officer whom I have not met and have not heard of. I would suggest that paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) make this censure motion a joke.

I take my ministerial responsibilities seriously. I do not believe that when I am on holidays-and I do not get many of them-I ought to be held responsible for decisions that are made then. If the Opposition and the Democrats proceed with this motion and carry it, in the knowledge that I was on leave and could not have known anyway, even if I had been briefed, because the mistake occurred after the authorisation for the payment process-and I have gone through a list, which is only a part list, there being others, to explain to the Senate where advance payments are made and why officers do not need to seek legal opinions to make them-the process will become a joke. We ought not make censure motions a joke. I will be the first Minister ever censured for a decision taken while he was on leave. I will be breaking new ground. I will be No. 1. But, if the Opposition and the Democrats wish to proceed, so be it. I can assure the Senate that I can live with that. It does not worry me or phase me for a second.

I believe that, as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, I carried out my responsibilities fully. When it comes to north Queensland and the saving of rainforests, which is the real reason I am being pursued today, as far as I am concerned I am proud of what I did and would do it all again tomorrow. I hope other Ministers who occupy that portfolio over the years get the opportunity to save areas in the way I did. I hope that, when they do, they do not take a holiday because, as soon as they do, they will come up against what is happening to me today. I am to be censured for going on holidays in January. For going away with my family and for not being there, the Senate, apparently, is going to carry a motion. I ask the Democrats to have a long think about that, as they should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate-and it might be worth while for Senator Richardson to consider this-that the Senate is censuring him for failing to supervise the actions of his former department, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in a number of ways. That is what the Senate is doing. It is not censuring him because he had a holiday in January, but because he failed to supervise the actions of his Department. He spent all of his time in the Ravenshoe area, and all of his time in the World Heritage listed areas, running around getting publicity for himself and his Government so that it would be re-elected by the greenies. That is what he was concerned about. He was not concerned about running his Department, looking after things as they should be looked after and doing the proper things that had to be done. He was simply concerned about gaining a bit of notoriety for himself and his Party so that it could get the votes of the conservation movement in the hope of forming another government.

SPEECH.PARA: We did not want any particular exceptional standard from Senator Richardson-a standard that could not be met. All we wanted was a bit of attention and competence from this Minister so that he would look after the things that he created and the hurt that he caused. He gives the direct lie in relation to Senator Boswell's comment that Senator Boswell's motion is vindictive or has something to do with World Heritage listing. Of course it does not. World Heritage listing exists. It is accepted by everybody now, and it will always be accepted. What we are looking at is his mismanagement of a very important government department.

As Senator Coulter so rightly pointed out, this was not any ordinary agreement, a normal government function-something that would happen in the normal course of events-it was a particularly important matter that had not only become part of Australian history but also was recognised worldwide. It was a most important occasion. We might have expected that once Senator Richardson had the votes he would have done something to properly administer his Department.

Senator Richardson's rather pitiful defence said nothing really. He was talking about advance payments made, trying to downplay the seriousness of paying money to the wrong person. Both he and Senator Ray have embarked upon a program of belittling this Senate and belittling censure motions. I remind Senator Richardson that censure motions, if they are passed, are passed because a majority of honourable senators, who represent a majority of people in Australia, consider that something very serious has happened-in this case, the administration of a government department. For Senator Richardson and Senator Ray to belittle the motions of the Senate is appalling; that in itself deserves censure. I wonder whether Senator Ray and Senator Richardson are trying to downplay this because they are a bit frightened that, after the events of earlier this week, some of their own colleagues might take the opportunity to come over and vote with us and record their censure against the man who has caused so much disruption to this Government and this nation in the last week.

I do not have a lot to say on Ravenshoe. All of that has been very clearly and concisely put by my colleagues Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee, and also by Senator Coulter, who gave a very clear address and showed a clear understanding of what ministerial responsibility is all about. It is about honesty and integrity in government. It is about looking after things and having a bit of responsibility.

Senator Ray went on with some pious nonsense in a very half-hearted defence of Senator Richardson. One might say that if one gets people like Senator Ray to give that sort of half-hearted defence, who needs enemies when one has that sort of person as a backup? One might even think that Senator Ray's contribution was designed to ensure that the maximum number of people voted for the censure motion. Obviously, Senator Ray had not read the motion and he had not listened to Senator Boswell who gave a very clear and concise account of what it was all about. If he had read it, he would not have stood up in the chamber and admitted that he knew nothing about the whole motion.

As I mentioned, the vindictiveness and lack of genuineness that Senator Ray has suggested of the censure motion are obviously not true. This is not a matter that has come up just this week or just recently. It is a matter that Senator Boswell was pursuing long before I came into parliament and it is a matter that both Senator O'Chee and I have been pursuing since we have been here. It had nothing to do with World Heritage listings. It had something to do with the people-ordinary Australians-who have been devastated by Senator Richardson's lack of attention to his portfolio. That is what this matter is all about. That is what Senator Boswell has been trying to bring to light. He has not tried to be vindictive or tried to re-create the debate on World Heritage listing. That has all finished.

Senator Boswell has been trying to look after little Australians, ordinary Australians, who have been devastated because Senator Richardson does not have the time or the inclination to look after his portfolio. Senator Richardson is pretty good at getting the votes when he can go and fool the greenies to get them on side. He is pretty good at trying to get the votes to back up his leadership contenders, although in recent days, that has been shown to be rather a farce. But he has prided himself on that; that is what he has concentrated on. He has had no interest in Ravenshoe. He has had no interest in the people who have been hurt very badly. He was only interested in getting the votes.

I might say that even the conservation movement has now woken up to Senator Richardson. In a newspaper article, Mr Phillip Toyne, the Executive Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, was quoted as saying that:
Ravenshoe was an ugly example of where the system has gone wrong.
We wanted to work out a fair deal through consultation, but it didn't happen.

The Government has to come in with a package to help in those type of circumstances. But things have gone from bad to worse at Ravenshoe with what seems to be misuse of public money and the large cost to Ravenshoe.

So even the conservation movement is waking up to the fact that no matter how much the Government talks about it, how much it wants to do, it has to get in there and supervise its departments and make things work. Of course, that is what Senator Richardson has not done and that is what he has been censured for not doing. If one reads the censure motion, one will understand that. This was not an ordinary case; it was not just some ordinary administrative thing. It involved a series of actions by Senator Richardson on a very, very important matter, one that had worldwide headlines. Ever since I have been in this place, Senator Richardson has embarked upon a course of untruth, of hiding the proposals, of pushing things away and of giving half answers. Heavens knows that we have given him every opportunity to do the right thing.

We have asked questions here and we have asked questions in two lots of Estimates committee hearings. We have made speeches. We have spoken to Senator Richardson; we have pleaded with him. We have done everything possible to try to get some justice and to get the problems that he has created sorted out, but he has ignored us.

For Senator Ray to turn up today and say that the censure motion is a vindictive action about something that happened years and years ago is complete nonsense. The number of people who turned up here to support Senator Richardson in this very serious censure motion is an indication of just what his own colleagues think about his attention to this matter.

I want to highlight briefly the distress that Senator Richardson and his Government have caused the people of Ravenshoe-not just those people in business, not just those who were in unions when they had a job, but also the ordinary people. This motion is all about the money that was supposed to have gone to the mill at Ravenshoe. If it had gone there it would have kept the mill going; it would have provided jobs; and it would have given employment and succour to the people of Ravenshoe. If that had been done, the situation in Ravenshoe would not be as bad as it is now. Because Senator Richardson chose not to properly administer his Department, that money has not gone to Ravenshoe; that money has gone to another company which appears to own a mill in Kyogle, the creditors of which, I assume, are very happy with Senator Richardson because, no doubt, they have been paid.

One wonders whether the creditors in Kyogle-in New South Wales-were perhaps some more of Senator Richardson's infamous mates, because the money certainly went to no-one in Queensland. It went to people in New South Wales, no doubt to creditors in New South Wales. A formal legal agreement-it was not just a whim-said that Senator Richardson should have paid that money to Plywood and Plastics Pty Ltd and that it should have been paid on 1 July.

What has Senator Richardson done? He has paid the money to a different company which owns a different mill in a different State with different employees and different creditors. He claims that it is not his fault. He claims that it is the fault of some junior clerk. How is that for ministerial responsibility? He cannot even stand up and take it on the chin. He blames some kid who cannot defend himself, who cannot come in here and who will never have the chance to say anything. Senator Richardson gets up and blames this fellow. Senator Richardson is always too preoccupied doing other things; he is the great king-maker.

What has happened to Senator Richardson now? Where is he now? He is in such odium that the only person his Party can get to defend him is now his competitor for leadership of the Right faction. He has not only let down the people of Ravenshoe, but he has also let down his colleagues who blindly followed him and thought they might get something out of the spoils of office. Boy oh boy, don't they now know? All they had to do was ask the people of Ravenshoe, who could have told them not to bother following Senator Richardson who had no idea of what he was talking about. They would have known that. But anyhow, Senator Ray showed today that he is cock-a-hoop with his victory-his coming leadership of the Senate. What we are trying to say to the Senate is that Senator Richardson has not properly pursued this matter.

Madam Acting Deputy President, in answers to the Senate all the way through this saga, Senator Richardson has pretended that things were done properly. He said in December 1989, `We sought financial reports'. Again, early in 1990, he said:
There was no indication at this time that there was any financial difficulty in the mill or the holding company.
That is what Senator Richardson has had us believe all the way through this matter.

We found out a few weeks ago that, in early January 1990, the company wrote a letter saying that it was in financial difficulties and that it had problems. The letter contained things that should have made the Minister and his senior officers have a closer look at the matter. What has happened on the way through? Senator Richardson has tried to mislead the Senate by suggesting that everything was okay in January 1990.

Had things been okay in January 1990, had the cheque been paid to a company that was solvent, had Senator Richardson and his officers made sure that that money went to the mill and that the mill continued to operate, we would not have the real social problems that we have in Ravenshoe now. Senator Richardson should have some concern for the street kids of Ravenshoe, the unemployed, the disadvantaged, the Aboriginals who are now out of work and suffering more than others. He is not interested in those sorts of things; he is more interested in flitting around the world looking after his mates like Brian Burke.

Senator Richardson lists as some of his interests: welfare and structural adjustment-how appropriate for a man who has so blatantly looked after his own welfare so well over the years instead of the welfare of all of those people around him. It is interesting for him to say that he is interested in structural adjustment because he has misused the structural adjustment package that was allowed for Ravenshoe in order to prop up some business in New South Wales. Is that his interest in structural adjustment?

Looking at Senator Richardson's lavish indulgences on his overseas trips, it is worth comparing these expenses with the debts owed to the people of Ravenshoe who gave credit to the mill believing that Senator Richardson was doing what he was supposed to be doing and supervising the retooling of the mill. The $4,473 that Senator Richardson spent in car bills over two days while he was in Ireland could have paid back the $4,000 that was owed to Johnsons Transport in Ravenshoe, for example. The $1,348 hire car bill which Senator Richardson clocked up in the Hague in January earlier this year could have paid back the $1,300 owed to R and A Berwick in Ravenshoe. The $1,532 hire car bill which the Minister achieved in Rome could have paid back the $1,300 owed to the Club Hotel Motel, the $142 owed to the Ravenshoe Pharmacy, the $69 owed to Gerrys Upholstery and the $25 owed to Doyles Electrical. The Minister's $894 hire car bill and his sumptuous $1,000 per night accommodation in London could have easily paid back the $800 owed to NZ Hydro.

The Minister's now notorious Comcar overtime bill of $30,000 could have covered the $16,000 owed to G and D Williams Builders, the $11,500 owed to K and A Chatfield, the $308 owed to Sheppards Newsagency and the $200 owed to the Koolmoon Motel. And the list goes on and on. In fact, the Minister's three overseas trips in the last eight months alone, amounting to $130,048, could have paid easily the $80,000 owing to Condon Contractors of Ravenshoe, the $20,000 owing to Kidner Logging and the $28,000 owing to P.K. Engineering.
