The total of $220,000 owed to Ravenshoe businesses could have been paid easily from this Minister's $11m budget to publicise the worth of the Department of Social Security. This Minister is proud of the fact-and he said it with some glee during Question Time some months ago-that he spent $11m on balloons and other things in order to publicise the Department of Social Security. I would not have thought the Department of Social Security needed publicising-it has the most business it has ever had because of the recession that Senator Ray's lot thought we had to have. Those opposite made us have the recession and because of that they have given the Department of Social Security all of the business it will ever need. The Minister does not need to spend $11m publicising it and getting new clients.

Just a small fraction of that $11m would have done something for the people who are suffering in Ravenshoe. Senator Ray would not understand that, but I challenge him to go there some day and see what it is all about. See if his heart cannot be wrenched by the real social and family problems of the people in that area, and all because Senator Ray's former colleague Senator Richardson could not be bothered to put in the time making sure that cheques were paid to the right place and he could not be bothered to put in the time making sure that a proper and comprehensive legal agreement made between him and a company called Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd and signed by him was, in fact, honoured. That is why these people in Ravenshoe are facing these problems-because Senator Richardson has shown a complete disregard for his responsibilities as a Minister.

We are told that it was not until two weeks ago-as the Minister said last Thursday-that he first saw the letter which indicated that Ravenshoe was in trouble. Are we to believe what the Minister said: that this was the first time he knew the mill had had financial problems prior to receivership? I say we cannot believe Senator Richardson when he says that. Can he not understand that his lack of care and his acts of gross negligence are the root cause of the social, family and economic problems that are now facing Ravenshoe? If Senator Richardson had abided by that agreement, if he had paid the cheque at the right time and to the correct company, then the problems which are now facing Ravenshoe would not be there.

The acts of treachery which are so evident this week in Senator Richardson's actions against his own colleagues are nothing compared with what the people of Ravenshoe think of him. The people of Ravenshoe were initially lulled into a false sense of security by Senator Richardson's promise that they would be looked after and that no-one would suffer as a result of his actions in relation to World Heritage listings. Of course, they blindly followed him. They believed blindly what he said he would do. Of course, he has not done it and he has been involved in the greatest mismanagement, lack of attention and irresponsibility that any Minister could ever perpetrate in a matter which was not just an ordinary-day matter, but one of great importance to the people of Australia.

I had hoped that, as an act of contrition to the people of Ravenshoe, Senator Richardson would have the courage to resign because of his gross mismanagement and the real hurt that he has caused all of those people. If he does not have the courage to do that and if he is not prepared to make that act of contrition he should be sacked by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-not for the things that have happened this week, but for the fact that all the way through this Ravenshoe saga Senator Richardson has not been interested and has not administered his portfolio properly. This has caused the mill to fail, businesses have been lost, livelihoods have been shattered, houses have been taken by mortgagees, kids have been forced to leave school, unemployment and crime have increased dramatically, there have been suicides related to this matter, and the social and family problems are enormous. All of these things result from this Minister's inability to administer his Department properly. For that, the Senate should censure Senator Richardson and he should then take that censure as an indication of what the people of Australia want him to do: to get out; to resign. If he is not prepared to do that, the Prime Minister should sack him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come to have some regard for the Senate while I have been a member of this place. I hold many of its processes to be very good and there is much good debate. We have before us today a censure motion which I think everybody has said is a very serious step indeed-or it should be a very serious step. I think in years to come people will read about the proceedings that have surrounded this censure motion and they will make a judgment as to how we, as a Senate, acted. They will say that this censure motion is in the nature of a judicial hearing because this Senate will impose a very significant penalty on a Minister and it will say, `We censure this man'. The people will say, `Did the Senate come to its conclusions on the basis of calm reflection? Did it apply a test that would meet the dictates of natural justice? Did it give a hearing to both sides? Did it come to a conclusion with an unbiased mind?'. Or will the people decide that on this day the Senate applied lynch law, that in a fit of emotion with outpourings of venom the Senate came to a predetermined conclusion?

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the speech by the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. At least from the parts that I heard, he gave a defence of his administration. He said that not only his Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories but all departments work in a particular way, one which would have made it impossible for him to see what cheque was sent out and what happened on this occasion. He said, `Look, everybody who is knowledgeable would know that what I say is true'. He quoted Senator Durack, a very eminent and honourable senator of this place, in support of what he said.
I thought I would come in here and hear an answer to what Senator Richardson said. In light of that, I will read what he has been charged with. The motion states:
That the Senate censures Senator Richardson as the former Minister for the Environment for failing to properly supervise actions of his department.

It then gives five matters that have resulted from that action. In the speech we have just heard-unfortunately I did not hear earlier ones-there was no proper consideration of those issues. We have been invited to censure Senator Richardson for his activities overseas in allegedly spending more money on travel than he should.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean, `allegedly'?
—This is interesting. Senator Alston, who--
—Senator Alston, if you want to interject, perhaps you could resume your seat and let Senator Cooney continue.

—The comments of Senator Alston, who knows what natural justice is, show what this debate really concerns. I mentioned the alleged excessive expenditure by Senator Richardson overseas. That was mentioned in the context of this motion. Senator Alston asked what I meant by `alleged'. By that question he infers that, in considering this motion, we should take into account what Senator Richardson has done overseas; what he has done with the factional activities that go on in the Australian Labor Party; what he has done when he was visiting Ravenshoe; what he has done `flitting around the world looking after his mates'; and what he has done with his `lavish bills'. Those are the issues that we have been asked by Senator Macdonald and Senator Alston to consider in light of this censure motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters that they put forward are matters of emotion, which invite us to apply lynch law rather than proper judgment. This is one motion that I, with absolute and complete conviction, will be voting against because I do not want to be read in years to come as somebody who has lynched a Minister not on the basis of what he did in respect of the matters raised in the motion that was put forward but on the basis of what he is alleged to have done in all sorts of other areas.

Senator Richardson is accused by Senator Macdonald of getting the vote from the environmentalists. He has been accused of going out and electioneering in a way that did not suit the Opposition. Senator Macdonald is a very eminent lawyer. He represents what the Opposition is saying in this case. The Opposition has said that we should censure Senator Richardson today not in respect of the cheque but in respect of the factional deals he has been doing, his attempt to get the environmentalists' vote on the last occasion, his failure to look after little Australians and his attempt to contest an issue with Senator Robert Ray. Apparently, one reason we have to censure Senator Richardson is that Senator Robert Ray is cock-a-hoop about events that happened yesterday.

Senator Richardson's character has been attacked. Apparently, we have to censure him for flitting around the world, committing acts of treachery this week, failing to have the courage to resign, because his Comcare overtime bill is too great and because he spent $4,430 on car bills. They are the sorts of things for which the man has been condemned.

Senator Richardson's defence of his position has not been met. When Hansard comes out, I will defy anybody in this chamber to show that a very careful analysis of what Senator Richardson went through in his defence to the motion that was put forward has been made. Has anybody in this chamber been able to contradict his statement that it is not for the Minister to supervise the actual making out and sending of cheques? Has anybody here met his argument that he was on holidays? If this motion is to be put forward and put forward seriously, why is his case not met? Why is not the case that Senator Richardson put forward in his defence met? Opposition senators in this chamber will today condemn a Minister without meeting his case. They have put forward a series of allegations which, before Senator Richardson spoke, I suppose people could speculate upon. But since he has answered those allegations, why is his answer not met?

I would have thought that it is not hard for those opposite to have checked up with somebody like Senator Durack, who knows how ministries work. I can understand people who have not been in government for eight years not knowing how the process works. But, on the other hand, there are members of the Opposition who have been in government, know how government works and would have been able to give an answer to this question if one were available. Has one former Minister stood up and condemned Senator Richardson? Where is Senator Durack? He is the person who best knows what happens here. Why has he not come forward and joined in the debate?

Hansard will show that today the Senate condemned a Minister not on the basis of evidence supporting the censure motion as written out but of allegations that go to his character and on allegations that are couched in the wildest and most intemperate of language, that it has condemned the man not in respect of what he is charged with but in respect of all sorts of other things. This will appear in the Hansard for all time. If that is not lynch law, I do not know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you hear what Senator Coulter had to say?

—Unfortunately, I must confess that I did not hear what Senator Coulter had to say. I have nothing but the highest regard for Senator Coulter. I am sorry I was not here for the debate. I certainly heard most of Senator Richardson's defence.
—How do you know whether he answered those propositions?

—All I am saying is that Senator Richardson made statements in his own defence about the processes by which departments work. I sat and listened to them. I must confess that prior to that I did not know the details of what he was going through. I do not criticise what has been said before because it was said on the basis of ignorance.

SPEECH.PARA: But once Senator Richardson made his defence on the basis that he did, it ought to have been answered. It certainly was not answered by the Opposition; that is all I am saying. What those opposite are saying is, `We will condemn Senator Richardson. He having made his defence, we will condemn him without answering that defence'. No matter how we twist or turn as a Senate and no matter how we try to justify things, as a chamber we are saying, `We will put charges against you, Minister, and when you get up and make a defence we will not meet that defence. We will not meet it in respect of any of the issues you put forward'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he never met any of the charges either.
—Senator O'Chee says that he has not met any of the charges. Well, I certainly thought he did. These are the charges:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Richardson as the former Minister for the Environment for failing to properly supervise actions of his department.

Senator Richardson made out a defence which said, `Look, within the grand traditions which guide how a Minister should supervise his Department, I have met all the rules. I call in as a precedent and in support of what I have done what Senator Durack has said and what Senator Durack did on a particular occasion'. In saying that, Senator Richardson has met the charges made by the Opposition. What has not been done on the other side is to say that Senator Durack did not do those things; that Senator Durack was wrong when he did those things; that Senator Richardson is wrong when he says, `That is how the Department should work' or `Here is a book that sets out how Ministers should act in these circumstances'. None of that was done; none of those rebuttals was put forward.

If those opposite are going to make out a case and that case is answered by Senator Richardson, they should then rebut the case that has been put by him. They should not get to the point where he gets up and makes a defence and then introduce material that is obviously terribly prejudicial to his case and has nothing to do with the charge that has been made but everything to do with his trips overseas, his factional dealings, the problems that the Australian Labor Party has been going through in the last couple of days, and his having spent, so it is said, too much on his Comcar. All those things were brought up but at no stage was an answer given to the matters he raised in his defence.

We are about to vote on this censure motion. I shall certainly vote against it. In years to come, readers of Hansard may well say, `This was a pretty emotional debate; they never seemed to get down to the issues that were involved within the terms of the motion that was put. The opposition'- in the sense of the general opposition to Senator Richardson's position- `never seemed to answered his defence, yet went ahead and condemned him. It seems to be more like the application of lynch law than a proper considered hearing where natural justice was applied'. I at least can say that I did not go ahead on the basis of applying lynch law to this man; that I at least listened to his material and, when no proper evidence was put forward to rebut it, I gave him the benefit that anybody should be entitled to; that is, that one should not go down on a charge unless it has been proved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up, I would just like to run through a few points. I am sorry that the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, is not here, because he accused me of malice. Senator Ray is known as one of the straight shooters around this place, and I believe that remark did not really indicate the true Senator Ray. I have no malice in this place. I come here representing a constituency different from that of the Australian Democrats and different from that of the Australian Labor Party. I said in my contribution today that I opposed the World Heritage listing. I did not come in here with any malice at all. I come to this place to represent my constituency, as do the Democrats, as does the Labor Party and as does the Liberal Party of Australia. But that is not the reason why I moved this censure motion. I moved it because I firmly believe that Senator Richardson did not supervise his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put it on the record that I was drawn into answering an interjection regarding Senator Durack. I have the highest possible regard for Senator Durack and his abilities in the Senate. What I meant to say was that what Senator Durack said five years ago is totally irrelevant to what has happened in Ravenshoe. So, if I have offended Senator Durack in any way, I hope that he will accept my apologies.

Senator Ray then went on to some obscure document about resignation. I never mentioned resignation but, since it was mentioned, it may be appropriate if Senator Richardson feels that he has let the side down. But the real truth is that the Minister has not administered his Department.

Senator Coulter presented his reasons in a very logical way. He believes that the slackness of Senator Richardson will make World Heritage listing more difficult in the future. That is quite a good argument. In getting into the meat of the argument, he also read the agreement signed by Senator Richardson and Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. He indicated that the amount is paid when the mill operates up to 120 days in any one year. Senator Coulter raised the point that, because the money was paid in advance, we will never know whether the mill had earned the $2.125m. That is a very relevant point.

Then Senator Richardson was flippant about being censured for not answering a question on notice. I put it to Senator Richardson that this is a very serious censure motion. It relates to an amount of $7.6m that has not hit the target that the Government allocated and appropriated the money for, money which has not gone to Ravenshoe. I am not saying that Senator Richardson is not entitled to a holiday. The problems did not occur on 9 January when the cheque was drawn. These problems have gone on for months and months. In fact, on 7 June 1989, there were already indications and the dogs were barking all over north Queensland that something was wrong in the mill. I heard about it. I could deduce that money was going into the mill but that the people of Ravenshoe were not getting paid, the small business community was not getting paid, the loggers were not getting paid, the carriers were not getting paid and the people in the whole town were seizing up because no money was coming in. It was very obvious to me, months and months before 9 January, that the money which had been allocated was not reaching its mark.

That is why I proceeded to find out what in fact happened. I do not think Senator Richardson can come in here and say, `Exonerate me because I was on holidays the day it happened'. What about the fact that the veneer mill went out the back door and the fact that a boiler was purchased with government assistance and then sold to AGC Finance Co. and leased back? Senator Richardson was the Minister responsible when all this happened. The censure motion reads:
The Senate censures the former Minister for the Environment for failing to supervise the actions of his department . . .

A lot of money-at least $4.5m-went to the wrong company. A plywood mill was sold without government permission or without Senator Richardson's knowledge. A veneer mill was sold. A lot of stock was also sold and the money never went back to the company. The Minister was responsible for all those things. Then we face the problem of the Minister, or his Department, allowing a cheque for $968,841 to go to the wrong company.

Already that company, as has been proved by Senator O'Chee, has had money that was determined by the Government to go to Ravenshoe. Already money has been syphoned off Ravenshoe and put into National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd. It is a company that has no responsibility for Ravenshoe. It is a company that has responsibility for a mill in Kyogle. That is why I say to Senator Cooney and all honourable senators opposite that the date of 9 January is fairly irrelevant. All these things were happening before that date. Senator Richardson cannot walk in today and say that $968,841 disappeared because he went on holidays on 9 January. It disappeared because Senator Richardson never administered his Department. That is what it is about. In my original address today I said that passing a censure motion is the highest reprimand that the Senate can place on a Minister. I believe that the Minister deserves it because he was the one who went to Ravenshoe and said to the people, `You won't be affected; I make that commitment to you on behalf of my Government'. He made such a statement.

As Senator Macdonald and Senator O'Chee have rightly pointed out, the residents of Ravenshoe say that the town is bankrupt-I believe that-the mill is bankrupt, and everyone has been hurt. That has occurred because Senator Richardson did not administer his Department. Had he administered his Department and the money that was allocated to the mill had ended up retooling the mill, there would have been 40 jobs, the mill would have been sustained, and the town would have lived off the mill as it had for the past 50 or 60 years. The censure motion stands on its own. All this occurred because Senator Richardson did not administer his Department. That is perfectly obvious to the Senate. I therefore commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Boswell's) be agreed too.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 13 citizens), Knowles (from 58 citizens) and Macdonald (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The speeches read as follows-
POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991
There is no greater duty upon the representatives of the people in a democratic society than the duty to ensure that they serve all members of that society equally.

This duty requires government which is free of corruption and undue influence. It requires standards of integrity and honesty from its representatives. And it requires that the system itself does not engender a diminution of those standards.

The integrity of the electoral process is central to the maintenance of these standards and the honouring of this duty. In our own society the pursuit of government office at all levels is far more complicated today than it was when the first elections were held for this Federal Parliament.

The development of modern election campaigning and communication techniques have impacted greatly upon the electoral process. This has been no more so evident than in the area of campaign financing. The vast sums required to fund modern political campaigns have added substantially to the pressures upon the electoral system.

With these changes in mind the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters as part of its inquiry into the 1987 Federal Election produced a report titled ``Who pays the piper calls the tune-minimising the risks of funding political campaigns''. This Parliament is indebted to the Committee for its report.

The concerns raised in the Committee's report have been the subject of separate State corruption inquiries. Both Queensland Commissioner Fitzgerald and Assistant Commissioner Roden of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption dealt with the problems of political campaign finances in their reports. Related concerns are now the subject of inquiries in Western Australia and Tasmania.
The ``risk'' to which the title of the Joint Standing Committee's report refers is a real and dangerous one.

As Commissioner Roden said in his report on his investigation into north coast development, ``with the mounting cost of campaign advertising, parties must be increasingly vulnerable to attempts by substantial donors to exert influence. It appears that the parties are themselves aware of this, and various proposals for increased public funding, limits on allowable spending, free television time, and bans on television advertising, have all been mooted''.

This risk applies throughout Australia. No political party or government is quarantined from that risk. Steps must be taken to protect the integrity of our systems of government. The Bill before the House today will take such steps. It will contain measures designed to repel the threat of corruption to public order in Australia.

The Government will not wait until the problem becomes unmanageable. Action must be taken now to sanitise the electoral system. Nor will the Government take action which only partially addresses the problem. The Joint Standing Committee identified the need to expose the system of electoral funding by enhanced disclosure provisions but equally identified the need to control the burgeoning cost of political campaigning.
As Commissioner Roden has stated:
`` . . . as increasingly vast sums of money become necessary for successful political campaigns, the problem will grow. It must be faced and dealt with firmly and openly . . . ''
The majority report of the Joint Standing Committee considered a number of options for addressing the risks of funding political campaigns.

The Committee reviewed the present disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. These provisions and those of similar effect in the New South Wales Act are the only laws requiring disclosure of political donations throughout Australia. The lack of a national uniform legislative scheme which comprehensively covers all political donations in respect of all levels of government is lamentable. The Government will propose to the State and Territory governments that the lack of such a system be remedied as quickly as possible. In doing so, the Government will put forward the comprehensive disclosure laws proposed in this Bill as the basis for uniform legislation.
The Government welcomes the commitment to such laws already made by the West Australian and Victorian governments and sees this as a positive start to this process.

The need for full disclosure laws is universally accepted. Disclosure will remove the taint of suspicion from legitimate campaign donations which are at present not required to be disclosed. As Commissioner Roden said in his report:
``to allow large secret donations to political parties or candidates, is but one step removed from allowing large secret deals with political parties or candidates''.

The Committee considered a number of options for dealing with the problem of potential corruption stemming from campaign costs. The Committee recommended that a system of freetime for party political broadcasts be offered to registered parties and candidates by broadcasters who would provide airtime free of charge. The proposal was strongly criticised at the time they were released. Many of the criticisms had more to do with the protection of self interest than a fair assessment of the proposal. The Government has rejected the proposal because it believes that the allocation of time to parties would be inequitable and administratively impracticable. Freetime would unfairly advantage the major political and incumbent parties. Furthermore freetime alone would not reduce the need for political parties to expend vast sums upon advertising. Political parties and candidates could be expected to continue to advertise in addition to using the freetime made available.

The Government has also rejected the proposal for a limitation on advertising expenditure by political parties. Experience both overseas, particularly in the United States with so-called political action committees and domestically, through such notorious examples as the community polling organisation in New South Wales, has shown how easy it is for political parties to conduct campaigns through front organisations.
The Government's preferred course for dealing with the problems associated with campaign costs is to prohibit the broadcasting of political advertisements.

The Government has not taken this step lightly. The competing claims of the various options were considered. The Government opted for a ban on political advertising because it is the fairest and most effective means of addressing the problem of burgeoning campaign costs.

The proposed ban is aimed directly at the single greatest factor in campaign costs. The exorbitant cost of broadcast advertising precludes the majority of the community and all but the major political parties and large corporate interests from paid access to the airwaves.

The Government carefully considered the implications of the proposals on the right to freedom of speech, both as it is generally accepted and specifically under international law. In respect of the latter, article 19 (2) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which Australia is a party requires parties to guarantee the right of freedom of expression. This right is not absolute. Article 19 (3) of the covenant provides that the right may be limited in the interests of public order. The prohibition of the broadcasting of political advertising is directed squarely at preventing potential corruption and undue influence of the political process. The Government is satisfied that the proposals are a necessary and proportionate response to this threat and do not constitute a breach of our international obligations.
Of course the ban will not affect the expression of opinion or information through broadcasting of material other than advertising.
Mr President, I turn now to the text of the Bill.
The Bill inserts a new part IIId into the Broadcasting Act 1942. The part contains a framework for the proposed ban on the broadcasting of political advertising.
Part IIId is structured in a way which makes it clear that the several provisions of the amendments are to operate to the extent that the Constitution allows.

The Greiner Government of New South Wales has indicated that it will challenge the proposed ban to the extent of its application to State governments and elections. The Bill has been drafted with the possibility of such a challenge in mind. It also reflects the different nature of election and non election periods. During the former, when the heightened attention given to political issues creates more intense pressure on broadcasters to give access to politicians, and parties, the Bill prohibits certain government advertising and does not provide for the same exemptions from the ban as those which operate in non election periods.

The ban will prohibit broadcasters from carrying paid or unpaid advertising which includes political matter. It will extend to such advertisements whether run by broadcasters on their own behalf or on behalf of others. The latter step is designed to ensure broadcasters do not flout the ban. To exclude advertisements on the basis that no consideration is paid would be tantamount to creating a privileged class to whom the airwaves would be open for political advertising. Provided you could afford to own a broadcasting service and licence you would be exempted from the prohibition. Similarly, the potential for influence buying and corruption would continue.

The ban extends to elections for all levels of government, including by-elections and Commonwealth referendums to alter the constitution. Were the ban to apply only to Federal elections, the problems created by the need for political parties to raise huge sums necessary to advertise during an election campaign would only be partially addressed. As the Joint Standing Committee report concluded, parties would merely transfer funds to ``exempt campaigns''.

In the Bill, political advertising means advertising containing political matter. This definition of political matter is used throughout the Bill and is based upon that of ``electoral matter'' in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The provision has been modified slightly to fit the context of the Bill.

Fundamentally, political matter is defined to include matter which is likely or intended to affect voting at an election or matter which includes an implied or explicit reference to an issue in an election. It would not include, for example, the ordinary fundraising activities of a charity.

The Government has however received representations from legitimate charitable organisations concerning the effect that they perceive the ban may have upon the promotion of their operations. Whilst the Government remains committed to ensuring the need for integrity of the operation of the ban to prevent avoidance, the Government accepts the concerns of bona fide charities that they should be able to continue to advertise, to the extent that they actually use the medium, in a way which they consider effective for bringing the public's attention to the cause which they espouse.

As a consequence the Government will be introducing amendments to ensure that broadcast advertisements on behalf of charitable organisations which promote the charitable purpose of that organisation will be exempted from the operation of the ban at all times.

Under S. 95a of the Bill the ban is to operate at all times and includes the prohibition of advertisements containing matter likely to affect voters at or matter before voters in any election whensoever held.

Sections 95b, 95c and 95d operate during specific Commonwealth, Territory, State and local government elections. Under these sections, the ban prohibits the broadcasting of advertisements containing political matter in respect of the relevant election period.
The Government has been particularly vigilant to ensure that under the Bill, incumbent governments do not enjoy an advantage over their opponents through the use of government advertising.

Firstly, government advertising which falls within the general prohibition on political advertising will be banned. Secondly, during a Commonwealth election period, the broadcast of all Commonwealth Government departmental or authority advertising other than that containing exempt matter will be prohibited. A similar ban upon Territory Government advertising will be imposed during territory elections.

The extended ban is designed to ensure that government advertisements which arguably may marginally fall outside the definition of political matter cannot be screened during election periods. Whilst it is currently Commonwealth Government practice to administratively apply such a ban, the Bill will ensure that the ban has the force of law in the future.
The ban is confined to political advertisements as commonly understood.

The broadcast of bona fide news reports, current affairs programs and documentaries which contain references to political issues will not be affected by the legislation. Broadcasters and members of the public will continue to be free to use these forums and others, such as talkback radio, to express views on political issues. Editorial comment by broadcasters will not be impeded by the ban on advertising. The delivery of information to the public including the print handicapped by such means will be unimpeded.

Those in the community who are visually disabled or functionally illiterate will continue to have access to political information and comment by such means. Additionally the Government will re-examine the impact of the proposed ban upon the reading of newspaper advertisements upon publicly supported radio services for the print handicapped and if necessary exempt, in this strictly limited way, such services from the operation of the ban.

Mr President, the airwaves of Australia belong to all Australians. Currently, access to those airwaves by means of paid advertising through commercially licensed operators is restricted to those few in the community who can afford to pay the prohibitively high cost.

In respect of the broadcast of political advertisements, the chief users of the airwaves are the major political parties who, at the 1990 Federal election expended over $15 million on broadcasting advertisements.

During the same election period, all other non political party expenditure on such ads amounted to $1.7 million. Of that figure, over $1.1 million was expended by the logging industry while the Australian Conservation Foundation spent just over $25,000 on broadcast advertising.
These figures illustrate the inherent inequity in the presentation of political debate through electronic advertising. The reality is that only the rich can get their message across by such means.
As one political commentator has described the current situation, ``a system which money decides who is and who isn't heard renders meaningless the right of free speech''.

The ban will thus remove the privileged status of those few in the community who can afford to pay the high costs of broadcast advertising to express their political views, at the exclusion of the vast majority who cannot afford to do so. It will place all in the community on an equal footing so far as the use of the public's airwaves is concerned.

It must also be remembered that television advertising leads to packaging of important political debates and information into 30 second, even 15 second messages, widely criticised for their trivialising of content, and concentration on image making.

Mr President, whilst the bulk of expenditure by political parties on advertising occurs during elections, the proposed ban will operate at all times. If the ban were restricted to election periods, parties and others who buy political advertising would run campaigns outside the ban period. The problems associated with the need to raise the huge sums necessary to fund campaigns would remain, but apply to mid term and pre-election period campaigns which could be expected to take on the importance presently attached to election campaigns.

Mr President, since the Government announced its intention to proceed with the proposed ban it has been suggested in some quarters that it is contrary to the direction of practice in similar overseas democracies.

This is despite the broad degree of regulation of political advertising that exists in the so-called western democracies. For example France, Denmark and Austria prohibit paid political advertising at election times. The United Kingdom and the Netherlands prohibit such advertising at all times and Norway and Sweden prohibit all advertisements including political ads.

Furthermore rather than a trend towards deregulation of political advertising, tangible evidence exists of a trend in some cases towards further regulation. In the United Kingdom the parliament reaffirmed its support for the longstanding prohibition on political advertising in the 1990 Broadcasting Act.
In the United States, five Bills are currently before the Senate which further regulate broadcasts of political matter and advertising.

The Bill provides for certain matter to be exempted from the effect of the ban. This is primarily non-contentious matter and includes announcements concerning civil or military disorder; information relating to the conduct of and promoting participation in an election or referendum; the promotion of services and programs of the ABC and SBS; certain non-contentious government administrative announcements and advertisements for goods and services which do not contain any political matter which are run on behalf of government departments or authorities.

A further exemption which applies in all but election periods is made for advertisements which concern matters of public health. This would include aids prevention and anti drug abuse advertisements but not advertisements which refer to public health systems.

The voluntary broadcast of party policy launches during election periods will not be prevented by the ban. Such launches will be restricted to no more than half an hour in length and may only be broadcast on one occasion. The provisions of the Act requiring equal treatment of political parties will continue to apply to the broadcast of launches.

The use by politicians of ``free broadcast time'' for party political broadcasts will be prevented by the ban. This will ensure that politicians do not enjoy access to the airwaves which is not available to other members of the community. This will include the provision of ``free time'' by the ABC.

The Bill ensures that all broadcasters, whether public or private, are treated in the same way. Apart from applying the ban to the ABC, the Bill will not affect the ABC's power to determine to what extent and in what manner it shall broadcast political or controversial matter.
The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be able to receive complaints regarding alleged breaches of the ban provisions.

In recognition of the urgent nature of complaints of alleged breaches of the ban, for example during election periods, the tribunal will be required to deal with complaints or information about alleged breaches forthwith.
Both the Tribunal and any individual with legal standing will be empowered to seek an order from the Federal Court to enforce or prevent a likely breach of the provisions of the new part.

The ban is expected in practice to operate chiefly as a deterrent. It will be an offence under the broadcasting Act for a broadcaster to broadcast an advertisement contrary to the ban. Compliance with the ban will also be a condition of every licence granted under the Act.

The provisions of the part will also be conditions of licences and permits issued under the Radio Communications Act 1983 thus extending the ban to video and audio entertainment and information services, such as skychannel.
I turn now to the amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

I have already referred to the inadequacies of the current disclosure requirements in the electoral Act. These were perhaps best summarised metaphorically by the former Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes, in his evidence before the Joint Standing Committee:

``what happens under the present arrangements would be that the recipients of donations stand to one side of the table with three walnut shells, only one of which is transparent if it is labelled `a donation to the next federal election'. There are two other walnut shells which are completely opaque and it is up to us to guess which walnut shell the pea is under. If it is not under the transparent one, they merely say, `wrong', and that is the end of the matter . . . ''

The majority report of the Joint Standing Committee accepted that the matter referred to by Dr Hughes should not end there and made sweeping recommendations to overcome the deficiencies in the present law.
The Government agrees with the committee that these changes must be made and electoral financing in Australia should be open and transparent.

The reforms proposed in the amendments to the funding and disclosure provisions of the electoral Act will bring that transparency to the electoral process. It will enable the Electoral Commission to investigate and expose any avoidance of the disclosure obligations.

The public is entitled to be assured that the parties and candidates which make up the Government or Opposition of the day are free of undue or improper outside influence. The present system of disclosure cannot and does not engender complete confidence. The Government will restore confidence to the system by exposing who pays the piper.

The electoral Act will be amended to require political parties to fully disclose all income, expenditure and debts. Parties will be required to lodge annual returns with the Australian Electoral Commission within eight weeks of the end of each financial year in addition to the existing requirement for the lodging of returns in respect of electoral expenditure following elections.

The Bill requires that all amounts received paid or owed by a political party must be disclosed. Whilst the total sums of all such amounts will be required to be disclosed the Australian Electoral Commission will determine the approved form in which disclosure shall take place. It is envisaged that the Commission will not require details of every individual transaction (beyond total amounts) but will require generic disclosure of categories of expenditure, income and debts.

The identity of individuals who pay to, receive or are owed amounts by political parties will be disclosable only in circumstances prescribed by regulations made under the Act. Parliament will thus be able to approve or disallow the regulations which are intended to provide a flexible and workable scheme which does not require disclosure of the identity of those involved in insignificant transactions. This will avoid a needless administrative burden being placed on the Electoral Commission and political parties and guarantee the appropriate protection of privacy. Examples of the type of disclosure which would not be required by the regulations include the publication of ordinary membership lists and details of identity and outlays of employees and salaries.
Tougher disclosure requirements will also be placed upon third parties who participate in the political process.
Third parties include persons or organisations other than registered political parties or candidates who incur electoral expenditure, including the making of a gift to a political party or candidate.

Currently third parties are required to disclose such expenditure but need not do so where the expenditure relates to an election which does not occur during the specific reporting period. This has enabled third parties to avoid the reporting requirements. The Joint Standing Committee identified this problem and recommended that the loophole be removed. The Bill removes this loophole by requiring disclosure of electoral expenditure in respect of any election.
Third parties will also be required to disclose any gift made to a political party or part thereof, regardless of whether the gift is for electoral or other purposes.

The Commission will also be required to publish a list of all third parties in its reports on the operation of the funding and disclosure sections of the Act. This will ensure that the identity of those participating in the political process will be publicly available in keeping with the commitment to full disclosure.

The Government is determined that the Electoral Commission should be armed with the powers necessary to enforce the disclosure requirements of the Act. The Commission has for some time had the power to conduct investigations where it has reasonable grounds to believe that an offence relating to the disclosure provisions of the Act has been committed. The provisions amount to the ability to conduct a spot audit of a political party or a candidate's financial affairs to ensure the Act has not been breached.

While the Commission retains confidence in the efficacy of such compliance audits as an enforcement tool, the current provisions require the Commission to have reasonable grounds to believe that a breach of the Act may have occurred in order to activate an audit. This has prevented the Commission from conducting random audits.

The Government's amendments will remove the deficiencies in the Act and provide the Electoral Commission with the power to subject political and third parties to random audits to ensure compliance with the disclosure requirements of the Act. The Commission will be able to do so at any time and will not be required to have a reasonable ground to suspect an offence under the Act has been committed. Political and third parties will be subject to a random audit at any time.

Furthermore, the Commission will be required to publish a record of all spot audits in the reports on the funding and disclosure provision of the Act which it is currently required to publish following each election. The Commission will also be empowered to issue such supplementary reports as it considers necessary to comply with its obligation to report all spot audits.

As some third parties are not established solely for political purposes and their financial affairs may only relate in a marginal way to their involvement in the political process, the Commission will be prevented from publishing any details obtained during a third party spot audit other than details of an offence under the Act.

The Government has moved, through the Bill, to recognise and protect the rights of donors. The Bill will make it an offence under S.327 to interfere or hinder with the free exercise by a person of his or her right to make a gift to a political party.

The Bill amends the Act to provide that registered political parties and candidates are entitled to the same level of public funding per Senate vote as is provided for a vote for the House of Representatives. Under the public funding provisions inserted in the Act in 1984 a Senate vote is currently valued at one half or two-thirds of a vote for the House of Representatives depending upon the type of Senate election held. These provisions discriminate against smaller parties who concentrate upon Senate campaigns and fail to sufficiently acknowledge the costs of such campaigns. The Bill will place all votes on the same footing.

Amendments are also made to the Electoral Act and the Referendum Machinery Provisions Act to ensure that the result of an election or referendum cannot be overturned by the Court of Disputed Returns by reason only of a breach of the Broadcasting Act or the Radio Communications Act. Mr President, the Bill represents a comprehensive response to the threat of corruption and undue influence which hangs over the political process. In the terms of the Joint Standing Committee report these proposals minimise the risks created by the need to fund political campaigns. The importance of sanitising our electoral process and of restoring public confidence in it has never been more paramount. The potential risk in not doing so will not diminish in the future. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY BILL 1991
The Australian National University Bill 1991 provides for the amalgamation of the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts from 1 January 1992.

In July of 1989, the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts finalised an affiliation agreement with a view to amalgamating by 1 January 1991. In July 1990, the University and the Institute of the Arts agreed to amalgamate.

Legislation to give effect to this amalgamation was to be introduced into Parliament last year but was deferred because of the possibility that the Report of the Committee to Review the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University (the Stephen Report) would have legislative implications. This has proved not to be the case.

Honourable Senators will be aware that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, made a statement earlier this year on arrangements for higher education in the Australian Capital Territory, on the basis of advice contained within the Stephen Report and the advice from Professor Chubb. In that statement he endorsed new administrative arrangements which will encourage the Australian National University and the University of Canberra to co-ordinate their efforts and cooperate more closely in order to provide the best possible educational opportunities for the region. He also endorsed new funding arrangements for the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University, which will enhance the Institute's role as a national resource and result in an appropriate performance evaluation and peer-review process to guarantee the best use of research funds.

Honourable Senators could not have failed to notice the reports in the media about these decisions. There has been persistent misrepresentation of the Government's intentions towards the Institute of Advanced Studies. On Friday 10 May, Mr Baldwin met with the ANU Council to discuss points of difference in relation to the Government's decisions.

This provided the Minister with an opportunity to clarify a number of key points with Council members. He stressed that key issues such as the performance criteria to be applied every five years and the composition of the review panels evaluating each School and Centre within the Institute would be matters on which the ARC would need to consult, and seek agreement with, the ANU.

However, the Government continues to believe that it is legitimate and appropriate for it to be able to receive expert advice from the ARC, the only body with broad based knowledge of research activity throughout the higher education system, except the National Health and Medical Research Council for medical research, as to the overall distribution of research funds between the Institute of Advanced Studies and the rest of the higher education research system. In arriving at such advice, the ARC would draw on the reviews of each component of the Institute and would notionally apportion a level of funding to each. It is not the Government's intention, however, to require that the ANU's internal resource allocation decisions would correspond to its own notional apportionment.

There is no implication in any of this that the Institute's funding should be cut-in fact the new review arrangements could mean more funds. Like Stephen, the Government acknowledges the high quality of much of the Institute's research, and sees value in retaining a concentration of research resources and personnel. However, funding at the level provided to the Institute must be a demonstrably effective use of scarce research funds, and the Government, quite properly, will demand advice on the opportunity cost involved in funding the Institute at a given level compared with other research activities in the higher education research system.

The present Bill, however, is entirely separate from these new arrangements for higher education in the ACT. Its purpose is to put into effect a longstanding agreement to amalgamate between the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts.

The Bill abolishes the Institute of the Arts as a separate institution and adds to the functions of the University the requirement that it provide facilities for courses at higher education and other levels in the visual and performing arts and, in doing so, to promote the highest standards in those fields.
The Bill also provides for the students and staff of the Institute of the Arts to be transferred to the University on terms and conditions no less favourable than they enjoy at present.

The amalgamation can be expected to enhance the national and international roles of the University through the addition of the visual and performing arts to its range of disciplines while at the same time allowing the Institute of the Arts to become a member of the unified national system. With its small student load, the Institute of the Arts would be unable to enter the unified national system of higher education in its own right.

The amalgamation will permit students from both institutions to benefit from a wider range of course options. The development of higher degree courses at the Institute of the Arts will benefit from the University's greater experience in graduate education. In addition, the consolidation of adjacent campuses under one administration will lead to cost efficiencies and the rationalisation of shared services and amenities. The local community can expect to enjoy greater benefits from an expansion of university extension programs with the addition of more musical, art and gallery activities.

One substantive amendment to the Bill was passed in the House of Representatives. A major portion of the Bill provides for the transition to the consolidated Australian National University (incorporating the Canberra Institute of the Arts). The amendment will enable the Pro-Chancellor of the Australian National University to continue in office after commencement of the new Act on 1 January 1992. This is consistent with provisions already in the Bill for other senior officers. Like them, the Pro-Chancellor will continue in office for the remainder of the term of his or her original appointment and under the terms and conditions of that appointment. This amendment was sought by the University to make for a smooth transition to the consolidated University.
Other amendments to the Bill, also passed in the House, were in connection with minor technical drafting matters.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
UNIVERSITY OF CANBERRA AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The purpose of the University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991 is to amend the University of Canberra Act, 1989 which provides for the operation and management of the University of Canberra.
The Bill provides for four substantive changes to the principal Act.

The manner in which representatives of the Australian Capital Territory are appointed to the University's governing Council has been streamlined to enable the Chief Minister of the ACT Legislative Assembly to appoint the ACT members directly to Council. Previously representatives of the ACT were appointed by the Governor-General on the nomination of the ACT Minister responsible for education.

Changes have been made to the University's audit requirements to make them more appropriate to the non-commercial nature of the institution and to bring the University of Canberra into line with other comparable Commonwealth higher education institutions.

The Bill also provides for the membership of the University's Council to be increased from 17 to 22 members, and for the University to be able to appoint its Chancellor either from outside or from inside the membership of Council, as is the case for other higher education institutions.
The amendments have the support of the University of Canberra.

GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1991
Both Labor and coalition governments have in the past supported the protection and wise use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and I hope that this bipartisan support will continue.

It has been 16 years since the passage of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the creation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Over that time practical experience gained from managing the Marine Park has highlighted areas where protection of the Reef could be improved.

The Government has noted with concern the effects of spillages of oil and other toxic substances on the marine environment around the world and is of the view that such risks to the Great Barrier Reef should be minimised as much as possible. The affects of an incident like that of the Exxon Valdez would be quite disastrous to the Great Barrier Reef environment, and even smaller spills of toxic material would be very damaging.

The purpose of this Bill is to improve the protection of the Great Barrier Reef against possible spillages of oil and other toxic substances by introducing compulsory pilotage through the northern inner shipping routes of the Reef.

These routes offer relatively calm waters, but are shallow and intricate in places. Approximately ten percent of the 2,000 large ships or ships carrying potentially hazardous cargo using the passage every year are not adhering to the current voluntary system of pilotage. Extensive diplomatic representations have not brought a higher level of compliance with the voluntary scheme. The Government does acknowledge the 90 per cent of ships which do adhere to the present system of voluntary pilotage. The responsibility of their masters and owners is appreciated.

The current voluntary pilotage system covers ships of 100 metres in length and over, as well as ships carrying potentially hazardous cargo. A lower limit of 70 metres has been set in the new system because of the number of groundings of ships in the 70 to 100 metre range occurring in recent years. There has been at least one per year.

Australia is committed to the uniform application and development of international law and international cooperation, rather than unilateral action, in protecting our marine environment. Hence we sought recognition by the international maritime organisation (IMO) for the special status of the Great Barrier Reef and endorsement of the compulsory pilotage scheme.

Australia was successful in having the IMO pass two important resolutions in November 1990. The first was to identify the Great Barrier Reef region as a ``particularly sensitive area'' the first such listed area in the world. The second was its recommendation that all governments recognise the need for effective protection of the Great Barrier Reef region and to inform ships flying their flag to act in accordance with Australia's system of pilotage.

This is the first time that the international community has endorsed such a system. It marks a new development in international law, recognising the dynamic balance which exists between protection of the marine environment and freedom of navigation.
The proposed amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act will give effect to these IMO resolutions.

Vessels meeting criteria recognised in the IMO resolutions will be required to use the services of a person holding a Queensland and Torres Strait pilot's licence while navigating the inner route or Hydrographer's Passage.

At present pilots hold licences as coastal pilots issued by the Marine Board of Queensland. These licences will be recognised in the regulations. The regulations will also enable additional licences to be introduced. It is intended that there be extensive consultation with interested parties and organisations before any other forms of licensing are introduced.

Three offences have been created to enforce the compulsory pilotage system. In the first, the master and owner of any vessel over 70 metres and any loaded oil tanker, chemical carrier or liquefied gas carrier, irrespective of size, will be liable to prosecution if that vessel navigates without the assistance of a pilot in the area between the northern boundary of the Marine Park and latitude 16 degrees 40 minutes south, and also in Hydrographers Passage, which is just off Mackay. The maximum penalty imposed following conviction would be $50,000.
The other two offences are linked to the subsequent entry into an Australian port of a vessel which has navigated in the designated areas without a pilot.

In the first of these two, both the owner and the master will be liable to prosecution if the ship enters an Australian port under the command of the master who navigated in the compulsory pilotage areas without a pilot. In the second, if a ship navigates in the compulsory pilotage area without a pilot and later enters an Australian port under the command of a different master, then only the owner will be liable. Again, the maximum penalty imposed would be $50,000.
These port entry related offences have been included to take advantage of the clear authority which Australia has under international law to control the entry of vessels into its ports.

The Government intends that inspectors appointed with respect to compulsory pilotage will normally be officers of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA). AMSA officers are more likely than Great Barrier Reef Marine Park officers to be in a position to exercise the power to seek evidence concerning pilotage as they frequently board vessels to carry out inspections under the Navigation Act 1912.

The reason the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act has been chosen to implement the compulsory pilotage system is to indicate Australia's commitment to greater protection for the Great Barrier Reef environment. It clearly demonstrates to the international community that the measures are aimed at reducing navigational hazards in this particularly sensitive area, for its enhanced protection.

After these measures are introduced and enforced, the rate of compliance, already 90 per cent under the voluntary pilotage scheme, is expected to be total. A particularly vulnerable part of the Reef will thus be more effectively protected from the possibility of an environmental disaster caused by a shipping mishap.

In deciding on this course of action, the Government considered other options including the suggestion by some conservation groups that tankers should be prohibited from the region. This was rejected as impractical for a number of reasons:

(1) Much of the tanker traffic operating inside the Reef is servicing the population centres of far north Queensland. Without access to such shipping these communities and the industries on which they are dependent, such as tourism, agriculture and mining, would not be able to satisfy their energy and other needs;

(2) The waters of alternative routes in the Coral Sea are less sheltered and less well served with navigation aids. Ships transiting via these routes therefore constitute an equal or greater risk to the environment than those inside the Reef; and

(3) Ships navigating in the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef are exercising the right of innocent passage under international law. It would not be open to Australia to completely restrict this right.
In conclusion, this Bill represents the Government's resolve to improve the protection of one of the world's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef.

SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

In August last year the Attorney-General announced that the Government had decided to repeal and replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901, following consideration of the Law Reform Commission's report on Service and Execution of Process.

One of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations mentioned in the announcement was an extension of the Act to proceedings before tribunals. At present the Act only applies to proceedings before courts.
This extension would apply with respect to tribunals that resolve disputes and to tribunals that conduct inquiries.

As honourable senators are aware, there are a number of important inquiries being conducted in Australia at present. I refer particularly to the Royal Commissions in Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania.

This Bill amends the Service and Execution of Process Act to enable Royal Commissions and other investigative tribunals to serve subpoenas on persons interstate, and to provide for interstate enforcement of subpoenas to give evidence to investigative tribunals.
The new provisions are based on the Law Reform Commission's recommendations. The Act already provides for interstate service and interstate enforcement of subpoenas issued by courts.
As well as enabling investigative tribunal subpoenas to be served interstate the Bill provides appropriate safeguards to protect the interests of persons served with an interstate subpoena.

At present State or Territory Royal Commissions and other inquiries can only effectively subpoena witnesses within the State or Territory concerned. This can be a serious restriction on the effectiveness of the inquiry and can inhibit its capacity to uncover all relevant information.

The Government believes investigative tribunals, including the Royal Commissions I have mentioned, should be given the power now to summons witnesses from interstate. These tribunals must be able to conduct full and thorough inquiries so that the greatest possible public benefit can ensue.

The Government is bringing forward this reform as a separate Bill, rather than in the Bill to replace the Service and Execution of Process Act, so that it will be available for current inquiries. The Chairman of one Royal Commission has informed the Government he considers that, without the powers being conferred by this Bill, the Commission's work may be restricted in some important respects.

Because of the Government's heavy legislative program the replacement Bill will not be ready for introduction until the next sittings. As it is a substantial law reform bill we would then wish there to be adequate time for examination of the Bill by honourable members, the legal profession and the public, before it is passed.
This Bill will insert a new Part 3A into the Service and Execution of Process Act.

That Part will apply to investigative tribunals which, for the purposes of the Part, will be persons appointed by a State Governor (such as Royal Commissions of Inquiry) or under a State or Territory law, and bodies established under a State or Territory law, for the purposes of inquiring into and reporting on matters, where those persons or bodies have the power to take evidence on oath or affirmation.

A subpoena requiring evidence to be produced to such a tribunal will be able to be served out of the State or Territory of issue, by leave of that State or Territory's Supreme Court. Leave may only be granted where the court is satisfied that the evidence sought is relevant to the tribunal's functions and cannot reasonably be obtained from a person within the State or Territory. The Supreme Court will specify the date by which the subpoena must be served. A notice will be attached to the subpoena setting out the rights and obligations of the person to whom it is addressed.

Reasonable expenses of complying with the subpoena will have to be paid to the person subpoenaed. That obligation will be placed upon the State or Territory in which the tribunal is established. A person subpoenaed only to produce documents or things will be able to comply with the subpoena by delivering them to the secretary of the tribunal not less than 24 hours before the date for compliance.

Where a subpoena is addressed to a person in prison, the Supreme Court of the State or Territory in which the subpoena was issued will be able to order that the prisoner be taken interstate to give evidence. The State or Territory in which that order was made will be required to pay the expenses reasonably incurred in connection with compliance with the order.
I appreciate that there is a question whether the Commonwealth has power to legislate to provide for the service and execution of process of State tribunals.

The Government has been advised that it has power to do so under section 51(xxiv) of the Constitution, which confers power with respect to ``the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the States.''
The Bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.

I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Definitions
`30. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:

Referendum to choose electoral system
`31. (1) A referendum is to be held to enable the electors of the Territory to choose which of 2 voting systems is to be used at future elections.

`(2) The 2 systems are the single member electorates system and the proportional representation (Hare-Clark) system, more fully described in the Referendum Options Description Sheet set out in Schedule 3.

`(3) The Electoral Commission may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, engage such temporary staff as it thinks necessary for the purposes of the referendum. A person so engaged is taken to be an officer for the purposes of this Part.
