COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
Referendum Options Description Sheet

The following brief descriptions of a model single member electorates system and a model proportional representation (Hare-Clark) system have been prepared to assist ACT electors to determine their preferred electoral system.
MODEL SINGLE MEMBER ELECTORATES SYSTEM
* The ACT will be divided into 17 separate electorates. Each electorate will elect one member to the Legislative Assembly.
* No candidate will be allowed to stand in more than one electorate at a general election.
* The ballot paper used will look like this:
[THE DIAGRAM IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4260]
* Voting will take place in each electorate in accordance with the system of voting used to elect members of the House of Representatives.
- Instructions on the ballot paper will require voters to show preferences (1, 2 and so on) for all of the candidates standing in the electorate.
- Candidates to be elected will have to receive a majority (ie 50% plus 1) of the formal votes in the electorate.

- If no candidate has obtained a majority of votes after first preference votes have been counted, the candidate with the fewest votes will be excluded and his or her votes will be transferred to the remaining candidates who stood next highest in the relevant voters' preferences.
- This process of excluding candidates with the fewest votes will continue until one candidate has obtained a majority of the votes still in the count.
* If a member dies, or resigns, or otherwise vacates his or her seat, the vacancy will be filled by a by-election in his or her electorate.

* The boundaries of electorates will be drawn by bodies independent of the Commonwealth and ACT governments. The criteria which govern the drawing of the boundaries of House of Representatives divisions will apply as nearly as practicable to the drawing of the boundaries of Legislative Assembly electorates.
* A redrawing of boundaries should take place in the first 12 months after each general election of members of the Legislative Assembly.
MODEL PROPORTIONAL REPRESENTATION (HARE-CLARK) SYSTEM
* The ACT will be divided into 3 separate electorates, of which two will elect 5 members each, and one will elect 7 members, to the Legislative Assembly.
* No candidate will be allowed to stand in more than one electorate at a general election.
* The ballot paper used will look like this:
[THE DIAGRAM IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4261]

* The names of candidates within party groups will not be printed in the same position within the group on every ballot paper. Instead, a particular candidate's name will be printed at the top of the group on some ballot papers, in the second position within the group on other ballot papers and so on, so as to share out the positions.
* The same principle will apply to the printing of independent candidates' names in the column for independents on the ballot paper.

* Instructions on the ballot paper will require voters to show preferences (1, 2 and so on) for as many candidates as there are vacancies to be filled in the electorate concerned. Voters will have the option of showing as many further preferences as they wish. Seats will then be allocated to the candidates using the Hare-Clark system of proportional representation, as used at elections for the Tasmanian House of Assembly:

- Candidates will have to achieve a quota of votes in order to be elected. The quota will be determined by dividing the number of formal votes by 1 more than the number of vacancies to be filled, and adding 1 to the number so obtained (disregarding any remainder).
- If an elected candidate obtains surplus votes (ie votes in excess of the quota), the votes will be transferred to other candidates in the count.

- If vacancies remain to be filled after surplus votes have been transferred, the candidates standing lowest on the count will be excluded and their votes transferred to the remaining candidates who stood next highest in the relevant voters' preferences.
- This process of distributing the surplus votes of elected candidates and of excluding candidates will continue until all the vacancies have been filled.

* If a member dies, resigns, or otherwise vacates his or her seat, the vacancy will be filled by a fresh examination of the ballot papers bearing the votes which elected him or her, to determine which of the available candidates who failed to be elected was most preferred by the voters who chose the former member.

* The boundaries of electorate(s) will be drawn by bodies independent of the Commonwealth and ACT governments. The criteria which govern the drawing of the boundaries of House of Representatives divisions will apply as nearly as practicable to the drawing of the boundaries of Legislative Assembly electorates.
* A redrawing of boundaries should take place in the first 12 months after each general election of members of the Legislative Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add ``, with the following amendment of the amendments recommended by the committee:
Government amendment no. 7, proposed subclause 31(3), omit ``on the same day as polling day for the next general election to be held'', substitute, ``as soon as practicable''.

This is a report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which was intended to resolve problems associated with the framing of amended legislation to bring about a new system of election under which the next Australian Capital Territory (ACT) election could be held.

In the opinion of the Australian Democrats the Committee was unable to resolve the problems that are associated with this legislation. Therefore, as far as we are concerned, it is not possible to endorse the Committee's report. Quite simply, that is because the legislation perpetuates the d'Hondt system. It is that d'Hondt system which demonstrated the shortcomings of the first ACT election. It is that d'Hondt system which has been discredited by the ACT electorate, political commentators and any number of political scientists and experts on the mechanics of electoral systems. Because of this unity of opposition to the d'Hondt system I am amazed to see that the Committee report offers little better than some cosmetic adjustments to that system. The fundamental flaws are not dealt with. The fundamental faults remain.

As I mentioned during the second reading debate, the passing of this legislation would result in the costly creation of an interim system. It would also result in the conduct of a referendum which, it is now apparent, will not be binding upon the Government elected at that time. In other words, we could be designing an interim system which could be retained for subsequent elections. This is unlikely, but it is possible. Because of the concern that that is possible, I wrote to the Australian Electoral Commission as follows:
The Australian Electoral Commissioner,
West Block,
Canberra
Dear Sir,
The Standing Committee on Environment Recreation and the Arts tabled its report on the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill today.
The Committee has not proposed any fundamental changes to the existing ACT electoral system.

I would appreciate your opinion regarding the desirability of conducting the next ACT election under the (essentially) d'Hondt system. By ``desirability'', I refer to the tallying convenience, the accuracy in reflecting voter intention and general efficiency of election processes which would occur in an election conducted under the proposed altered, modified d'Hondt system.
I do not seek your opinion regarding the perceived electoral advantage or disadvantage which might come to particular parties contesting the election.
I would also appreciate your advice regarding the suitability of any other electoral systems which may be available and appropriate to use in the ACT.
I hope to be able to use your advice on these matters when the ACT (Electoral) Amendment Bill is discussed in the Senate in the very near future.

I received a reply which I would like to quote from extensively because I think it is pertinent to this Committee's consideration of the report. I received the reply on 30 May from the Electoral Commission with regard to my letter on 29 May. It reads as follows:
Dear Senator Bell

I refer to your letter of 29 May 1991 in which you sought the Commission's ``opinion regarding the desirability of conducting the next ACT election under the (essentially) d'Hondt system'', and also asked for ``advice regarding the suitability of any other electoral systems which may be available and appropriate to use in the ACT''.

I shall first address the question of the suitability of the modified d'Hondt system for further use. While the proposal to hold a referendum on the appropriate voting system for the ACT should settle the issue in the long run, it is a matter of concern to us that as things stand at the moment, at least one and possibly more than one further election will be held under the ``modified d'Hondt'' system. The Commission has consistently taken the view that the modified d'Hondt system has been demonstrated both by theoretical analysis and practical experience to be fatally flawed, and that it should not be used again.

The Bill currently before the Senate, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991, flows from the Government's consideration of Report Number 5 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (``Inquiry into the ACT Election and Electoral System''), which was issued in November 1989. That Committee's inquiry was undertaken as a result of the very high level of dissatisfaction which had been expressed regarding the modified d'Hondt system. The defects of that system, which were documented in detail in our Submission to the Joint Standing Committee, include the following:
It accepts certain votes as formal even when the markings placed on the ballot paper by the voter are ambiguous or contradictory.
It distorts preferences expressed by the voters, attributes to voters preferences which they did not in fact express, and enhances the relative influence of some electors' votes for no good reason.

It arbitrarily excludes from the count candidates who and parties which receive less than 5.55 per cent of the vote. The rationale for this exclusion process has never been clear. At the 1989 election, it caused the exclusion at the outset of the scrutiny of the candidate who polled the second highest number of first preference votes given for individual candidates rather than parties, and had a major influence on the current composition of the Assembly.
* It offers electors an inducement to vote `strategically', indicating preferences other than those they truly hold.
* It is literally impossible to find out from the public record what purpose is meant to be served by the last 3 stages of the scrutiny.
* The system is complex, is not based on any well-defined principles of electoral justice, and consequently is understood by hardly anyone at all.
* Because of the inordinate complexity of the system, the scrutiny takes an unacceptably long time to complete.
* The legitimacy of the Assembly has been diminished by the general recognition that its members were chosen using a defective voting system.

Taking all these factors into account, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters agreed with the Commission's view that the modified d'Hondt system was fundamentally defective and should be replaced. It should be emphasised that the defects of the modified d'Hondt system as set out above will not be corrected by the minor changes to the system contained in the Bill currently before the Senate.

Concerning possible alternatives to modified d'Hondt: the Commission has consistently argued that one workable and defensible option would be the replacement of the modified d'Hondt system with a slightly altered version of the voting system used at Senate elections. In our Submission on the issue to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, we put forward a number of alterations for consideration. They were proposed in the context of a search for a voting system which could be adopted permanently for ACT elections. In the context of a search for a system which would only have to apply pending the introduction of legislation to give effect to the result of the proposed voting systems referendum, we would see one of those alterations as highly desirable: optional preferential voting ought to be allowed `below the line', so that if there were a large field of candidates, persons who wished to vote for individual candidates would not be required to number from 1 to around 117 (the number of candidates in 1989). The widely adopted approach of requiring voters to show as many preferences as there were vacancies to be filled, ie 17, could be followed.

Such a system could be expected to produce results very much more quickly than modified d'Hondt, and would do so in a way which would be more likely to be accepted by the voters as producing a legitimate Assembly. The shortening of the scrutiny would not only allow the Assembly to resume its work more quickly after the next election, but would also decrease a burden on ACT taxpayers, since section 27 (1) of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 provides that staff employed by the Commission for the purposes of the next election are to be taken to be employed on behalf of the Territory.

Taking into account the extent to which the defects of the modified d'Hondt system have been documented by successive inquiries, we are not aware of any worthwhile argument that could be used to dispute the proposition that a Senate-based interim voting system for the ACT would serve the people of the Territory better than modified d'Hondt. It is our considered opinion that the necessary amendments to legislation to provide for such an interim system could be drafted quickly and easily.

I was horrified when I received that letter because it had been for some time that this whole process had been before committees, committees of inquiries and this chamber and it had been for some time that this whole matter had been discussed in the press, yet we have no evidence that those who first initiated this legislation and those who were attempting to improve this legislation-any of those people, parties or representatives-in any way, shape or form had contacted the Australian Electoral Commission for its opinion on this whole matter.

I was dismayed to find out that the expert opinions and the guidance of the Electoral Commission had neither been sought nor asked for in any way. Because of that we now have a Committee report which is lacking because it has a vacuum where there should be this wisdom which can be provided by our Electoral Commission. That wisdom is well founded. That wisdom should be taken into account but it will not be by what we have proposed in front of us.

All I can do, because I have already expressed my dissatisfaction with the Bill and the proposed amendments, is to offer an amendment which has been circulated in my name. It is an amendment which asks that we at least get cracking and introduce the referendum as soon as practicable. Apart from that, I side with the advice that has been given to us by the Electoral Commission and express my disgust that we have not taken any account of it in the proceedings so far.

Why is that? I would not want to be sinister and suggest that it might be that the proposed system might actually work, that the ACT Government might want to keep it and, by keeping it, that there would be absolutely no possibility of single member electorates. It seems to be a plain fact that the Electoral Commission has suggested that this might work. If that is the case, the opportunity for the proponents of single member electorates has been lost. I hope that that is not so, but it seems that this advice has been neither sought nor revealed. The losers are the electors of the ACT. Having exposed it here, perhaps they will express their disgust, as I have tried to do, with a system that has been demonstrated in theory and in practice to be totally useless in meeting the needs of the electors. I cannot endorse the passage of that system. I would hope at least that some cognition would be given to the amendment circulated in my name but then hope is pretty faint indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government believes that, despite Senator Bell's comment, it is discharging its duty to the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) in providing for a democratic electoral system. It is unfortunate that not all the weight and attractiveness has been recognised in the Hare-Clark system, which Senator Bell and I would recognise as being worthy of some consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe that the Government, in making amendments to the d'Hondt system, has offered the Committee an opportunity to bring about a situation where most of the objectionable features of the first election held under that general system can be eliminated. It was an absolute disgrace that some 117 candidates standing for the 1989 election created such a difficulty with the count that nine weeks was taken up in completing the count. That is totally unacceptable. So a new system staged--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I cannot hear myself--
—The conversation on my left is too loud.

—Under the new system a stage counting process will be used. As that gets under way we will find that within a couple of weeks the result can be known. In that way much of the very adverse commentary which was attracted to the electoral system in the ACT will be dissipated.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other points in the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill 1991 quite apart from the question of the actual foundation of the proportional representation system to be adopted, which will assist in assuring that the next election to be held in the ACT is of a more serious kind, if I can put it that way as an outsider looking in.

There is no doubt that some steps had to be taken to discourage some of the less serious candidates, the more frivolous groupings, from confusing electors and adding to the difficulty of the voting and counting processes. I think everyone in this Parliament looks forward to the transfer of that responsibility and the discharge of it by the ACT Assembly. In the meantime, I commend the Bill to the chamber and hope that it has passage before the dinner hour.

REPRESENTATIVES
Page 12, Schedule, amendments to the Patents Act 1990 after the item relating to subsection 233 (10) insert:
``Subsection 233(1):
After `Chapter' insert `and the regulations' ''.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the amendment made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the amendment, but there are a few things that need to be put on the record. Firstly, when the former Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) introduced the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill in the lower House, he gave no explanation as to why the amendment was being moved in any way, shape or form. On inquiring from the Minister's office as to the reason for the amendment, it was described by his office as being a simple drafting error identified by the working party on the Patents Act. By inserting the phrase `and the regulations', new section 233(1) will read:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this Chapter and the regulations, this Act applies in relation to a standard patent or a petty patent granted under the 1952 Act as if the patent had been granted under this Act.

This is creating a Henry VIII clause which is, of course, a practice which is universally condemned. At the third conference of Australian delegated legislation committees held in Perth only a week ago, a motion which I actually proposed in the workshop and which was subsequently adopted by the plenary session was worded in this way:

While noting that there may be a rare, justifiable use of a Henry VIII clause where such use would be subject to tabling and disallowance, this Conference believes that Henry VIII clauses have no legitimate general application in the legislative process.

The effect of introducing that phrase and the regulations is to give to the Executive the power to make regulations to actually change the provisions of the transitional and savings provisions contained in the Patents Act. The Minister has chosen to move an amendment to the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 to effect the amendment to the Patents Act because this Bill is an omnibus Bill and there is a schedule at the back of the Bill which contains amendments to the Patents Act. The amendment to that schedule, so as to effect the amendment to the Patents Act, in effect uses the Henry VIII clause technique.

I draw attention to this because I do not think it is acceptable for a Minister to introduce an amendment, which may well be justifiable in the rare case that I mentioned in the motion that was passed in Perth, without explaining to the Parliament why a particular technique is being used and the effect of it. This is because chapter 23 of the Patents Act, the transitional and savings provisions, is a grandfathering operation; but by giving the power to make regulations in this way, the provisions of that chapter may be altered. However, they would be subject to tabling and disallowance. So, although the Opposition will not be opposing the amendment, I do think it is important to place on the record the fact that the Minister did not do the House of Representatives the courtesy of saying why this particular amendment was being moved. Mr McGauran, in the other place, noted that no explanation was given. No explanation has been given here, and I think that that ought to have been done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills before the Senate tonight purports to offer a new start to those currently languishing in the dole queues. Instead, it offers little more than a false dawn, an expensive distraction from the main game and a clear straight sets win for the bureaucrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 forms the centrepiece for the Government's so-called active employment strategy. As such, it is a major disappointment. It is necessary to strip away the complex array of administrative procedures to arise from this Bill in order that the proposals can be seen for what they are: an active employment strategy for more public servants, but offering little hope for the unemployed.

Six hundred new full time positions have been created within the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) to carry out some of the so-called initiatives contained in this Bill. Surely more intensive use of existing CES capacity would have been more appropriate than a wholesale expansion of an organisation very few Australians have a great deal of confidence in. Better still, there would have been an increase in the use of private employment placement agencies. This Bill does little to provide the unemployed with a more appropriate set of incentives to undertake more effective job search activity. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) said recently:

If you've got an unemployment benefit which is simply there as a right that anyone can access for as long as they like on very generous conditions, is it really helping them much? Sure they're getting income support but is it really equipping them . . . to get back into the labour market?

Mr Dawkins is absolutely right. They are fine words, but unfortunately the measures contained in this Bill do not go any distance at all to giving proper effect to that aspiration. Paying unemployment benefit ad infinitum does not encourage an early return to work; it simply promotes a disastrous cycle of welfare dependency. For many, such assistance has become a substitute for paid employment.

In very few other developed countries are such benefits paid on an ongoing, open-ended basis. In the United States, for example, unemployment benefit is typically paid for a maximum of 26 weeks, with the possibility of a further 13 or 26 weeks if the particular state's unemployment level is above a specified minimum. In West Germany the benefit is paid for maximum periods of 16, 20 and 24 months, depending on the age of the applicant. In the United Kingdom unemployment benefit ceases after 10 months. In France unemployment assistance is paid for a maximum period ranging from three of the last 12 months to 24 months of the last 36, depending on age. Even in the classic welfare state of Sweden the maximum period of assistance ranges from 300 to 450 days, again depending on age.

So there we have most of the developed world providing a cap on the length of time unemployment benefits are payable. Yet here is Australia with currently more than 40,000 people who have been on the dole for five years or more, and a package of so-called reforms which does little to ensure that such appalling instances are ended.

A lecturer dismissed from the University of Newcastle some 10 years ago has since been on the dole. In a recent court case relating to his dismissal, the judge said that the former lecturer had made no genuine attempt to mitigate his damages by finding other employment, that many of his job applications had been made to Newcastle University, which obviously would not reappoint him, and that he had `engaged in nothing more or less than a charade'? Why is it that this man was able to receive unemployment benefits for over 10 years without making any serious attempt to find work, but merely going through the motions of fulfilling the work test? Why is it that under the so-called active employment strategy, as embodied in the Bill before us today, there is no guarantee that such appalling abuses would not continue?

One does not have to be very much in touch with the system to know that there is simply a nominal requirement to put down the names of a couple of people with whom one claims to have been in contact. Indeed, that farce which has served both the unemployed and the taxpayers so badly for so long is not addressed in this Bill and presumably will therefore be allowed to continue. The latest justification for that is that it is a matter that will be picked up in due course if there is any centralised concern either through the tax file number or elsewhere.

The fact of the matter is that one does not have to have been in the system for very long to know that all one needs to do is pick a couple of names out of the phone book. Indeed, I have received many complaints from people who are being rung up by applicants who are not interested in finding work, but who simply want to use these people's names to fulfil the minimum requirements.

Unlike Senator Richardson, caught in a sad downward spiral of pandering to one group of special pleaders after another, the coalition is willing to make the hard decisions. We are committed to ending unemployment benefits after nine months, after which time special benefits will be payable in cases of undue hardship and where employment has not been found despite serious job search. Such a policy is not out of step with international thinking, nor is it out of step with the attitude in the electorate. It reflects the view that prolonged, let alone indefinite, welfare dependency is not in anyone's best interests. The sooner people are back in touch with the labour market, the better their chances of establishing new careers.

This Bill does very little for those who have been unemployed for less than 12 months. For these people it will be business as usual. How can we call this an active employment strategy when we are waiting for someone to join the ranks of the long term unemployed before they are given any assistance? Why wait until the problem has eventuated? Surely a program of earlier intervention is far preferable. To this end, the coalition intends legislating to ensure that after six months of being on the Job Search allowance, an unemployed person's entitlements are reviewed, and so also is that person's whole job search strategy.

There will be a mandatory requirement for attendance at an interview and participation in a counselling session which will explore the available options as well as stressing the nine-month cut-off date. Rather than leaving the person out in the cold for an entire year, the coalition intends to do something for the unemployed. But this is not the end of the problems we have here with what purports to be an active employment strategy.

This package of reforms also features a disturbing over-reliance on government training programs. Fifty thousand extra places in such programs are to be created at a cost of $227m up to 1993-94 and this is in addition to the extra $105m announced in the March industry statement. The 50,000 places is small beer compared with the number of Australians displaced by Mr Keating's engineered recession.

Over the past year, more than 144,000 jobs have been wiped out; an extra 319,300 Australians have become unemployed and an additional 222,473 are on the dole. But what are the 844,000 unemployed being offered by this Labor Government in return for such catastrophic job losses-50,000 places in bureaucrat-intensive government programs over the next three years.

Like the recent headline in the Northern Territory News, `Aborigines want jobs, not training' the same can be said for most other unemployed Australians sick of going around on the training roundabout with no jobs in sight. Not only do many of these training programs amount to little more than a very expensive means of keeping the unemployed amused while sitting on the sidelines, but also their content is highly questionable.

We have the Newstart program-as opposed to the allowance-for those who have been on benefits for 12 months or more. Featuring so-called counselling and a show bag of glossy pamphlets telling one how to find a job, the program is little more than an insult to the long term unemployed who have presumably already spent the past 12 months doing the rounds of the bureaucracy. These people want jobs.

An Australian National University academic, Dr Bruce Chapman, suggested in a recent paper that much of the expenditure on government vocational training is wasted unless training is followed fairly quickly by a job. So what do we have in the midst of the most serious downturn since the Great Depression-the Government throwing even more money at training people who will not have the opportunity to put into practice what they have been taught.

Instead of trying to get people into the workplace as quickly as possible, the Government prefers to keep them out of the work force for as long as possible. The only real winners in this orgy of government labour market programs will, as usual, be the recession-proof public sector. It is time for a real solution-labour market reform. It is time for a system of trainee wages to provide the unemployed with real jobs and real training opportunities, rather than enduring the slap in the face of yet another training program leading nowhere.

The Government simply does not have a true active employment strategy. What it has is a farce. The current strategy provides for the active employment of bureaucrats and little else. It is a waste, a sham and a set of lost opportunities. Apart from assessing this Bill in the context of the current job climate, it is also important to measure it up against where we are heading.

The coming few years will be a very rough period for employment. One in 10 Australian workers are currently unemployed and this proportion is rising. Even the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) concedes that the figure will exceed 10.75 per cent-the highest in 60 years. Imagine where we would be without the recent dramatic increases in school retention rates.

Unemployment will rise much further, possibly to stabilise in the medium term at around 12 per cent. This possibly has become even more real, given yesterday's news of yet another decline in the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group job vacancy survey-this time of the order of 6 per cent. On top of this, world capital markets are drying up. This is likely to lead to a rise in world interest rates in the near future, increasing the likelihood of a prolonged world recession. Just as the Australian economy begins to improve with declines in domestic interest rates, it is probable that Australia will be caught up in an exacerbated world downturn. Within the next two years, Australian unemployment may scale new heights, perhaps reaching as high as 13 or 14 per cent. Dr Hewson's prediction of a rolling recession will then become a reality.

Given current policy settings and the Government's policy paralysis, the consequences for employment of a rolling recession will be terrible. With the economy hitting new depths with each successive downswing, unemployment will ratchet higher and higher. The upward spiral of unemployment could be averted, at least in part, if the industrial relations and wages systems were made more flexible at the individual firm level and if the Government cut loose from its anachronistic security blanket-the accord-which is all about protecting those lucky enough to still be in the game.

If such a package of comprehensive labour market reforms is not put in place, the Government's active employment strategy will be absolutely worthless, with millions of dollars of public funds being squandered. There is no point in pushing the unemployed through government training schemes if new skills cannot be tried and tested and there is no point in forcing the unemployed to chase nonexistent jobs.

One of the more surprising features of this Bill is the Government's intention to make eligibility for the Newstart allowance contingent upon having been registered with the CES as unemployed for 12 months. With the Newstart allowance comes prioritised access to labour market programs and CES counselling, all with the aim of providing specialised assistance to the long term unemployed.

However, given the deliberate laxity with which the CES maintains its books, it will be possible for someone to register as unemployed with the CES, either find work or drop out of the labour market altogether and then almost 12 months down the track, receive Job Search allowance and then go on to the Newstart allowance, not because the individual is long term unemployed, but merely because the CES has recorded the person as having been unemployed for 12 months.

Such a scheme is quite likely considering that the CES has over 200,000 more people recorded as unemployed than the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Indeed, the Government has, on numerous occasions, admitted to the total hopelessness of CES unemployment duration figures. On 15 April 1991, in answer to a question on notice the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) said that CES unemployment figures include:
. . . many who no longer require . . . assistance. It is certainly not a measure of the number of people `actively seeking employment.'
On 16 May 1991 an even more eminent source, Senator McMullan, told the Senate:

. . . people can be registered with the CES and they certainly have no obligation to, and do not necessarily, remove themselves from the register when work is found or they move interstate or whatever. It is not a priority of the CES at this time to keep those records precisely accurate.

What a damning indictment. The number of people registered as unemployed at a CES office is one of the variables used to allocate staff among CES offices-so the higher the unemployment registrations at any given time, the higher the staff allocation. So herein lies the CES manager's incentive not to purge the office books of formerly unemployed individuals no longer requiring assistance.

Not only are the CES unemployment figures hopelessly unreliable, but also the CES actually has an incentive to inflate them artificially. It will be a priority of an incoming coalition government to overhaul radically this cumbersome and ineffective bureaucracy. This Bill will lead to many of the long term unemployed missing out on prioritised assistance and many short term unemployed receiving extra and special assistance because of legislative sloppiness. The result: poor targeting and more waste. Senator Richardson has, in recent days, been trumpeting the idea that in recent years social security has become more targeted. He recently told the Age newspaper:
There is also room for efficiency gains, there is also room for some more targeting, but I think we've done so much in the last few years that I have no rabbits up my sleeve.

Yet another blatant and outrageous political ambit claim which has, of course, been slapped down by other senior Ministers in recent days. Yet here we have Senator Richardson presenting a Bill which has massive targeting problems. Peter Baldwin has told him so, Senator McMullan has told him so and I dare say the bureaucracy has advised him so, but all of that advice is to no avail.

To target assistance more tightly to those who need it most and to ensure that the millions of dollars the Government intends throwing at such assistance at least has a chance of being of some use, the coalition intends moving an amendment to ensure that the Bill will not end up being the farce it currently is. Let there be no doubt that the CES is a sluggish organisation-the overweight offspring of the lumbering dinosaur that is the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET). Under the new government-a coalition government-it is doubtful whether it can survive in its present form. A recent Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls-DEET survey on community attitudes to DEET programs and policies found that only 12 per cent of people surveyed nominated the CES as the main way in which the Federal Government assisted the young unemployed. Clearly, this is not due to low recognition factors-nearly everyone has heard of the CES. Rather, it is evidence of the low regard that those surveyed have for the quality of the services the CES purports to provide.

The absurdity of the current duplication of functions, with both the Department of Social Security and CES dealing with different aspects of unemployment, is that during times of prosperity there is a much greater demand for CES services than for those of DSS and during times of adversity this situation is reversed. In other words, at any given time one or other service is clearly under-utilised-a massive waste of government resources and a situation which must be redressed urgently.

The Government professes to be trying to bring the two services together. Indeed, we have a policy of collocation which, on the latest figures, supposedly shows that some 62 per cent of officers are collocated. There is no reason at all why there could not be full integration, other than of course the potential for job losses and no doubt the political odium that would be attached to that-particularly for those who depend on the Public Service and Public Service unions to be re-elected, as do members and senators for the Australian Capital Territory.

So it is quite clear that the Government will go slow in this, as in many other areas, when all the logic of the argument demands that there ought to be full integration, full cohesion and joint interviewing on the same premise; that is that people should not be shuffled from one service to another, quite often now knowing where to start first, let alone not knowing where to come out at the end. What we have here is not an active employment strategy. It is a piecemeal, poorly conceived and unimaginative strategy for waste and lost opportunities.

By comparison, the coalition will put in place a set of integrated and holistic policies which will ensure that income support need not be passive. More effective job search on the part of the unemployed will be ensured as will more job opportunities for the unemployed. Industrial relations and wages reform; the introduction of a goods and services tax in place of the antiquated and distortionary wholesale sales tax system to reduce taxes on exports and raise general efficiency; the reform of the Reserve Bank of Australia to ensure that it pursues price stability so that workers become less concerned over the distributional struggle as prices rise, and more concerned with productivity enhancement; and a whole series of micro-economic reforms, including privatisation, will ensure an expanding economy in which active income support, rather than passive income support, to the unemployed, will quickly become a reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating three Bills cognately tonight and I wish to deal with each of them separately. Firstly, the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991 makes no policy changes. It is simply to ensure transition from the Social Security Act 1947 to the new plain-English Act of this year. I do not want to go through this Bill in any detail. It is relatively straightforward and I take this opportunity to commend again those people who were involved with the drafting of the plainEnglish version. It has certainly introduced a far more accessible piece of legislation. The Australian Democrats support this Bill and will not be moving any amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 implements minor Government initiatives and amends the 1947 Act. Legislation yet to come before the Senate will ensure that these provisions are included in the new Act when the 1947 Act is repealed on 1 July this year. It is fair to say that these initiatives are generally not of concern and, in most instances, actually benefit the clients of the Department of Social Security.

Again, I do not wish to go through it in detail, but I want to look at two clauses-clauses 8 and 19. Clause 8 alters the Act so that scholarship payments awarded outside Australia for the purposes of education and training approved by the Minister do not count as income for the purpose of the income test for pensions, benefits and allowances. This change appears to have come about primarily as a consequence of the Mary Guy case in Tasmania where Ms Guy would have had her invalid pension reduced significantly if she had accepted a scholarship from overseas. The clause has a retrospective element effective on 1 September, but this is mainly to ensure that Ms Guy is covered.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has indicated its dissatisfaction with the clause, calling it an example of legislation by press release and it says that it does not come within the limits which the Committee has been prepared to accept in the past. The Democrats also have some problems with retrospective legislation, but consider that in this case it is desirable. It is an example of a very benign case of retrospectivity. It certainly will not disadvantage anyone-in fact, it remedies what is a very unjust situation. It will benefit only a small number of pensioners and beneficiaries who would otherwise have been seriously disadvantaged and it has minimal financial consequences.

Clause 19 removes from review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal a decision made by the Minister under section 251(1B) of the Act to give directions to the Secretary relating to the latter's power to waive a debt due to the Commonwealth resulting from an overpayment. Again, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has expressed concern at this removal of the power to review and it noted that such a decision was also not disallowable. Section 251(1C) requires the Minister to lay any such decisions before Parliament, but there is no provision for either House to disallow the decision. There has been considerable concern expressed about 251(1C) for quite some time. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs stated in its report on Debt Recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans Entitlements Act as follows:

If such instruments as the directions in s251 are legislative or even quasi-prescriptive in character, then they should be subject not only to tabling but also to disallowance. The purpose of this is to preserve the primacy of Parliament in the law-making process.

The Committee believes that Directions under s251 are clearly legislative, particularly as the Explanatory Memorandum states they are intended to bind the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Government's response to the Committee's recommendations was totally unsatisfactory. In fact, this legislation worsens the position. The Democrats will be opposing this clause and moving an amendment to permit ministerial determinations under section 251 to be disallowable by either House of Parliament within 15 days of their being tabled.

I will now move to the major piece of legislation that we are dealing with tonight, which is the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991. The effect of this is to abolish unemployment benefits as of 1 July this year and replace it with a two-tier system. It was originally announced in 1990 in a February economic statement and was originally called the active employment strategy. It was, however, renamed Newstart after market research indicated an understandable public cynicism with the name. Perhaps the Australian people found the name a trifle ironic in view of the Government's pursuit of an active unemployment strategy in this recession that we had to have.

The scheme is founded on a 1988 social security review by Professor Bettina Cass entitled Income Support for the Unemployed in Australia: Towards a More Active System. It supposedly represents a much closer linking of income support with labour market programs. Its ostensible aims are: to develop a climate of individual support and planning for the unemployed to hasten their return to the work force; to provide greater assistance to the long term unemployed; and to enhance the skills and job prospects of unemployed people with labour market disadvantages and those at risk of long term unemployment. All these aims sound wonderful and are laudable and they are all being trumpeted by the Government from the rooftops.

The Government is offering this as something positive, but these aims do not stand up under scrutiny. Make no mistake-this program will cost the Government votes at the next election because the people whom it will affect worst, the ones who will be severely disadvantaged, are the traditional supporters of the Labor Party. They are the ones most likely to suffer from it.

I will look briefly at how the new scheme works. Firstly, the job search allowance (JSA) is what people move directly on to once they have become unemployed. It lasts for 12 months, but after 3 months an activity test comes into place-the same as the one that is in place now. The unemployed must actively seek paid work and be willing to undertake such work if the secretary, that is, the departmental officer, deems it to be suitable. They must comply with any direction from the Department of Social Security (DSS) requiring them to undertake vocational training courses or participate in a labour market program. In fact, they must take all reasonable steps to get a job and comply with any direction at all.

The unemployed have to attend at least two compulsory interviews with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the DSS. About 10 per cent of JSA recipients will also be required to attend an intensive interview with DSS after three months. Further interviews may also be required of them with the CES. After 12 months, they drop off this system. Here no doubt we will see the first few people who will contribute to the Government saving money because some people will be neither able to follow nor understand how to follow the procedure to reapply for the Newstart scheme, and to make a fresh application on a new set of forms.

In addition to the activity test, which still stays, the unemployed also have to get into what is called a Newstart activity agreement. This is done not with the DSS but with the CES. Compliance with this agreement is a condition of continuing to receive the allowance. The CES will now be able to initiate the cancellation of payment where unemployed people fail to meet the terms of this agreement. There is a three-week period in which all the paper work must be done and the application must be made. Indeed, if it is not made, people can be cut off and will need to know that they must appeal. That appeal must be lodged within 14 days to restore them without any loss of payments.

I have three major problems with this Bill. Firstly, the Democrats object to the compulsion. Secondly, the content of the agreement is vague. It is not specifically written down, certainly not in any legislative form. It is not subject to parliamentary scrutiny or legislative control. The actual courses that will be made available are the third major complaint and concern.

In many cases the courses will be worth while but they are compulsory and will benefit fewer people than would have been the case had the university, technical and further education systems, as well as private courses available, been opened up and unemployed people given the option of attending the course most suited to their needs.

I will look firstly at the content of the agreement and the fact that it is so vague. It is controlled by the discretion and subjective judgment of CES staff. I do not want to in any way criticise CES staff. They are also seeking direction and assistance with the implementation of this legislation. I will give an example of that later.

The legislation is so vague that the Government could force people to do virtually anything. It is all very well for the Minister to say that he will not require anything unreasonable. But we then need to ask why the word `reasonable' is missing from this piece of legislation. It is in the new plain English version. Perhaps we thought it may have simply been taken out from here on, but that is not so. The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991, the next Bill we will be dealing with in a week or so, arrived on my desk today. The word `reasonable' has reappeared, and I only had to go as far as page 9. Why is the word `reasonable' missing from this Bill?

Despite its initial assertions to the contrary, the Government has had to admit that one item-606(1) (e)-could have been used to implement immediately work for the dole. I am very pleased to see that this has now been amended, thanks to the pressure from Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). But still the criteria are very broad, open ended and not subject to parliamentary scrutiny. In fact, originally the contents were not subject to appeal, but the Minister has again recognised an unjust situation and again thanks to ACOSS and its lobbying, we now have that situation remedied.

Still there is no reciprocal obligation upon the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) to actually provide the services that are supposed to be available. It is extraordinary that the unemployed can be compelled to undertake certain activities when there is absolutely no reciprocal obligation on the Government to provide the services mentioned in the agreement. It rather makes a mockery of the word `agreement'.

Let us look at why the agreement is needed. As I have already said, the unemployed are required to meet the activity test. DSS can already terminate payments if a person refuses to take up a job, to do a course or, indeed, even if he or she misses a letter and does not show for an interview with no reason. The unemployed already have to participate in market programs or any other course.

Why does the Government need more? What does it propose to compel the unemployed to do? We do not really know because those regulations will not be put before us. There are already major problems with the types of courses people are compelled to do. I want to read one example tonight from a number of letters I have received. This is from a gentleman, and I quote:

I am thirty years of age this year. I have a BA (Hons) and have completed four years of a Ph.D. I suspended my studies in order to take up employment in 1986. I worked as a Researcher/Organiser for a student union for three years, until my contract expired and I lost my job. Thus, as a relatively young person, with a good education, and flexible job skills, I anticipated only short-term unemployment. However, when it became clear that it was likely to be long term, I considered further studies.
I considered two options. Firstly, completing my Ph.D. However, I would be ineligible for a scholarship or AUSTUDY and would have to lose my unemployment benefits if I enrolled full-time.

The second option was to enrol in a short-term course, in order to develop specific skills which would enhance my chances of re-employment. For example, a number of advertised project officer jobs required a diploma in strategic planning. Other options included a computing course or a diploma of education. However, here too, I would be ineligible for AUSTUDY, would have to lose my unemployment benefits and, in some cases, would have to pay fees. These conditions rule out any retraining I might consider.

Then, to add insult to injury, on Sunday last week, I saw the Employment Minister in an interview saying that people who are unemployed are being paid by the Government, so the Government should expect something in return-namely, that they undergo compulsory retraining. Compulsory? I have not even been allowed to undertake voluntary retraining!

And, to further illustrate this farce, a few weeks ago I received a letter from the CES ``inviting'' me to attend an information session at a local employment centre. However, if I did not accept the invitation I would lose my unemployment benefits.
He goes on to say:

The course, run by the Adelaide Central Mission was a useful and highly commendable one, however, it was of no use to me, being an eight weeks basic office skills course, teaching skills I already possessed. So, on the one hand we have an educational and social security system which prevents me from attending courses which might enhance my employment opportunities. On the other hand, I am forced to attend sessions which are of no use to me whatsoever. And, at the same time, we have a Minister who pontificates on the duties of the unemployed regarding retraining, as if we are a bunch of bludgers desperately trying to avoid education.

As this indicates, the current system of unemployment payments is not, as the Government and the Opposition like to imply, a passive system. There are already rigorously enforced and very difficult conditions. We need to ask: why is the Government screwing it down tighter and tighter, particularly in the current climate? How can it possibly be of any benefit to the unemployed?

It can be clearly demonstrated by the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme for sole parents that it is possible to run a successful scheme voluntarily, without compulsion. Here, large numbers of unemployed people participate and participate very willingly. In fact, the JET programs are generally full, to the point of being oversubscribed. People do want to work, to study and to volunteer. The Government needs to get its house in order and ensure that these opportunities are provided before it starts forcing people into activities unnecessarily.

As one CES worker told me, the fundamental problem with the active employment strategy is that it is all sticks and no carrots. Where are the jobs once the people finish their courses? Here I must agree with Senator Alston. It is being implied that once these people complete these courses they are somehow suddenly employable and the jobs will be there. But the jobs will not be there. For many people, it is simply a further imposition and a further very disheartening and soul-destroying activity. But members of the Government recognise this. To illustrate this, I want to quote very briefly from a speech made by former Minister Stewart West, recorded in the Hansard of 9 May 1991 as follows:

It cannot be denied that the underlying strategy of income assistance being linked with training and tougher compliance type measures was designed for completely different labour market conditions from those which now exist in this country. To make it brutally clear, what we are proposing is not a strategy for the here and now; it was devised in early 1990 when different economic conditions prevailed. At best, it is now a strategy for the future. It may help to produce better trained people for future jobs, but it is not a strategy for the current economic situation.

Australia is currently experiencing a significant decline in job growth. Already this year, we have seen in March the worst one-month job losses on record since the Australian Bureau of Statistics began keeping records in 1978. The official unemployment level reached 9.9 per cent in April, and we suspect that the real or hidden level of unemployed is closer to 15 per cent. The conservative prediction of the former Treasurer was a rise to around 10 1/2 per cent within a few months, and it seems more likely that the official figure will be closer to 12 per cent.

Surely it is clear that it is the lack of jobs that is causing unemployment, not a shortage of labour market programs and certainly not the attitudes of the unemployed people themselves. Perhaps the worst feature of all of this Government's program is that it is pandering to the views of those in the community who believe that we do not need to worry about the unemployed because it is all their fault. One sees letters to the editor in the newspapers and occasionally I get a letter across my desk saying, `Yes, we should cut off all benefits and not support them at all because it is all their fault'. Why do those people believe this? Often it is because they see the end result as being that lower government expenditure means that they pay lower taxes.

I turn now to look at the practical problems. The infrastructure is simply not in place. It is not just the Democrats who are stating this over and over again; it is also ACOSS and the welfare rights centres. It also includes groups such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence which actually have to work with the unemployed and know how hard many people are going to be hit. But it is also the Public Sector Union (PSU), which faxed this document to me yesterday:
. . . members have nothing to offer the majority of long term unemployed in this climate and regard the compulsory nature of Newstart agreement as wasteful and unjust.

These are the people the Government is forcing to implement this program without any real direction at all. The membership have voted on and passed four motions. The second motion relates to the provision of additional staff and a claim for over 1,000 additional staff just to make this program work. We must remember that the CES will have 200,000 people on its doorstep after 1 July. The staff also want adequate training so that they can be fully qualified and capable of assisting these people. In particular, they are asking that the Government hold this off. The first motion reads:

This meeting of PSU members endorses those AES proposals which would increase the employment opportunities for our clients, but to ban any proposed activity testing regime which includes any compulsory contract/agreement as we feel that this would be an unnecessary and intrusive element of our service delivery to clients. Instead we support the development of a genuine client centred service which reflects real client needs.

A number of other people, including CES officers, have written and telephoned me to express their concerns. The first is the difficulties that people from non-English speaking backgrounds are going to experience. Will there be specialised staff to assist them? Secondly, what about young people with special needs-people with psychiatric problems such as schizophrenia who do not qualify for a invalid pension or disability allowance? The third concern relates to professional people, such as the one I mentioned earlier, who already have one or more tertiary qualifications. So much for a clever country!

Despite the significant and welcome injection of funds into labour market programs, there will still not be enough places to go around. It has been estimated that only about 19 per cent of unemployed people gained access to labour market programs in 1989-90. With increased funding, this number may rise to 25 per cent-that is, one in four-but what does the Government intend to compel the other 75 per cent to do? Some labour market programs have merit but most are short term and basic and offer low skills training in areas where frequently there has already been a great loss of jobs and where there are certainly reduced opportunities for employment. There are no positions available as apprentices, in trade courses or in technical courses and, most important of all, there are no jobs available at the end of these courses.

Let us look now at the human rights angle. There are also serious philosophical problems which go to the heart of the sort of society we want this country to be. Article 25 of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights signed in 1948 states, in part:

Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services and the right to security in the event of unemployment . . .
I go on to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. Article 6(1) states:

The State Parties to the present Covenant recognise the right to work, which includes the right of everyone to the opportunity to gain his living by work which he freely chooses or accepts, and will take appropriate steps to safeguard this right. It is interesting that some people in this place can get very concerned about human rights and international obligations when it comes to political advertising, and other people can get very concerned about rights for specific groups such as the charter of residents' rights and responsibilities in approved hostels and nursing homes which passed through this place last year.

Obviously, these are both very important issues and people have legitimate concerns, but where are the concerns now for people who are unemployed? It is an accepted view that citizenship confers a right to adequate income to fulfil basic needs. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has commented that:

Adequate income security . . . is a recognition of the fact that inability to obtain work is a function of economic, social and political forces in a changing society and is not the fault of the individual.

Unemployment exists because of economic and structural forces. It has been some time since the Federal Government has operated from a full employment policy. There is now an acceptance that some level of unemployment will persist. We will not suddenly recover from a situation of 10 per cent unemployment. In fact, it is most likely that we will still have around 5 per cent unemployment at the turn of the century.

What do we do in this climate? We introduce contractual obligations upon the unemployed without a corresponding commitment on the part of government at least to attempt to create more employment, provide adequate resources for the strategy and develop improved opportunities for paid work experience in labour market programs. This is certainly basically putting the blame back on the unemployed for circumstances which are obviously beyond their control. It is nonsensical, irresponsible and divisive to perpetrate the myth that the unemployed are without jobs because they cannot be bothered to look for them.

This legislation represents a fundamental shift away from the concept of the unemployment benefit as an entitlement and a compensation payment from the community for the inability of the labour market to provide adequate income through employment. This strategy certainly reverses the concept of unemployment benefit as an entitlement. Again, I would suggest that this is something that the community needs to look at very carefully and to understand the ramifications of. Make no mistake, the legislation will not reduce unemployment; it will not suddenly mean that lots of people, for genuine reasons, are no longer in need of support payments.

Let us look at income support generally. Looking at waiting periods, the Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, Bishop Michael Challen, observes that many of the 4,809 people receiving material aid from the Brotherhood in the first three months of this year were doing so because they were waiting to qualify for social security payments or because the payments they were receiving were insufficient to pay for their rent, food and clothing. There is another myth that somehow these benefits are of such a luxury standard that nobody need bother, nobody need worry, about finding employment because that person is on such a good thing. Let us also be clear-I refer here to some information that Senator Alston gave us-that we do not need to cut off totally the unemployed who have been on a benefit for nine months, which the Opposition's amendments to be moved tonight or tomorrow would effectively do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, that is not what he said.

—I stress to Senator Walters that if these amendments were passed now, without anything else in place-any of the special benefits that the Opposition has talked about-they would mean nothing was available. We have been through them very carefully with several sets of legal advice. We wish we could have supported the Opposition. We also agree that the Newstart program is effectively a waste of time, and that the labour market programs and the additional CES programs can be accessed without compulsion. If the amendments were passed, people would be cut off any benefit altogether after nine months. I wish to read the comments of a couple of other people, particularly Bettina Cass. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald states:

SPEECH.PARA: Bettina Cass is the professor of social policy at the University of Sydney and the author of a ground-breaking two-year review of the Australian social security system. Pointing to the US, she says: ``There is very little evidence as to what the long-term unemployed in the US manage to live on, but we know there is a very high incidence of despair and violence. That, surely, is what Australia would wish to avoid.''

It is not a disincentive to get to the point where we are forcing people into destitution. They simply have no choice in the stakes. They simply drop out of the system and the community picks up the cost eventually, through the health system, the police, or the gaols; there is an enormous cost to the community. I quote again from the article:

Even commentators to the right of the political centre have significant reservations. Asked whether he believes that discontinuing the dole would result in more crime, Barry Maley, of the Centre for Independent Studies, says: ``There is an intuitive feeling we have that if people are out of work and starving they will do something about it, whereas if you support them with the dole they have much weaker incentive to do that.''

Let us look briefly at job creation. People do want to work. What the Government should be doing is looking at specific job creating programs. Here I refer to a report by the National Advisory Group on Local Employment Initiatives which has, unfortunately, been lying on a shelf somewhere gathering dust. The report, which is entitled Local Employment Initiatives: A Strategic Approach, is four years old and the Government does not seem to have opened it. This report offers an innovative and intelligent approach to providing and funding employment projects at a local level with the aim of generating employment through the development of viable initiatives; for example, cooperatives, municipal enterprises, community businesses, environmental projects or socially focused enterprises.

Finally, I ask those Australians who are lucky enough to have jobs at the moment: do they really want to make it so difficult for people who are out of work, through no fault of their own, to get income support that we will see more and more families queuing for handouts from welfare agencies? Do ordinary Australians, those lucky enough to have work, accept that this legislation will put greater strain on our health system and on our police forces across Australia, as is already happening in South Australia? Under the current system they are already unable to cope with the steadily increasing crime rate. People will survive; somehow they will feed their families. Do the ordinary people of Australia accept that the pressures will increase further on our schools, as more and more school counsellors are required, on our transport police, on our rail systems and on public order in general? Do people really want to be party to this punitive campaign against the most vulnerable people in our society, against those who are not as fortunate as themselves?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation being debated this evening is the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991. As of yesterday, or the past couple of days, the Government has had the hide to give us another 11 amendments to this legislation, at a time when there are well over a million people looking for jobs. Looking at the March figures-we can look only at the March figures because the April figures will not be available until tomorrow or Thursday, and I hate to think what they will be-the Government has calculated that 844,000 people, or 9.9 per cent of Australians, are unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider how those figures are arrived at. They do not include a tremendous number of people who are basically either unemployed or underemployed. If a person is unemployed and works for one hour a week for a friend and no payment is made but a survey is undertaken and that person is asked whether he has done anything at all in the way of employment that week and he says, `Yes, I worked for a friend for an hour, but I did not get any money for it', he is still not classed as unemployed, irrespective of whether he has been paid. Again, if people take part in any training scheme, they are not classed as unemployed. Figures for March 1991, provided to the Age newspaper under the Freedom of Information Act, show that 1,054,000 people were looking for work. Never before in Australia's history have one million people been unemployed. I believe that the Government is panicking, trying to save on unemployment dollars, and is looking for a way out of the huge bill that it knows will come its way. As I say, these figures are for March. What will the April figures be like? They are due out either tomorrow or Thursday.

The figures go further than that. Looking at the tables, we find that 9.7 per cent of Australians, or 832,800 people, work on a casual or part time basis for fewer than 15 hours a week. On top of that 9.9 per cent, an additional 9.7 per cent are underemployed. In the past three quarters, an average of 190,000 people have been shifted from the unemployment benefit to other benefits such as the special benefit, the sickness benefit and the invalid pension. This means that an additional 190,000 people-10 per cent-are removed from the unemployment figures by being placed on other benefits.

As for the people who have just become unemployed or who have just been thrown out of a job, what hope can they possibly feel, when the Government of the day is behaving in the way it is? We have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who has admitted that, while he did not like doing it, he had to mislead the people about his agreement with Paul Keating because had he told the truth he would not have won the election. We have the situation where the Prime Minister misled the Australian people and, as a consequence, this charade has been going on in the Parliament-while we have one million people unemployed, and all the tragedies that arise from that.

For the first time-and I think it was probably because the Prime Minister was under such pressure over his leadership-the Government refused to support the Industrial Relations Commissioner when he brought down the 2.5 per cent award wage decision. The Government refused to support him and came out and said that it would support the unions. Indeed, we had Mr Hawke himself sitting with the employers on the waterfront, demanding that Accord Mark VI be followed. Accord Mark VI was for an immediate payment of $12 per week, with an additional wage increase of about 4 per cent to be negotiated at enterprise level and an additional 3 per cent employer superannuation contribution to be phased in over the next couple of years.

Rather than go for the Industrial Relations Commissioner's decision, when we have more than one million people unemployed, the Government still went for the unions, and that is because the union power within this Government is paramount. Telling the truth to the electorate is not paramount. The deal done between the Prime Minister and his Treasurer at the time concerning who would take over the leadership is paramount. But the question of the number of unemployed people is not paramount in the Government's thinking. Paramount, though, is the deal done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) on the award wage under Accord Mark VI.

Tonight Senator Lees told us that the Democrats would be willing to support our amendment. She said that she thought that the Newstart arrangements with this Government were just a waste of time. If we put through amendments to make special benefits applicable after nine months, will the Democrats support those?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?
—Well, Senator Alston has already put up one amendment and I am sure we will put up the other amendment if we get a guarantee from you that you will support--
—Order! Senator, please speak through the Chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure the Democrats understand that we will put up the additional amendments that are in line with our policy, so long as we get a guarantee--
—He is not interested.
—Well, now I am being told by Senator Bell that we are not interested, and I can assure him--
—No, Senator Alston is not interested.
—Order!

—I can assure him that we are interested. But I will be amazed if the Democrats support our amendments. In the coming months, as former Treasurer Keating indicated, the unemployment figures will be horrific. In just the last week in Tasmania three large industries have closed. Ovaltine, which has been synonymous with Tasmania, has closed down, with the loss of 170 jobs. A fishing company has gone into receivership, a company that worked out of George Town, with the loss of another 70 jobs. Today, we have seen the loss of 68 jobs in the silicone industry. That may not sound much to the larger States of Victoria and New South Wales, but it means a tremendous amount in my State-and I hate to think what tomorrow or Thursday will bring in terms of further unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to members of the Government to start getting their house in order again, to pull themselves together, to give up their head counting and their number crunching and to think of the people out there who are unemployed, in ever increasing numbers every day. Instead of mucking about as they have been doing, they must think of how they are going to deal with the present recession, which, according to the Government, we had to have because we were expanding too rapidly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed active employment strategy is based on some false and incredibly arrogant assumptions. The plan, developed before the recession, assumes that a personal lack of effort rather than a lack of jobs is the reason for a person being unemployed. I am surprised that I have not come across the word `deems' in this legislation, because `deeming' a condition or a situation that a person might be in seems to be a favourite method of operation. Nevertheless, the strategy assumes that somebody who is unemployed, by definition, has no skills worthy of employment and that new skills must be acquired before employment will result. That assumption is certainly wrong. I think just a couple of examples might suffice to illustrate this. The Tasmanian Teachers Federation estimates that there are some 1,000 unemployed teachers in Tasmania. We need to ask: what sort of training does the active employment strategy propose for such unemployed teachers? What about the other unemployed professionals whom we know exist?

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of case studies were sent to us just this evening. Are these unemployed professionals, people who have made a significant contribution and sacrifice in order to train and obtain qualifications, meant to scrap their years of education and go for a new start? I suggest not. I suggest that the assumptions that come with this strategy are faulty, when they assume that such situations can develop. The training programs that we have at the moment and the vocational courses that exist now in our institutions of higher education are already over-subscribed, so it is difficult to see the need for the active employment strategy's compulsory training contracts.

The unemployed people who exist now have already indicated their willingness to undertake training. They are already trying to crowd into existing training opportunities. The Government's existing programs have failed to meet the demand that exists now. According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 March this year, Government spending on job training and employment programs has declined by 69 per cent per capita since the 1982-83 recession. That sort of statistic gives the lie to the assumptions made in this Government's approach to the problem.

It is true that after a long period of unemployment it is much harder for people to gain new employment. The increase in the number of long term unemployed people will far outstrip the extra places promised by the Government for training and work experience.
