According to the Australian Council of Social Service, only 26 per cent of the long term unemployed were able to secure a place in training programs last year. By next year, the increase in the number of long term unemployed will mean that only one in four will be able to secure such a place-that is, if those training programs exist as they do now.

In the current climate it is imperative that this Government place a higher priority on training and employment services, including paid work experience programs. They are the sorts of things that are hard to define but they are the sorts of things that people find extremely valuable. The paid work experience program is not necessarily defined as employment, but it is the pre-vocational experience which people are able to use to both identify themselves to prospective employers and identify prospective employers to them. That is the sort of commitment or strategy which we should have seen in this legislation.

The latest unemployment figures are due out on Thursday and, as we have heard, most market analysts expect the figure to top 10 per cent of the Australian work force. This would represent a record number of 844,000 people. That is a 60 per cent increase in just 12 months. It is hard to imagine a 60 per cent increase-it is very seldom depicted in that way-but the rise over the last 12 months has been astronomical.

In Tasmania we have the second highest unemployment rate, seasonally adjusted at 10.8 per cent, behind only Western Australia which had a figure of 11.1 per cent. It is the teenage job seekers who continue to be badly hit. We are all well aware of that. To repeat the sort of message that we are so terribly familiar with, unemployment among 15- to 19- year-olds rose in April to nearly 26 per cent and there are figures which suggest that these proportions run more closely to one in three.

I would support the contention that there is an unemployment level which is hidden by these sorts of statistics. Dare I say it, I agree with Senator Walters that the survey techniques used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in this instance, of discounting those who have had some form of employment for more than an hour in the survey period as having been employed, are nonsense. Such a failure to count people is really flying in the face of commonsense. As I said, I agree with Senator Walters that there would be a greater number of unemployed people than those surveys revealed, especially young people.

According to a report in the Australian Financial Review of 3 June, the number of job advertisements fell by more than 6 per cent just in May. Last Thursday we were told by the former Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, that his prediction was that unemployment would hit 10.75 per cent in 1991-92. I do not know whether that was a swan song from him, but I would suggest that it was a conservative one, whatever it was, because there are employers who are still scaling down their staff and there are other economists who predict that that figure might get even higher.

It depresses me to have to say these sorts of things because I believe that there is some sort of talking down effect when people in parliament, or anywhere else in public, make those sorts of statements. It is not quite the effect of a run on a bank but it is depressing. It is depressing for me to have to repeat these statistics with which we are all too familiar.

The fact is that more than half a million Australians have been out of paid work for three months or more. That is a statistic which we cannot deny and have to face up to. Figures from the ABS, such as they are, show that in April 509,200 people were unemployed for three months or more and this was a rise of 200,000, or 65 per cent, in the nine months from July 1990-a shocking set of statistics. They are statistics which, rather than glibly glossing over them and saying they are too embarrassing to look at, we should emphasise enough until something is done that is actually useful.

Continuing with the depressing statistics, in that same period the number of people out of work for one year or more increased by 46 per cent to 182,500. That figure is expected to rise above 200,000 by the end of this year. The official figures suggest that anyone losing a job is at risk of long term unemployment and there are currently around 30 unemployed people for every job vacancy.

A report recently released by the Brotherhood of St Laurence stated that most of the Federal Government's policies are irrelevant and will do little to stem this surge in poverty and long term unemployment. It is strong criticism indeed. The report was considered and not flippant at all, and one into which went a great deal of research. The report was entitled Unemployment in the Recession: Policies for Reform and stated that high unemployment and the recession mean that the Federal Government's key policy vehicle-the active employment strategy-has already lost much of its relevance. That is because the active employment strategy was developed before this recession for conditions of high employment growth. That is the logic which we have to question. In addition, the report from the Brotherhood of St Laurence says that the active employment strategy is really only half a strategy, because it does not have a strategy to enable unemployed people to get jobs but merely to qualify for them.

The Australian Democrats agree with a number of the recommendations in the report of the Brotherhood of St Laurence. These include increasing the number of trainees and apprentices, and increasing resources for the technical and further education (TAFE) sector, in particular, for retraining and upgrading skills. The report also recommends that the Government should stimulate the economy to provide more jobs and more opportunities for paid work experience-there it is again-in labour market programs. It also suggests that training programs such as Jobtrain and Skillshare should become longer and more intensive.

I must say that, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which recently held a public hearing in Hobart, I was fortunate to attend a site visit to a Skillshare project in Hobart, with which I am familiar-the Willson Training Centre. The representatives from that group were unanimous in their recommendations to our Committee, but in particular about one. They suggested that the modular approach-the short term skill training sessions-was not in accordance with the demands and needs of those who are unemployed and seeking employment and training for employment in overwhelming numbers from that provider of training. Those experienced people who have been working in this area for more than a decade were able to tell us that longer and more intensive periods of time in which to prepare people for employment were very important and what they needed. They said that the 12-week or similar modules of training were frustrating these experienced trainers and making it difficult to place people afterwards.

These mickey mouse, fancy courses that seem to be drawn up by bureaucrats in isolation from the real work force attract the sorts of criticism which the bureaucrats and the designers of such things should have taken into account at least eight years ago, because these criticisms have been consistently made by the people involved in preparing young people for employment.

The Democrats also support the development of enterprise schemes, including the opportunity to establish local cooperatives, which at the moment is administratively and legally difficult but which nevertheless encourages and supports the establishment of various business projects. It is the clumsiness of our administrative and legal procedures which, in many cases, precludes those sorts of things from being established. Rather than assume that people need training to find employment, it might be wiser to look at the administrative red tape and mumbo jumbo that we put in front of people who have the capacity to develop employment for themselves in a number of enterprises if only they were given the opportunity and if only the administrative procedures were made a lot easier to establish such things as worker cooperatives or local work groups.

Moving away from the job market, at least in theory Australian universities are experiencing record levels of unmet demand and over-enrolment. That is another problem which shows the irrelevance of this active employment strategy because people are clamouring for places at existing training institutions, if we define universities, for the purpose of this debate, in that way. There are no Tasmanian figures for unmet demand for higher education simply because there is no admission centre in that State but a number of applications are still rejected. There are other students who apply only to mainland institutions because they are aware of the situation and know that tertiary enrolment in Tasmania is difficult.

We can measure this nationally. We know that, in 1990, 20,000 people who qualified for entry into university failed to get a place. This year the unmet demand figure is closer to 30,000 and that is the measurement we are able to make. That does not include those who may have qualified but who knew that getting a place was difficult and knew that it was a pointless or fruitless exercise. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee reports that up to 29,100 eligible applicants have failed to gain a place this year. That is an increase of more than 40 per cent since 1990. The problem demonstrates that people are seeking training and a development of their skills, which would enable them to be more employable. At least that is one of the reasons why people are trying to get into university.

We have a proposition which will compel people to enter a training contract or arrangement, which has as its end point a training agreement. Yet at the moment this Government has been unable to rearrange or schedule its activities or priorities so that people who are already willing, without any compulsion, to enter into further education are unable to have that willingness met with the provision of a place.

The solution is not what has been proposed by some as an up-front fee for students who qualify but who miss out on places. That would effectively place Australian students in competition with full fee paying overseas students. No doubt the idea could spread across the board. This really would be back door privatisation of our universities. This has been suggested by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and we disagree with it. The Liberal-National Party coalition has also suggested it and we disagree with it too. The Industry Commission draft report on the export of education services, released today, also suggests it and we disagree with it, too. We do not feel alone because we know that it is not a proposition which should be supported. Thankfully, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, has already ruled this out. He was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 28 May this year as doing so.

I can understand why the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee might be tempted to suggest this because it is frustrated knowing that, according to its research, Australian universities have enrolled 15,000 more students than they had been funded for this year. So the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee can be forgiven for coming up with such a suggestion. I cannot imagine why the coalition would come up with that suggestion. I will not forgive the coalition, no matter what its reason.

The other aspect of universities is indicated in a landmark study by the National Institute of Labour Studies released in April this year. That established that Australia would face a shortfall of academic staff in our universities of up to 20,000; just a shortfall of staff would be up to 20,000 by the year 2000. Again, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee believes that continuing expansion in higher education, especially at the demand that it can see knocking on the doors now, is such that the shortage might be even greater-perhaps up to 25,000 by the end of the decade.

In a similarly unfortunate manner, the TAFE system has found it impossible to cope with the demand for places this year. Estimates are that TAFE institutions are being forced to reject approximately 100,000 applications. Yet again this proves the lie to this strategy that requires people to enter compulsory training contracts, agreements or whatever they are. With 100,000 people unable to get into existing TAFE courses, what on earth is going to be the situation farther down the track when this strategy is brought into force? One would imagine that to get the house in order we could get the existing institutions able to meet existing demand before we propose that there be imposed upon them an additional need to be catered for.

Given the state of our tertiary sector at the moment, there is an urgent need to redirect funding to construct new buildings, to increase infrastructure, employ more staff, and increase funding for off-campus studies. In my direct experience, off-campus studies provide an excellent return for the investment the community makes in the provision of those studies. Not enough consideration is given to this particular sector of our education provision. The provision of off-campus studies is a particularly effective way for people to develop new skills without needing infrastructure to the same extent as on-campus studies. By definition, a campus is not required and by practice many of the other expensive requirements in education provision are not so expensive in the off-campus provision of education.

I suggest that we would be wise to look at the opportunities which are becoming increasingly available with developing technology to regain the lead which Australia once had in this area. We did have an international reputation for our initiative and our use of technology in helping people in remote areas gain skills. That may be one way that we can increase the provision of skills for our population without adding inordinate expense.

But, without any funding and without redirecting the funding which we are now providing, Australia will continue to lose its academic and research base. The quality of the education that we can provide even now has deteriorated because of overcrowding. I suggest that anybody who has not witnessed such overcrowding should visit any tertiary campus in Australia as soon as possible. Next week would be a good time. Simply by visiting a campus, the overcrowding is demonstrated.

The Australian Democrats would support a greater emphasis on vocational training, as has been suggested both by the Brotherhood's report and others. Vocational training is not necessarily simply defined as labour market training, but as training in preparation for vocations. I think this difference should be apparent. It is interesting to note in passing that the very successful pre-vocational programs of the TAFE system were discontinued last year. I hope that it is fact and not rumour that they will be reintroduced, because those who were involved in those programs have been able to tell me that the pre-vocational courses were successful on the basis of a number of criteria and that their discontinuation is difficult for those participating to understand. The reasons why I support the pre-vocational programs are a little like those that I have given for supporting paid work experience programs. Those pre-vocational courses allowed prospective employers to evaluate their prospective employees and, as such, were particularly effective.

The critics of our present system say that the German model, rather than the overblown American model, is the one that we should be following. Under the West German model, employer spending on vocational training equals nearly half of the government spending on all forms of education. The models are there. I suggest that they are well known as well. What is frustrating is our inability to recognise what is good and what is quality and to take advantage of it.

The present figures for Australia in comparison with those of overseas countries are depressing and disgusting. They are disgusting to somebody who believes that there is a future-that we have a future which we can grasp and a future which belongs to those who are ready for training now. Yet we see that we have had a drastic cut in apprenticeships; that there are 47 per cent fewer apprentices than in the record year of 1989. In that year, analysts thought that we would still fail to match supply with future Australian demands. But Australian Bureau of Statistics figures now show that two out of three unemployed Australians are without any post-school qualifications, including apprenticeships. People with trade qualifications make up 8 per cent of our total unemployed and people with degree qualifications still make up 6 per cent. This is changing as our recession deepens.

Graduates, it is thought, succeed because of their adaptability. Richard Blandy from the Institute of Labour Studies made that assertion. But, with current trends, we will be educating many people who will be scrambling for even fewer professional jobs. As such, undergraduate qualifications will be progressively devalued. The obvious situation is that, while present circumstances have created a job squeeze, industry, by cutting back the number of apprentices it trains, is laying the foundations for a skills shortage in the near future. It will not be an option for Australia, as it has in the past, to import skilled migrants to meet that need. We will suffer greatly from that skills shortage in the future.

During the past few months I have spoken to thousands of young people across Australia. The common fear of those young people is that they are being forced into study or training programs with very little prospect of employment after years of subsistence living as students. We are not properly catering for these people as students anyway. Many students are, in fact, hidden unemployed. They are young people who are not successful at school but who no longer have the option of skilled or semi-skilled labouring jobs. On the other hand, unemployed people are prevented from undertaking part time study to improve their prospects. That is another contradiction of this scheme. At the moment, Austudy is still less than the adult unemployment benefit, and tertiary fees discriminate against disadvantaged students. We have people who want to take on a career based on further study and improving their skills. The way we have organised our Austudy regulations and administration makes it extremely difficult for those people to do so.

In this strategy we have the assertion and the assumption that people do not want to continue their study. In fact, the mumbo jumbo that people confront in the administration of the many schemes we already have make it very difficult for people to engage in further training even when they want to. I feel that this is yet another example of a scheme which has been dreamt up in isolation from the real world. It is a scheme that we should not endorse in any way at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is currently considering the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991. This is a most important piece of legislation for the Parliament, particularly in these unfortunate, difficult economic times. The Federal Government proposes changes to the unemployment benefit from 1 July this year: a Job Search allowance for the first 12 months of unemployment and a Newstart allowance after that. Under the latter category, people will be asked to sign employment training contracts in order to remain eligible for benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I want to address only two specific issues that impact on this scheme and on so many people throughout Australia. For this issue I am relying principally on my experience in the Northern Territory, where there are some unusual effects of the social security system, es- pecially in regard to young people searching for jobs and looking for a genuine new start. Secondly, I will address a few comments to the specific problems that many unemployed Aboriginal people find that they have to cope with, not just because of their dire economic straits but also because of their isolation and the unusual and abnormal education and sociological problems in many remote communities of Australia. In looking at the legislation I was interested to note the following comment in the explanatory memorandum:

The Newstart Activity Agreement would be a document outlining the activities which a person has agreed to undertake as a condition of ongoing qualification. Under the terms of the Agreement, a person could be required to undertake activities such as job search, participation in vocational training courses or labour market programs, paid work experience, training designed to assist the person in searching for work and measures designed to eliminate or reduce labour market disadvantages of a person. A person may also propose voluntary work.

When negotiating the agreement, the CES would be required to take into consideration the person's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition as well as the state of the local labour market and training opportunities available.

Through representations that I have received, my attention has been drawn to literacy. I want to concentrate particularly on a report entitled A National Adult Literacy Strategy that has been prepared by the Australian Council for Adult Literacy. There is a fundamental issue that must be addressed in looking at problems of the unemployed and in asking them to undertake specific training programs. Adult literacy and numeracy is the foundation upon which all further training is built. I think that is a fundamental statement. It is certainly the key emphasis that the Australian Council for Adult Literacy has addressed.

When we look at problems of people who are caught up in the unemployed network and the social security system we need to wonder very seriously about the adequacy of the base qualification for participation in other vocational training. If people are unable to participate in the offered or suggested vocational training or educational training schemes, in effect, we will be compounding the problem by requiring them to participate in particular programs from which they cannot achieve a satisfactory objective at the end of the day. The Adult Literacy Council is concerned that people without basic literacy and numeracy skills would be unable to access these sorts of training programs and, therefore, risk losing their benefits. Drawing again on the national strategy document produced by the Australian Council for Adult Literacy, I quote from its rationale:

As a nation we must become more productive. A flexible workforce capable of developing transferable skills, is one vital element in achieving this economic goal. Retraining, job redesign, award restructuring and skills improvement will succeed only if it is recognised that adequate skills in literacy and numeracy form the basis for learning new skills and knowledge. For many people, their initial education will not, for various reasons, equip them to deal with a changing work environment. Seventy per cent of those who will be in the workforce in the year 2000 have already left school. Means other than those provided through the compulsory education sector must be available to enable people to develop literacy skills as their circumstances and needs change.
The document continues:
Where lack of literacy withholds access to employment, to advancement within employment, education or to the acquisition of new skills, neither economic productivity nor social justice is achieved.

Currently, literacy programs, particularly in the Northern Territory, are stretched to the limit. They will be unable to cope with any increase in applications or referrals from the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). Therefore, I challenge the Minister responsible and the Government, as part of the provisions of what they are intending to achieve by this legislation, to outline clearly to the Senate and to the Parliament the means by which they are going to ensure that the people from the various networks of unemployment and social security will be first assisted and trained in appropriate literacy courses to reach the desired level for participation in the appropriate vocational and other educational training that is required.

The matter is complicated because of lack of research into the level of illiteracy-right throughout Australia, not just in the Northern Territory-particularly among people in geographically isolated areas who have no access to literacy programs. This is an urgent and serious matter. It will, of course, involve the participation of the various State educational departments and educational authorities. I note that Senator Bell alluded to many of those issues. We have to be sure that the Government's intention in this legislation is that it will reach the appropriate consumer need in that area.

The second issue that I would challenge the Government to consider very seriously relates to the particular problems that apply to unemployed Aboriginal people in remote communities throughout Australia. I noted recently that the Public Sector Union in the Northern Territory urged CES workers to reject the contract system for long term unemployed. This, in turn, led to media speculation that they would refuse to operate the new scheme. The Sunday Territorian of 19 May 1991 reported their concerns. It reads:

Other perceived difficulties with the proposed system will be peculiar to the Territory. How, for example, will the contracts apply to Aborigines- in some settlements unemployment is as high as 90 per cent-and who will have the job of securing the contracts?

We must now engage and rely on special technology for those isolated parts of Australia that have to participate in programs such as these. The development of Imparja Television Pty Ltd in central Australia-which, of course, reaches a much wider network throughout outback Australia; particularly in Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia, as well as the Northern Territory-is a medium that I would commend to the CES for ensuring that programs can be effectively delivered and for which special programs can be developed.

The Federal Government very generously makes available some $2m for application to the operation of Imparja on an annual basis through the administration of the Northern Territory Government. I hope that this is an area where the Government will look sympathetically at the particular needs of Imparja and the various government departments which must be charged with the responsibility of ensuring that unemployed Aboriginal people in remote parts of Australia, along with other unemployed Australians, are not denied their basic rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 is being introduced in a climate of record unemployment. I thought that I would spend a couple of minutes tonight giving a brief Queensland perspective. In Queensland the latest official unemployment figure is 10.7 per cent, which equates to over 164,000 people. The hidden figure, no doubt, is even higher. The percentage of young people is undoubtedly higher, as is the percentage of Aboriginal people who are unable to find work. Over 10,000 Queenslanders lost their jobs in April and now have to compete with the thousands of others looking for decreasing numbers of jobs. The headline of a recent article in the Courier-Mail summed it all up in these words: `The Jobless Nightmare'.

SPEECH.PARA: A quick ring around the jobs advertised recently in Queensland produced the following information: a position as a junior accountant produced 25 written applications in the first three days; a position as a receptionist in a legal firm produced 50 applications; a position as a real estate salesperson produced over 50 applications; a position as a community worker produced 30 written applications in the first three days; and a position as an assistant in a print shop produced 120 applications.

I mention these basic figures to show that I believe people are trying very hard to gain employment. The inference of this legislation-that people will not look for work unless they are forced to do so-is, I believe, highly questionable. As well as there being insufficient jobs available, as previous speakers have pointed out, there is already insufficient funding for higher education places, with an unmet demand for last year of close to 5,000 people. The figures for this year are expected to be higher. Those people trying to attempt to improve their skills by attending technical and further education colleges are also about to be faced with vastly increased fees in Queensland, courtesy of the Queensland Labor Government.

The introduction of the active employment strategy, with its emphasis on compulsion and policing of unemployed people at a time of enormous unemployment, is an outrageous imposition on the many people who are already suffering greatly as a direct result of the Government's failed economic policies. The new procedure which will be introduced as a result of this legislation will place greater power and responsibility on the staff in Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices. CES staff, using very broad discretionary powers granted in this legislation, will be able to penalise so-called offenders by removing their benefits, potentially for enormous lengths of time.

The workload and the stress load on CES and Department of Social Security (DSS) staff will be hugely increased by these measures. Staff in these departments do a good job in circumstances that are made more difficult every day by the growing numbers of unemployed people and by policy changes. However, there are always occasions when a staff person can be unfairly harsh on people and in many ways I think that this is more likely to happen when staff workloads are too high. CES staff already have the power, in effect, to terminate a person's benefit by determining that the person has failed a works test. Failing a works test means that the beneficiary is deprived of income for two weeks for a first offence or for six weeks for every subsequent offence.

There have already been cases which show how dangerous it is to give broad discretionary powers to staff and a few examples that I know of from Queensland in recent months include: a person failing a work test-and his income being cut off-for being five minutes late for a CES interview; a person not attending a job interview because he was at the hospital whilst his wife gave birth to their first child. Anyone who loses his source of income because of an unfavourable CES report and who wishes to dispute the determination is also likely to face the prospect of being shuffled between CES and DSS offices as they try to sort out how to get some money.

The recent reports on racist violence in Australia and on black deaths in custody have shown that racism is still widespread in Australia. The potential for Aboriginals or migrants to be subjected to unreasonable demands as a result of conscious or even unconscious discrimination is another cause for worry.

To provide greater opportunities for training and vocational courses is quite obviously desirable. To reduce the security of unemployed people's income by forcing them to jump through every hoop they are instructed to is outrageous. The many people who are faced with the daunting prospect of unemployment need support and encouragement, not hoop jumping. The last thing they need is to be faced with a range of penalties and compulsory contracts being imposed upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main Bill which we are debating tonight, the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, is being discussed at a time when the number of jobs has drastically declined and there has been a massive increase in the number of unemployed. The present rate of unemployment is 9.9 per cent and it is predicted by those on both sides of this House to increase. The number of unemployed is at a record high. As Senator Walters has said, there are more than one million people registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) looking for work.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to these figures, there are hundreds of thousands of hidden unemployed: those who remain studying although they want to work; those who are working part time but who really would like to work full time; housewives who wish to enter the work force; and recipients of other Department of Social Security benefits-invalid pensioners and sole parents who would like to better themselves financially in the work force.

In Victoria, the number of unemployment beneficiaries rose by 84,000 or 120 per cent. That figure more than doubled during the year from April 1990 to April 1991. That is the climate in which we are debating this Bill. It must be recognised that during this recession-the Keating devised recession-that there are simply not enough jobs to go around. It is widely recognised that a job slump has occurred in all sectors-the skilled and unskilled, primary industry, manufacturing and the service sector.

In a very tight labour market, it is imperative that people are given an opportunity to find work and improve their skills. The unemployed should not be given open-ended access to government benefits for little or no positive job search and skill improvement assistance. The Government must take up the challenge of promoting and fostering more innovative, flexible employment and training programs which are oriented towards skills which are needed in the future. There should be more use of community resources and a greater emphasis on community endeavour.

In addition, there must be greater flexibility and innovation in industrial relations. As far as manpower planning, for example, is concerned, there ought to be part time and casual work and training and re-skilling wages. These are some of the issues that Senator Alston raised earlier in order to address the concerns. In addition, economic changes are required to lead to the creation of the jobs which will rectify some of the problems that we are seeing here. Just having this sort of program is not enough; we need an overall approach.

One of the issues that I do not think has been mentioned this evening which is of concern to me is the upcoming bulge in the number of long term unemployed. The rapid increase in unemployment has been concentrated over the past six months. This means that there is going to be a rapid influx of those who have been unemployed for 12 months during the next six to 12 months unless there is a major improvement in economic circumstances. If we believe what Mr Keating said about the level of unemployment and how long it will be sustained at the present level or greater, we can expect that bulge not just to be a temporary bulge but quite a large one-a pig going through a python. In fact, the pig is going to be enormous.

The consensus is that the economy will pick up no earlier than 1992. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Button recognise that unemployment will be one of the last areas to pick up if and when the recovery occurs. The Government's failure to introduce a more flexible industrial relations system will exacerbate and prolong the present constriction of the labour market, particularly at the youth and mature age ends of the market, which currently are practically non-existent.

There are presently 180,000 long term unemployed. The 60,000 increase since the beginning of this year is made up of those people who were unemployed at the onset of the recession, who predictably have not been able to find work since. When the full effect of those who have lost their jobs during this recession is felt, it is not unthinkable that the number of long term unemployed could reach 300,000 in the first half of 1992. This is the scenario facing a Commonwealth Employment Service which will be required to negotiate, update and check compliance with Newstart agreements that have been made with each and every person who has been unemployed for longer than 12 months. This will place an enormous strain on the staff and skill resources of the CES, but we have been given absolutely no indication of the number of recipients of Newstart agreements, nor has there been any convincing argument to show that the CES has sufficient resources to undertake this task effectively.

It has to be ensured with the implementation of this legislation that every client who negotiates a Newstart agreement fully understands what that agreement entails. It is important that each client is treated with the same courtesy, respect and fairness. I have been told that the officers undertaking negotiations will be at an ASO4 level. They must have an intimate knowledge of the process of negotiating these agreements and they must have the relevant people skills: patience; ability to listen; a genuine interest in the client's well-being; and an ability to communicate on the same level as the client.

There will be a wide cross-section of people entering into these agreements: migrants; those with literacy problems; rural people; unskilled people; young people and old people. Unless the CES officers possess well-defined negotiating and people skills, the marked differences in age, command of the English language, life experience and knowledge of the social security system will result in conflicting situations. Every client should have the opportunity to study the agreement form, both before they enter the negotiations and again before they sign the form.

In addition, I believe all clients should be allowed to be accompanied by an advocate who can assist them during the negotiations. They should also be allowed to bring family members with them, as they may be directly affected by the agreement. Clients should be informed before the negotiations commence that if they consider that they cannot communicate effectively with the officer who is chosen to negotiate with them they can ask to be interviewed by another officer. Apparently, the CES does not have any migrant liaison officers of its own and it has claimed that it will purchase this service from the Department of Social Security. The question I have is: will every client who requests such assistance be provided with it throughout the negotiation process? I envisage that this process will be very costly and time consuming and I wonder whether this has been budgeted into the costing of this program.

Another question I wish to ask is: what is the legal status of the Newstart activity agreement? The agreement itself and the legislation are quite clear about what will happen if the client does not comply with the provisions set down in part B-they will not be eligible for continued payment of the Newstart allowance. However, what will happen if the CES cannot provide the activities which are laid down in the agreement-particularly if it is a Commonwealth program which is part of the agreement and the program is not being run, there are too many people in it, or for some other reasons the persons are not able to undertake the agreement because of some breakdown on the part of the Commonwealth? What will happen if a Newstart client is injured whilst undertaking a training or voluntary work program that is set down in the Newstart agreement?

I brought this concern to the attention of the Department of Social Security and I was told that a legal opinion was being sought urgently from the Attorney-General's Department. I have not received a copy of this opinion; however, the office of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) has informed my office that the opinion states that the Department would not be liable unless it suggests an inherently dangerous activity.

It seems odd to me that I might sign an agreement with the Commonwealth as an unemployed person and proceed on my way to the voluntary activity which is part of the agreement and I might be insured when I am taking part in that voluntary activity-meals on wheels or whatever program the agreement might have set out-but what happens if I am injured on the way to the local council to undertake meals on wheels on a two-day basis? What responsibility does the Commonwealth have? I hope that has been clarified because, in fact, I have entered into an agreement with the Commonwealth which is almost like an employment situation. I am doing that as part of an agreement in order to receive my benefit. What happens if I am injured on the way to the program? Will the Commonwealth also ensure that any program I am engaged in has appropriate insurance cover? They are issues of some concern to me with regard to the Commonwealth's liability.

Senator Alston raised another question which I have also raised with the Department. I have asked the Department why 12 months was chosen as the time someone is unemployed before he or she is required to negotiate a Newstart activity agreement? There is no evidence to show that the choice of 12 months is anything more than an arbitrarily chosen figure. I think it might have been appropriate to look at some pilot studies to see whether the starting of these programs should have been different according to different age groups. Is it better to start earlier with younger people so that they do not learn some of the behaviour which we know can occur with the long term unemployed, especially the young? Is it more appropriate to have different starting times for different age groups? They are the sorts of questions and the sort of flexibility that I would have liked to see in this sort of program.

When the ideas which formed the basis of this Bill were mooted in February 1990, the number of unemployed was such that 12 months was an acceptable cut-off point at which clients would have a reasonable chance of accessing a Government labour market program. But sadly for the unemployed, this Keating-designed `recession that we had to have' means there are now not enough places to enable someone who has been unemployed for 12 months to be confident of obtaining labour market program access. This seems to me to be one of the crucial factors in the implementation of this Bill. I hope that the Government has thought this through adequately. I believe we will see significant problems as that bulge of long term unemployed people comes through. I hope I do not have to say, `I told you so', but I believe I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating cognately the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991. I wish to address briefly some aspects of the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. The thrust of the Bill, the individual provisions, and the criticism that the Australian Democrats have of that particular Bill have been addressed in some detail by Senator Lees who has direct responsibility for this portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise a few questions which are certainly raised by this type of legislation where we are forcing unemployed people to obtain training and where we are forcing people to look for jobs which are not there, at the risk of having their unemployment benefit-their sustenance-withdrawn. The question must be raised: what are these unemployed people being trained for? Will there be any jobs for them once they have undergone training, or is it all just a cruel hoax-a device to get people off the unemployment list and reduce the percentages? Will they be led to believe that if they undergo training they will be okay when the sort of training being provided to them will not enhance their job prospects at all?

It is worth remembering that at present there are 27 unemployed people for every job available. I refer to a press report which appeared in the Australian on 4 May 1991 describing a queue of 5,000 applicants for jobs at the new department store, Daimaru, in Melbourne which invited applicants to present themselves on a Sunday. I think we should note, for instance, that one of those applicants had an honours degree in arts history and an honours degree in museum studies and, yet, had been unemployed for five months and was very keen to find a job as a shop assistant at Daimaru.

There are other examples of that type. An advertisement for a kitchen hand at McDonalds in Elsternwick drew 47 applicants. An advertisement for a machinist drew between 50 and 60 applicants and an advertisement for a storeman driver for Tarantos Ice Cream drew 100 inquiries in the first hour and 45 people were interviewed by telephone. An advertisement for a junior receptionist with Concept Ads drew 150 inquiries. So it goes on. We must ask whether this active employment strategy actually has an aim. Does it end anywhere or does it end in a dead end? After all, we now have close to one million people unemployed, a 30 per cent unemployment rate for young people in the age group of 18 to 21 years-perhaps the greatest crime we are committing at the moment-and 50 per cent unemployment amongst the Aboriginal community.

We need to be careful to assess where we are continuing along this road with the present policy of deregulation and reduction in customs tariffs. Apart from the recession that we had to have-according to the former Treasurer-there are structural reasons for the loss of jobs in many industries and this is being pushed along and accelerated by the Government's policies. So-called reform on tariffs means that tariffs are being reduced even though nations in Europe, in the Americas and Asia are not doing any such thing. They are not opening up their frontiers and delivering their businesses to international markets as we are prepared to do. Why do we not use the reduction in tariffs as a bargaining counter to ensure that the farmers in Europe no longer receive the 40 per cent subsidies that they have enjoyed for so long which make sure that our farmers cannot sell wheat and meat in Europe?

I believe that other problems are raised by this Bill. We have been told by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we must become the clever Australia to be able to compete internationally and to increase our exports and thereby provide jobs at home. Yet, when we look at the state of tertiary education and the facilities that are available for people who are prepared to contribute to our becoming the clever society, we find that thousands of people simply cannot find places and that there is over-enrolment such as we have never had before. The community has risen to respond to the Prime Minister's call, yet the Government is not prepared to provide the necessary infrastructure to ensure that these people can study, obtain qualifications and contribute to the productive endeavours of this nation.

In this connection, we should look at the educational qualifications of our unemployed. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that two out of three unemployed Australians are without any post-school qualifications. These people are most likely to be the long term unemployed. People with trade qualifications make up 8 per cent of the total unemployed and those with degree qualifications 6 per cent. It is time that we engaged in a concerted strategy to enable our people to achieve the sort of educational qualifications which maximise their choices and chances to achieve jobs and to contribute to a productive Australia.

I now turn to a network of organisations which provide effective assistance to our unemployed people. I am referring to the network of welfare rights centres which are engaged at the moment in supplying badly needed support and advice to unemployed people and the sort of lobbying that this Government needs to ensure that unemployed people have some sort of chance as they proceed along their unenviable road.

We find that the welfare rights centres are currently fighting for their own survival. The centre in Melbourne needs $156,000 to pay for an administrator, information officer and researcher and has on-costs of $44,325. The salaries of the three officers are all in the region of $35,000 to $37,000. The centre in Geelong needs a regional service coordinator, a half-time secretary and $22,000 for on-costs, a total of $71,305.

An increasing number of people are relying on social security. The safety net for unemployed people has now been removed or is being removed with the advent of Job Search and Newstart. The law is highly complex and appeal procedures are slow and daunting. Access to information, advice and assistance is restricted by the very same factors which put people in need of social security.

The welfare rights centres are attempting to cater for a demand that is far greater than its capacity and a demand which is increasing every day. The centres are funded through a smorgasbord of State governments, local government, legal aid, charities, foundations and trade union centres. This funding is inconsistent, insecure and diminishing. State governments are increasingly citing the absence of Commonwealth Government funding for welfare rights centres as the reason for the withdrawal of their own funding support. It is time that the Commonwealth Government accepted its responsibilities in these times of rising unemployment and the calamitous state of our employment market to assist people who are in this situation so that they can help themselves.

I now turn to some of the economic measures that the Australian Democrats believe should be taken to ensure that jobs are available. These measures have been placed on the agenda before, but the Government has not reacted with alacrity. I wonder whether the change in Treasurer might have some possible effect on the direction that the Government is prepared to take. I believe that the new Treasurer, Mr Kerin, is a little more amenable to strategic intervention in our economy to ensure that the environmental and social objectives are met. In that sense I would suggest that it is time to call yet again for increased public investment in transport, communications, housing, health, education and research. We all know that in these areas infrastructure is badly lacking and that we have a million people waiting to do productive work. It is up to us and the Government to provide these opportunities.

I also wish to advert briefly to the community work program, which is part of the Australian Democrats' policy in this area. Many jobs cannot be carried out at this point because the funds are simply not available. They are jobs for which the recipients of services could simply not find the funds. This applies to private persons such as pensioners, who would dearly love to have their fences repaired, houses painted and gardens brought into order but simply cannot afford to pay commercial rates. They are not alone. There are local government authorities that would like to have conservation work carried out in their public parks but cannot find sufficient rate revenue to achieve that. The community work program has the chance to fill that gap. The concept is one of offering jobs, through local government administrations, to people who are unemployed to allow them to draw the unemployment benefit and to add an hourly payment which would bring the total amount they receive to an amount equal to the award wage.

This would require some amendments to our social security legislation, but it should not be beyond us. The community development employment program used on Aboriginal communities has required such amendment. It has been an unqualified success, giving people who otherwise would not have employment, the opportunity to earn their own living and to contribute to the well-being of their communities. Unless we do these sort of things and are prepared to think laterally with the aim of achieving a society which is socially just as well as economically robust, our society will not be become a sustainable society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Government has presided since 1983 over a widening gap in income distribution in this country. I refer to a study by Marc Lombard from the Macquarie University School of Economics and Financial Studies, completed just a couple of months ago. The main findings of this study are threefold. Firstly, there has been a marked widening of the income gap between 1983 and 1989. As an example, the top one per cent of income earners earned as much as the bottom 11 per cent in 1982-93 but in 1989 they earned as much as the bottom 21 per cent. So there was a doubling. Secondly, the gap was further increased by the Government's taxation policy through the lowering of marginal, and hence average, tax rates. Thirdly, the female share of the national income, relatively low compared with the male share, had remained almost stationary.

SPEECH.PARA: These findings are worrying, especially when unemployment figures are so high. We know that women and their dependants will usually be the first and worst hit in a recession and the ones who will suffer most from this social security package. In this regard, I commend to other senators the work entitled Common Wealth and Common Good, published by the Catholic Bishop's Committee for Justice, Development and Peace, written by Dr Michael Costigan. This has been a three-year consultative process in the community. It is not yet finalised, but the draft version highlights the need for a more equitable distribution of wealth in this country. There are huge inequities which became worse during the decade of greed in the 1980s. There is a plea for compassion as our community seeks to address the injustices as well as the inequities.

I am particularly concerned about this draconian piece of legislation, which is quite obviously part of the Government's overall approach to labour market deregulation through introducing a work for the dole scheme via the back door. The Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 provides for what is euphemistically being referred to as the active employment strategy. My concern is that basic wages and conditions cannot be maintained within the existing work force once the reserve pool of labour, constituting the unemployed, is forced into the labour market at Government discretion, regardless of skills and training.

The irony of this legislation being introduced at this time is that it was conceived during a period of job growth. It is essentially a program that attempts to train and educate unemployed people to better equip them as job seekers. But Australia is currently experiencing a significant decline in job growth. In March this year 82,400 jobs were lost. This collapse in the job market makes this legislation appear increasingly irrelevant.

The legislation before the Senate will abolish unemployment benefits and replace them with a new system of conditional payments. The Government has attempted to deceive the welfare lobby into believing this change is for the benefit of the unemployed when, in fact, it is not. The new system is punitive and will create added stress and insecurity amongst unemployed people. The new arrangements, known as Job Search and Newstart, are a means of ending the so-called dole by introducing a Job Search allowance (JSA) for the first 12 months and after this period a Newstart allowance. There is, of course, no automatic transition from one allowance to the other. The new programs are designed to involve unemployed people in compulsory labour market programs in return for a strictly conditional payment. These labour market programs are not new. A full range including Jobstart, Skillshare, Jobtrain and Job Clubs have already been available to unemployment beneficiaries for some time. Attendance rates have been high despite the non-compulsory nature of the programs.

The whole idea of this legislation is to provide less scope for social security and Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) officers to exercise compassion in dealing with individual cases, and more scope for penalising unemployed people through the new contract arrangements known as activity tests, set to ascertain a person's so-called attitude to job seeking and training. To introduce such a punitive system during a time of record unemployment levels at more than 10 per cent, but with the generally accepted figure of at least 12 per cent as the hidden rate revealed by CES figures, is unjust. It is also ironic that while the Government fought for many months to reject the use of the dreaded `R' word for recession, its own ranks, including Senator Peter Walsh, are now calling the severe economic decline a depression.

The bottom line is that the jobs people will be trained for are simply not available. People should be trained for unemployment and be involved in appropriate community-based work, not employment that does not exist, which will just further add to the loss of self-esteem and an increase in the poverty cycle. This legislation compels people to enter programs proposed by the CES with little input of their own or freedom of choice, limited appeal rights should they dispute the suitability of the CES proposals and, ultimately, the termination of their income should they refuse to comply or fail to come to an agreement with the local CES office.

As Senator Patterson has pointed out, many of the people in the CES offices will hardly be experts in dealing with these very sensitive matters as they arise on a daily basis in the offices right around the country. It is this element of compulsion that concerns the Greens because the current system generally is working and is not, as the Government has implied, a passive system. The current system of unemployment benefit payments requires that beneficiaries must be actively looking for work and be available to undertake suitable employment when it is offered to them. In practice, the work test is used to terminate benefits-that is, where a person fails to turn up for an interview or refuses to accept employment offered by the CES. Contrary to the media and other propaganda, the system of payment of unemployment benefits is not widely abused; it is highly focused and rigorously enforced.

The other draconian aspect of the active employment strategy is that the programs that are recommended do not involve any direct response to what the community wants or what an unemployed person would like to do. For example, there is no flexibility in the training system and there is no allowance for community-based enterprises such as tree plantings or involvement in programs reversing land degradation in rural areas. The Labor machine will have to reject the old economic model which saw full employment as achievable and will have to work towards greener and more democratic models. But at the moment we see people being trained for unskilled labour such as bar work or mechanics training, even though jobs in these areas, and in particular the trades, are simply not available. Therefore, the compulsion aspect concerns me, as does the irrelevant nature of the labour market training initiatives.

People would be better off moving into the non-money market, as is happening under the local employment trading scheme, whereby people exchange goods and services in their own communities, keep a balance sheet in LETS units and remove their community work from the traditional money market. This scheme is great for building a sense of community and will thrive as unemployment worsens, but it throws the Australian Taxation Office into a spin because earnings are not in dollars and are therefore not recorded.

This legislation at a time of rising unemployment in order to coerce unemployed people to participate in a social engineering experiment should not be passed. The repercussions will include much higher levels of stress amongst unemployed people, higher crime rates as a result of large numbers of people being deprived of income support and more homeless and destitute people living off the streets-as if we have not had enough examples of so many thousands of young people in Australia already in that very sad situation.

Green policies are directed towards reducing the existing inequalities in income and in the ownership of wealth and resources. Such policies seek to reduce the stigma attached to the receipt of social security benefits and to keep benefits in line with the consumer price index so that all citizens are guaranteed a minimum income if they become unemployed. This is a basic right in all societies that should never be challenged. Instead, we are being presented with a so-called active employment strategy which represents a punitive approach threatening the notion that citizenship confers a right to an adequate income to fulfil basic needs. As the Brotherhood of St Laurence says:

Adequate income security . . . is a recognition of the fact that inability to obtain work is a function of economic, social and political forces in a changing society and is not the fault of the individual.
Other speakers in the debate have testified to this already. I would say that it especially applies in our community so far as young people and Aboriginal people are concerned.

The concept of adequate income security is a right in the event of unemployment and one which is recognised by the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. This new employment strategy is completely one-sided and is based on contractual arrangements between the unemployed and the Government with no reciprocal commitments from the Government which can cut people off benefits at any time if it is found that their attitude is inappropriate. This whole legislative package smacks of an Orwellian nightmare in which the thought police are actively trying to ascertain a person's frame of mind and ongoing loyalty to the state machine.

The new program means that unemployed people will be, as I have previously stated, separated into two classes. Those who have been unemployed for less than a year will go into Job Search; and those who have been unemployed for more than a year will be deemed to require special supervision by CES officers under Newstart. People who have already been unemployed for more than a year as at 1 July 1991 will go straight into Newstart. Others will begin on Job Search and be progressively transferred to Newstart as they reach 12 months unemployment. To go back to day one, a person leaving Job Search to take up employment has to stay in work for at least six weeks. Similarly, people leaving Newstart have to be employed for at least 13 weeks before they can return to the beginning of the Job Search program. Obviously, there are going to be some gaps between those programs. What do people do for an income in those gap periods?

Each Newstart applicant will be required to enter into a special contract with the CES called a Newstart activity agreement in which they will promise to adopt and maintain correct attitudes in order to keep themselves permanently in an employment-ready state. These attitudes will be taught and refined in special training courses. Non-compliance will be detected through the application of an activity test which will have statutory punishment for failure in the form of deferment of support payments. JSA recipients will also have to attend at least two compulsory interviews with the CES and the Department of Social Security (DSS). Ten per cent of Jobstart recipients will also be required to attend an intensive interview with DSS after three months and further interviews may also be required with the CES.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition, the whole new strategy does not involve the creation of any new labour market programs. It relies on an increase in the number of places available under existing schemes when the Department of Employment, Education and Training is already stretched to the limit in terms of its internal budget and the pressures on its personnel. Apart from being quite malicious in some of the wording, this legislation is, as I have mentioned, an extension of the Hawke Government's obsession with labour market deregulation, which sees an end to the central wage fixing system and the introduction of arrangements that are negotiated on a personalised basis between employers and individual employees.

SPEECH.PARA: The push for a deregulated market economy relies on exploitation of the reserve pool of labour to lower wages and to increase profits for the employers and government. In this new deregulated environment, workers will be encouraged to underbid each other for wages in return for the few jobs that are available. The whole notion of pushing Australian wages down to make the country more competitive with newly industrialised nations in the Pacific Rim and using the unemployed as coolie labour is anathema to the basic rights of the worker. Without years of media bashing and scapegoating by employer lobby groups of the unemployed, this legislation would never have been acceptable to the Australian public or to its representatives in this place. People are being actively conditioned into believing the stereotype of the dole bludger. Of course, that has been going on for a number of years.

I must point out that all Australians have a right to a minimum standard of provision of income in order to meet their basic needs. If this cannot be provided through the labour market, it should be provided by the state as a matter of right and should not be contingent on people meeting such harsh eligibility criteria or having to prove their moral worth. While not condoning the abuse of the social security system, the Greens maintain that much of this abuse is the result of inadequate levels of benefit, which leave people with no effective alternative but to cheat the system, especially if they wish to keep pace with the expectations of our consumer oriented society, which of course I question.

Unemployment is a harsh reality for hundreds of thousands of Australian families right now through no fault of their own. However, it will be a time not only for those without adequate income but also for all of us to re-evaluate the quality of our lifestyles. All of us need to get off the consumerist bandwagon. However, to make it difficult for people without jobs to get access to a guaranteed minimum income is cruel; it is unnecessary and it is totally unacceptable in this relatively affluent society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say, and I am sure that the Senate will be pleased to hear it, that I will not be taking up much time this evening on this legislation. Senator Lees has already given the point of view of the Australian Democrats on the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991. I just want to add a little in relation to New South Wales and, in particular, my portfolio area of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Newstart proposal requires that the unemployed accept training; however, many unemployed have already tried to get training. They have tried to enrol in universities or technical and further education colleges only to be turned away. Courses are oversubscribed, in spite of the higher education contribution scheme. In 1990, in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, there was unmet demand for places in higher education of 3,700 to 5,400. The figures for this year are in the range of 4,700 to 6,900. Obviously, we are not in a position to supply education and training for all those who are eligible and keen.

This Government is forcing many people, who have not been able to study the course of their choice due to lack of places and who are unable to get work because there are no jobs, to take short term courses chosen by a Commonwealth Employment Service officer which gives successful students no formal qualifications and which may, indeed, be in areas where the individual already has skills. Worthwhile Skillshare courses are already oversubscribed and, even with the planned additional places, the courses will be in high demand if they meet people's needs. So why not provide sufficient places in all educational institutions now to enable people to select a relevant course without the Government resorting to standover tactics, backed up by the threat of having their bare bones survival income taken away? Will there be any jobs for the job searchers or the new starters once they have emerged from their courses?

A ring-around in Sydney last weekend showed that there are many more applicants than there are jobs. A job advertisement for a bar waiter or waitress produced 160 applicants; for a storeman and driver, 90 applicants; for a receptionist-typist, 200 applicants. A job advertisement for a machinist resulted in 50 inquiries. Even a job requiring trade qualifications, a carpenter-joiner, produced 40 applicants. The New South Wales Teachers Federation has 15,000 to 20,000 teachers listed as unemployed or underemployed. They are trained but there are no jobs for them. Presumably, their only option is to take jobs for which they are not trained and for which they are probably overqualified. Many teachers will succeed in getting one of those jobs but, in doing so, will ensure that someone else is on the unemployment benefit.

As we weather this recession, an increasing number of people will have to rely on social security for their income. They are victims. The vast majority are not responsible for their lack of employment. They have no control over government economic decisions. They want a regular paid position. The Democrats are particularly worried about the access which those people have to housing, which accounts for a large part of any person's income. We are seeing an increasing number of people on the streets month after month. The active employment strategy may have a lot to answer for in this respect. Any person who lacks, for whatever reason, the resilience and the inner fortitude to run the Job Search-Newstart obstacle race is likely to go downhill very quickly with homelessness waiting at the bottom of the down slide.

What will happen to the families of all those who fall through the net, the families of those who do not have the language skills to negotiate and understand all the paperwork? Already these people are having benefits cut off and are being forced to rely on welfare support. These problems can only increase with Newstart. The United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, to which Australia is a signatory, states in article 25 that everyone has the right to an adequate standard of living.

In fact, the deterioration of economic circumstances is creating an immense problem in the housing area, with a greater number of people now being unable to afford any sort of housing at all. This is especially true in Sydney which has the highest housing costs of all major cities and where the levels of poverty are probably higher than in other parts of Australia once housing costs have been paid. Despite these problems, the Federal Government has refused to allocate any additional funds to providing new services for homeless people. Indeed, under this Government there has been a declining emphasis on essential programs.

For instance, in last year's budget submission to the Federal Government, the Australian Council of Housing Societies drew attention to the fact that the housing situation among low income earners, including the unemployed, was getting progressively worse. The Council suggested that with the deterioration in our economic circumstances and increasing unemployment, the homelessness issue among Australia's low income groups, including the unemployed, was set to deteriorate. This is especially the case among Australia's homeless youth. This is despite the recommendations of the Burdekin report, which highlighted the appalling situation now facing Australia's homeless youth in our cities, suburbs and country areas.

Even though the homelessness issue has been getting progressively worse with this recession, the Government continues to cut back funding to essential housing programs. Such government programs are now often the only remaining option for low income groups struggling in the housing market today. Continued government funding cutbacks in the housing area will effectively destroy the Government's social justice strategy. Let us hope that the 1991-92 Budget will contain some measures aimed at assisting the housing problems of our lowest income earners. It is certainly disappointing that in past years the Commonwealth has effectively reduced its funding to housing in real terms when delivering the Budget.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquiry into homeless young people received much evidence that amongst Australia's young people homelessness is a large and growing problem. These problems have clearly worsened under the current recession and it is necessary for the Government to meet the responsibilities as a matter of urgency. Some low income groups, and in particular the young unemployed, are being forced into inadequate and inappropriate forms of housing. Consequently, these new social security packages of Newstart and Job Search will fail to achieve their goals because problems, such as the housing crisis and youth homelessness, will have an immediate counter effect on any positive outcome which these new unemployment packages are intended to create.

The social problems created by the housing crisis and youth homeless are immense. Yet, the staff of the Department of Social Security have been allocated three hours per year to counsel their clients. Obviously, that is an insufficient amount of time and agencies, such as the welfare rights centres, will find themselves in even more demand. Payments are now tightly targeted, yet many who are eligible do not receive their entitlements. The law is highly complex, while appeal procedures are slow and daunting. Access to information, advice and assistance are restricted by the same factors that put people in need of social security.

Welfare rights centres are attempting to cater for a demand for information and assistance far beyond their capacity, and it is on the increase. The centres are funded from a mixture of State government, local government, legal aid, charities, foundations and trade union sources. The funding is inconsistent, insecure and diminishing. State governments are increasingly citing the absence of Commonwealth government funding for welfare rights centres as a reason for their withdrawal of funding support. Without Commonwealth support, even the limited network of welfare rights centres will contract and disappear over the next two years. The network of welfare rights centres is seeking the immediate establishment by the Commonwealth Government of a national welfare rights advocacy funding program, which would be a significant and tangible contribution to social justice. In the current economic climate that is desperately needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation before us, the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991, is a symptom of a great deal of what is wrong with this Government and, indeed, of what would be wrong with the Opposition, if it were in government, because their policies are not all that dissimilar. What it indicates is that the Government is totally misreading the portents of history. Increasingly, it is attempting to design solutions for yesterday's problems and it is not considering where society is going and where it needs to go and designing the sorts of employment options, educational facilities and technologies that would fit a society moving towards the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early 1980s, Barry Jones wrote a book, Sleepers, Wake!, in which he pointed out that if the technologies for automated production of goods and services then available were applied-and of course this relates to a social decision which should have been made but which has never been properly faced-all the goods and services then made could have been produced with only some six to 10 per cent of the population working, with some 90 to 94 per cent of the population technically unemployed. Some honourable senators would recall that when the Hawke Government first came to office in 1983, one of the first things that Mr Hawke did was to call a national economic summit. The message in Sleepers, Wake! was to be put to the summit by Barry Jones, but the Prime Minister made a deliberate decision to exclude Barry Jones from the national economic summit, on the grounds that the people who were hand-picked and invited to that summit might be disturbed by the sort of message that Barry Jones would have to tell them.

That backward looking, instead of forward looking, approach of the Government has continued ever since. The Government is inventing solutions to yesterday's problems rather than considering the future direction in which we should move. Consider for a moment comparing the economy to a pipe-and this is a good analogy because the economy is currently measured through gross national product or gross domestic product-to a measure of the flow of goods and services through the economy. One observes that what goes into that pipe at one end is resources and human labour and what comes out at the other end is pollution. The Government-and indeed, the Opposition would attempt to do the same if it were in government-has endlessly increased the flow through that pipe, using up more and more resources and more and more human labour on the input side while producing more and more pollution on the output side.

Clearly, that makes very little sense. Moreover, it is neither sustainable nor consistent with the Government's stated aim of designing a sustainable economy. If one considers the economics of an individual householder, that householder does not attempt to increase the amount of money and human labour required to maintain the house. Quite sensibly, an attempt is made to decrease the amount of money and the amount of labour necessary to maintain the house. Similarly, with the national economy, there is no sense in endlessly attempting to increase the use of resources and human labour. In that sense, to attempt to create work simply for its own sake is quite ridiculous.
