In a productive economy such as we have in Australia at present, the task is not simply to create work, when work is narrowly defined as that for which one gets paid. The task of society is to employ people in creative activities in which they can feel socially useful. I believe that the majority of people wish to feel socially useful. There are very few people in our society who are really bludgers in the true sense of the word, who want to sponge on the rest of society. Most people want to feel socially useful. There is a whole variety of ways in which they can do that beyond that which is normally accepted today as work. One of the requirements that need to be put in place, if we really are to be forward looking rather than backward looking, is to redefine the nature of work.

Of course, none of this is to be found in the legislation presently before us. If we were to redefine the nature of work, we might discover that much of what is now done in the community, in the way of voluntary and unpaid work-and I use the word advisedly-indeed comprises the main part of economic activity but remains unmeasured because it is work for which no payment is made. I refer to work predominantly carried out by women in the home as wives, in the way of child rearing, and also the work of many, many people in voluntary organisations. Without this work the economy of this country would simply grind to a halt. Because it is not paid for, it remains unmeasured and absolutely silent within the economy.

The Democrats, in looking forward, would far prefer to recognise that, in a very productive economy, such as we have at present, the task is to more equitably share out the goods and services that that productive economy makes available. The old-fashioned way of doing that is to make people work-and I use the word now in a narrow sense-for payment, and it does not matter how destructively they work or how useless the work is, work is invented, they are paid for it and are considered to be legitimately participating in the economy. However, that is a ridiculous way to go.

The ultimate vision of the Democrats is to have what we would call a national support income, an amount of money that everyone in the community, every Australian citizen, as of right, would be paid. It would be a minimum amount but one on which a person could build by way of paid employment. It would be paid to individuals rather than to families, so that people who chose to stay at home and work in the home and people who chose to do voluntary work would be able to do that also. It would be free of means testing, of course, and free of the poverty traps which would lie just beyond the limit of the national support income. This would remove the vast bureaucracy. With the legislation before us one can anticipate an absolutely Hitlerian bureaucracy to supervise the means tests that are built into it. We would prefer to see a scheme free of means testing and free of the vast bureaucracy necessary to supervise those means tests, a scheme which would lead people to contribute towards our society in ways that they choose for themselves-in other words, it would be a much freer society.

The scheme which is before us, basically, is one which blames the victim. It absolves the Government entirely from responsibility for creating this iniquitous system-this system which means that people can quite literally starve before they become eligible for support. It victimises them further if they infringe the system in any way, often in ways which are to be quite arbitrarily determined by this Hitlerian bureaucracy. It does nothing at all to direct the Government's attention to the fact that it has created the economy. It is the Government which has said that we must have a recession. It is the Government that has created the conditions in which, necessarily, large numbers of people become unemployed and unable to support themselves. Yet we do not find anything in this legislation or elsewhere which recognises this. This is legislation which is victim blaming of the very worst kind.

We find also that the Government is maintaining, at these times of high unemployment, the importation of the skills component of the migration program. This has allowed, since 1947, the running down of educational programs in this country, the lack of proper training of individuals in this country and the substitution of Australian trained people with migrants. This migration program, since its inception, has been justified partly on the grounds of providing skills which are not available in Australia.

If, since 1947, we are still not providing the skilled people necessary in this country, that says something about the sorts of educational and training schemes which successive governments have simply failed to provide. It is about time that we stopped using that excuse, that we stopped the skills migration program and that we began properly training people and properly building the education programs which would, indeed, be the pathway to a clever country.

As other Democrats have indicated, we are really quite disgusted with this piece of legislation. It is not in any way addressing the twenty-first century problems that we should be looking to. It is not going to build a more just and fairer society. It is not, of itself, going to produce the skills which are necessary for tomorrow. There is nothing in this. It is based on an economic model which is backward looking. The Government and the Opposition still look back to Adam Smith and market forces and the laissez faire market driven mechanism.

It has been very instructive in recent days to hear spokesperson after spokesperson from the Government and the Opposition and, indeed, economic journalists saying, `When the economy recovers we must be positioned so that we can take advantage of that recovery', as though the economy was some disembodied instrument out there, totally out of control and totally not a creature of the creation of this Government. That is the extent to which the Government has deregulated, simply left the economy to market forces and absolved itself entirely of the responsibility for the iniquitous situation in which we now find ourselves.

There are many aspects which our spokesperson on this legislation will address in the committee stage, with quite a large number of amendments. These really deal with the detail, attempting to rescue some modicum of fairness and justice from a basically deeply flawed piece of legislation. I simply conclude by saying that if one had the chance one would scrap this legislation and write a totally different type of Bill altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped that during the second reading debate on the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991 we might have been somewhat enlightened as to what the Opposition was going to announce as its policy on what it would like to do-I was going to say for the unemployed, perhaps I should say to the unemployed. I am afraid that there was absolutely no idea, again, as to what the Opposition is prepared to do. It is difficult to comment on the speech that Senator Alston made.
—Are you marking time or looking for ideas from the Opposition? What is the purpose of this little exercise? Are you waiting for amendments?

—There is no purpose in that. We will not be taking the amendments. There is an agreement with the Opposition-and Senator Newman would not know this because she is always behind on these things-that we will be going into the committee stage on these Bills tomorrow. So, no, I am not waiting for that. Why does not Senator Newman listen? It would do her a bit of good.

SPEECH.PARA: Having listened to Senator Alston, as I was saying, it is quite difficult to answer a speech which totally avoided any of the issues so I think I can ignore it. But if one looks through the Opposition's speeches in general, again, there is little of any alternative to what the Government is putting. That makes any reply difficult.

As far as Senator Patterson's contribution is concerned, there are two things to say. Firstly, I know that she asked a question some time ago in a committee about a legal opinion from the Government. I have received agreement from the Attorney-General's Department for that opinion to be made available to her on a confidential basis. Obviously, we do not publish legal opinions, but we will be contacting Senator Patterson and making that available to her on a confidential basis.

Secondly, she raised some questions which I think really relate to the way that Newstart has worked. One would have to say that the measures in the existing Newstart strategy have proved pretty effective. We have been pleased with them and, until the recession was biting deeply, there had been a big reduction in the number of long term unemployed. What is more, even in the recession, if one looks at the percentages one can still say that that scheme has had its effect in at least trying to minimise the number of long term unemployed as a proportion of total unemployment.

I am more concerned with the contributions of the Australian Democrats because at least I respect the position from which they were coming, I might say, not the position to which they got, but the one from which they were coming which was, I think, worthy of some discussion.

Senator Lees said quite a few times, as have a number of her colleagues, that they do not basically believe in any scheme of this kind, anyway. I understand some of their worries but, while it is all right for Senator Alston to say that he does not want anyone put on a bureaucratic training roundabout, as he put it, the truth is that Australia's future will very much depend on the skills of its work force. If Australia is to waste an occasion such as this, when so many who are unemployed could be trained and their skills improved not just so that they can be the first to take advantage of the upturn when it comes but also so that the skills of the work force at large are improved, Australia would be missing a golden opportunity. That is certainly not what the Government would have in mind.

A number of the points that Senator Lees raised were covered in a number of meetings that we had with the Australian Council of Social Service and like groups. Senator Vallentine referred in detail to work for the dole. Perhaps some other senators did; I did not hear every speech in the debate. The Government has never believed and does not believe that this Bill allows work for the dole. So that there can be no doubt, so that no unemployed person in Australia would have to be concerned about this, we will be moving an amendment to make it clear, even to the most obtuse among the Opposition let alone any other grouping in the Parliament but mainly to make it clear to the Australian people, that as a government we would never support such a measure.

This issue has been raised by a number of Democrats but, basically, it is scaremongering. There will be no work for the dole under this Government. Dr Hewson did suggest that the Opposition would have some, and another issue was visited by him. Senator Alston's response was to try to limit this and say, `No, we will only do it for the over 55s', which is even worse than Dr Hewson's contribution but I am sure that, too, will be dropped before too long. I can assure the Democrats and any of those interested groups in the community who have made representations on the issue that we will not accept it anyway.

There has been quite a bit of discussion, not so much here tonight but before tonight and referred to by Senator Lees, about the use of the word `reasonable' here and there in the Act. Over the years the word `reasonable' has been introduced into the Act somewhat sporadically and certainly not systematically. It is a matter of concern to me that if we were to add it to this legislation we would be doing no-one any good. Obviously as a principle of administrative law the Government has to be reasonable. Given that this is the Hawke Government, it has always been reasonable.

We will have to ensure that in the administration of the Act we continue to apply those principles which we have been applying all along. Governments are held to account on their reasonableness and that will not go away. It would change absolutely nothing to put `reasonable' into the Act and simply add further to inconsistency. Either we put in every single clause right through legislation such as this that a government should act reasonably or we cut it out. I would be opting for cutting them all out and relying on that general principle of administrative law.

The line taken by the Democrats and by some in the Opposition that the Newstart program is not appropriate for today's labour market also misses the entire point of the Newstart program. It is not going to be the case that a person who undergoes a training scheme, comes out of that training scheme with his or her skills improved and then finds it impossible to find a job, will suddenly be cut off.

There will be tremendous flexibility in the preparation of the agreements about which we will be sitting down to talk to individuals to enable us to administer this program with all justice, or perhaps it is better to say `justness' to which Senator Coulter referred towards the end of his speech. As is so often the case, it will depend upon the way the departments administer it rather than the words of the Bill because many of these things finish up in administrative arrangements.

I can assure Senator Coulter and Senator Lees that the Government, in the preparation of the agreements that we are talking about, will allow for plenty of flexibility, such as the flexibility that would permit those Aboriginal groups to whom Senator Tambling referred to suffer no injustice and to be placed under no added pressure and the flexibility which would enable those who live in some regional areas that are particularly depressed, and where there are not too many employers, not to knock on the same three doors every week to show that they had been looking for work. Given the flexibility that will exist in the system, we ought to acknowledge that this is a long term strategy, not a short term fix. It is not meant to fix the recession; rather it is meant to address the long term difficulties in improving the skills of the Australian work force, and we will certainly continue to do that.

I share the concerns that Senator Bell expressed. We have to look more broadly, when talking about improving skills and training, than just at universities and technical and further education colleges. Most of the people affected by this program will not be going to those kinds of institutions. There are many ways that skills can be improved without going to universities. I would hope that all honourable senators would understand that. In any event, the industry statement released by the Government earlier this year went a long way in announcing extra places and how much we might do.

One point raised by Senator Tambling that is also worthy of mention is the question of literacy and numeracy skills. The Government must have a strategy for very early intervention where these deficiencies are discovered. All honourable senators would be aware that many people will go to great lengths to avoid revealing that very deficiency because it is a matter of sometimes considerable personal embarrassment to people that they do not have literacy or numeracy skills. The difficulty we then face is in making real contact with them so that they can explain the extent of the problem and how the Department might be able to give them some advice on how to sort out the problem. Already the Government has announced some considerable funds for that intervention program. I would not pretend that we have done all that we need to do yet. It is a matter that we ought to be looking at further during the course of Budget discussions.

For many workers it is the lack of a literacy skill that prevents them from getting jobs and it is the skill training that they need. I acknowledge that that needs to be done. I do not need to say anything more about Senator Patterson's contribution. I did say something before she came into the chamber. I am not sure whether she heard it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very good contribution.

—I would not go quite that far, as a matter of fact; nonetheless, I do not think I need to. In respect of Senator Spindler's contribution, I do not think that the kind of community work program that he has in mind will do very much to produce better skills for the long term unemployed. I also suggest that the cost of such a scheme would far outweigh the benefits. That is perhaps one suggestion that I will not be taking up. That just about covers the contributions of all those in the debate except for that of Senator Walters, and I will not waste too much time covering hers. In summary, this legislation provides the first real guarantees that those unfortunate enough to be unemployed will have a real opportunity for meaningful training and hopefully for better and more secure futures.

—I will be brief. There have been 14 speakers in a period of three hours. That is almost a record. I was on the list to speak. I thought it would be reasonable for me to be back from my meeting on the House of Representatives side at about 11 o'clock, which I was, and I was quite surprised to see that everybody had spoken. I regret not having spoken in this debate, but I will take the opportunity in the committee stage to be relevant in my speech.

There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question is that the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 be read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills now before the Senate is a very important combination of Bills aimed at reforming the telecommunications environment in Australia. The Opposition, as we have already made plain in the other chamber, supports the competition Bill but opposes the merger Bill. I believe that the competition Bill-if I can describe it as that-although a step forward, is not quite what it seems. It depends critically upon the Australian Telecommunications Authority-Austel. In many respects we have serious concerns about the guaranteed independence of Austel. In the United Kingdom, for example, Oftel, its counterpart regulator, is directly accountable to the Parliament; whereas in Australia Austel is very much the creature of the Minister, an arm of government and very susceptible to ministerial direction. One of the Bills contained in the package provides for an additional amount of funding, of the order of $4.5m, for Austel, but it remains to be seen whether that will be in any way sufficient to ensure that the regulator is able not only to keep a watchful eye on the dominant carrier but also to ensure fair play between the dominant carrier and the new entrant in terms of basic carrier services.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is playing for very high stakes in this area. It is quite clear that massive amounts of money will be required to be put up-front by a new entrant, and perhaps that is one of the reasons why the field has already narrowed to two effective consortia. That, I think, in large part reflects the widespread perception, both domestically and abroad, that the restructuring contained in the merger Bill is fundamentally flawed, is driven by the politics of playing to the telecommunications unions and, in this respect-and perhaps in very few others-I would have to say that Mr Keating got it right. The only trouble was he was rolled where it counted; that is, in Cabinet. The dominant players in that game were much more concerned about pandering to the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association and other bodies which were scared stiff about privatisation and the effect that it would have on the unionisation of a private sector work force, and which were not at all concerned to ensure that we have full and dynamic competition, as is the case in the rest of the world.

I do not need to stress the fact that to date we have given the rest of the Western world some seven years start. Not only the United States, the United Kingdom and Japan but also many other Western countries are now coming to realise the real virtues of competition in terms of efficiency of service, quality of service and price. Yet what we have here is a government that had every opportunity to learn from those international experiences but instead chose to put a politically flawed deal on the table and then tried to justify it in the marketplace. That is why there is a great deal of nervousness about a new entrant having to fork out something of the order of $3.5 billion over the next seven years to achieve an effective role out of a second network.

We remain to be convinced that there is any guarantee that the new entrant will achieve 25 per cent of the market. Certainly the comparable experiences in Japan and the United Kingdom suggest that the dominant carrier is likely to have well in excess of 90 per cent after a five-year period. Although I think it is fair to say that both of the two major contenders have very deep pockets and, no doubt, are praying for a change of government so that they will be able to get their shows on the road without being hostage to politically motivated changes, nonetheless they know that they are playing for very high stakes and are critically dependent upon the effectiveness of the regulator to guarantee fair interconnect and to ensure that the pricing regime is one that does not disadvantage them too greatly.

On the other hand, of course, we have the mammoth monopolist, which has for so many years been able to shelter cosily behind a statute that has given it all and more than any monopolist could dream of, suddenly crying poor. Despite the fact that it made a profit last year of about $1.3 billion and is set to return the same sort of figure this year, it is still crying that it needs another $300m. It has been to the Government and pleaded for more assistance on its balance sheet. It is clearly aware that it is going to be operating with one hand behind its back because it will not be able to get out into the marketplace and raise funds. Yet we have this preposterous proposal for a $1 billion merger fee, which I had hoped the Democrats realised would cripple Telecom Australia; but I am not so sure, from their amendment, that they appreciate that they will simply be allowing the Minister to go right ahead and set that same figure. If I am not right, I am delighted to be corrected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you.

—Maybe we have misread their amendment. I will revisit it overnight. I hope, as we had previously anticipated, that they share our view that this is yet another flawed way of raising funds on the part of the Government. It has nothing to do with trying to ensure reasonable competition between the carriers and it is punishing Telecom quite unnecessarily for being a victim of the political deal that, unfortunately, Senator Richardson and his colleague the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) were not able to deliver when the matter was before Cabinet. As a result of that, we regard the merger proposals as not only a subject of suspicion but also doomed to failure. We would hope to be in a position not only to privatise but also to open up the market in such a way that we would not be stuck with this unholy combination.

SPEECH.PARA: The duopoly that is intended to prevail until 1997 will be unravelled once we come to government-upon proper notice. We certainly will not accept any obligation to pay compensation. We reject as quite abhorrent the crude attempt on the part of the Government, as contained in clause 70, to allow the Minister to enter into a secret agreement with a second carrier whereby any amount could be provided by way of penalty, quite unrelated to any damages that might flow from the premature, in its eyes, exposure to the marketplace and yet find that the Government is liable to pay perhaps a billion dollar penalty fee.

That is preposterous nonsense and we would not regard ourselves as being bound by that. Nor should the Government be able to keep a straight face when pretending to the market place that that is a fair arrangement. One would have thought at the very least that any such agreement would have to be tabled and would have to be made public, but there is no such obligation. I treat the mere fact that the Government has had the temerity to propose that in the clause as being indicative of its lack of bona fides in the area.

Another major matter of concern in relation to unbundling is the ability of Austel to direct carriers to supply services to the public generally if Austel is satisfied about a number of matters. One of those matters is that the carriers' compliance with the direction will not unduly affect the practical ability of the carriers to be the primary suppliers of telecommunications services in Australia. Once again, the opportunities for special pleading are limitless. One can well imagine that it would not be a very difficult task for Telecom to be able to demonstrate on a plausible basis that somehow the practical ability of the carriers to be primary suppliers of telecommunications was jeopardised.

We used to get the same sort of arguments about community service obligations. Any attempt at all to require Telecom to bear any additional burdens was met with the contention that somehow this would be the end of the dominant carrier as we knew it. I would have thought that at the very least, the powers should be limited to a situation where it would be necessary for the carrier itself to demonstrate that any such changes would prejudice the effective and efficient delivery of telecommunications services.

There are also additional concerns about the ability of the dominant carrier to set a price regime for itself and its competitor which was different from those prices that would be prevailing for retailers or third parties. This is particularly so in relation to Telecom's ability to offer lower pricing regimes for such products as packet switch services and leased lines which it could easily do for its Auspac service and then to charge other retailers such as Australian Associated Press a higher price for an additional service on the basis that the basic carrier service was the final product.

We regard that as being pregnant with dangers because it raises the possibility that while the Bills contain lip service to the concept of full reach sale capacity, the practical effect may well be that down the line we will find that 90 per cent of the market for telecommunications services will have been effectively reserved to the carriers and that resellers and value added service providers will be simply marginalised and, given the lead time that will be available, they will find it very difficult to get into the game. So we have great concerns on that score as well.

This is part of the hidden agenda that is built into the 20-plus discretions which are available to the Minister and which have the capacity to nobble almost any competitive scheme if the Minister were so minded. Therefore, of course, there will be an enormous burden on Austel to ensure not only that there is a level playing field but also that there is a regime in place which allows each of the carriers to provide services on a fair and reasonable basis.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) continues to shirk another basic issue, that is, whether a third mobile licence will be granted. Given the fact that by the year 2000, something like 70 per cent of all telephone calls will have a mobile component, one would have expected that this critical decision would have been made well before now. Again, that is probably typical of the way in which this Government has managed to duck the hard decisions. It seems to be more absorbed with the politics of the issue. This is certainly not what consumers want.

Given the fact that the rest of the world has had about a seven-year lead time already, one would have thought that the time for full competition for mobile communications had well and truly arrived. But of course one has to remember that even back in 1980, we were talking seriously about pay television being introduced into this country. We can probably say that it is as far away as ever, not for any logical or technical reason, but simply because of the politics of the issue. That is what disturbs those who have to deal in this dynamic area, one where not only are the growth rates predicted to be higher than almost any other sector of manufacturing or services, but also one where there are enormous export opportunities for Australia if we get it right.

Telecommunications is currently a $10 billion to $12 billion industry in Australia. Telecom's asset base is something of the order of $15 billion. It is looking at another profit in excess of $1 billion. I have always thought that it had the unique ability to understate its profit and to pitch it at the politically optimum level. It does have very considerable demands for infrastructure and capital outlays, but the fact remains that if we did have truly competitive carriers in this market, if they were not hamstrung by the Government and by the constant shadow of political intervention, they would be able to make a much more significant contribution to our export services' bottom line.

We do have very significant concerns about the merger. It has been flawed since the outset. It is not going to contribute one iota to having a proper regime in place. It must have been patently obvious to every member of the Cabinet that OTC Ltd, which has had a very impressive record, not only in terms of service provision, but also in terms of efficiency and rate of return, was the obvious competitor to Telecom. Around those two organisations one could have built both a second international and a second domestic carrier. That was a regime that was crying out to be implemented. All those in Cabinet know that the only reason that did not come about was because of the prevalence of political jockeying.

As a result, we do not have an optimum regime. It will be very difficult to restore or achieve that in the short term, but I am confident that, when we have the opportunity to do so, we will unravel much of this unholy collusion that is going on at present. I feel very sorry indeed for those in OTC who I think have always prided themselves on their ability to prosper in the international environment, who were prepared to welcome the competition with open arms. Now we find that they are forced into a backdoor merger with Telecom, which does not have a competitive culture, which despite Austel's pro-competitive charter is going to be a most unwilling partner in most of these enterprises.

Some time ago I noted comments by an American import about the number of jobs that might be lost, particularly in the country division of Telecom, but nothing much has changed in recent times to have suddenly brought that enlightenment about. The fact is that Telecom has always had the capacity to dramatically reduce its work force. In terms of lines per employee, it has a very poor international record. It would have been a very simple matter to have achieved the sorts of redundancies and staff reductions that Telecom achieved in New Zealand, not to the disadvantage of thousands of technicians and others who have managed to achieve one of the greatest featherbeddings in history because most of those people who have been given unlimited opportunities in the private sector to become very real competitors, to have broken the first phone monopoly, to have been prepared to start repairing phones at weekends, to have reduced the waiting time from weeks to perhaps hours and to have started to turn the industry around. Unfortunately, it is business as usual and, as a result, we find that Telecom is going to be dragged screaming and yelling into the twenty-first century. The merger Bill is one that we cannot wear, particularly in regard to the merger fee. I am hopeful that the indications from Senator Kernot tonight bear fruit in the morning.

As far as the competition Bill is concerned, I think I have already indicated that we have some very serious concerns about the way in which competition will come about. But, at the very most, one can say that there are some positive aspects which have been welcomed by industry, and to that extent I think we are prepared to give the Government the benefit of the doubt in that area. But there will be a need for a very flexible regulatory regime to enable the carriers to take part in, hopefully, the exponential growth that is available in a fully competitive market. I, therefore, move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government's failure to allow reasonable time for consideration of the measure; and
(b) condemns the Government for choosing structural arrangements in telecommunications which do not satisfy the requirements for full micro-economic reform, noting that the bill:
(i) lacks clarity in important areas;
(ii) leaves significant detail for determination by regulations; and
(iii) fails to provide for a sufficient degree of independence from Government for Austel;

all of which factors have the potential to compromise further the development of the truly competitive telecommunications sector required to deliver the promised benefits to consumers and to the Australian economy at large''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications Bill 1991 and the six accompanying Bills have a unique capacity to influence the quality of life of each and every Australian. The Bills have the ability to determine how we will relate to each other, how we will work, live and even play. Very few technologies have the ability to touch our lives in this way. The scope, size and comprehensiveness of these Bills indicate that this Government does understand the power of the telephone to change society. Called by the Government at various times micro-economic reform, structural readjustment and deregulation, the sweeping reforms in this Telecommunications Bill and accompanying Bills are bold in concept and execution and obviously part of this Government's wider mission.

SPEECH.PARA: But like all `visionary' ideas, it takes a giant leap of faith, hope and even great reserves of charity on behalf of the community to accept the totality of that vision. The Australian Democrats do not. We do not believe that competition will necessarily lead to increased productivity and changes in work practices. It is a fact peculiar to telecommunications that technology, as much as competition, is likely to result in lower prices. This is in fact what has happened in this country with respect to STD charges.

At other times we have seen the implications of this Government's, what I call, blind faith experiment in the area of financial deregulation. Honourable senators have heard me say this before: we oppose the view that deregulation is the ultimate panacea. Deregulation has not delivered the goods across the board. Probably everyone notices that airline schedules still, almost exclusively, coincide. One of the big benefits we were promised with deregulation of the airlines was that they would not. It has not happened.

The decision whether to deregulate or privatise must be taken on a case by case basis. Tonight, by way of amendment, we will seek to ensure that the domestic telephone user is protected from any failure of this grand vision. Although we disagree with the fundamental assumptions of this Bill, we find some of the numerous acts of omission rather concerting. Belief in deregulation, privatisation and competition is one thing, but asking the rest of us to take so much completely on trust is another. The people of Australia are asked to believe, as an act of faith, that the quality of service afforded to them will at least remain the same, if not improve, even though all overseas experience indicates a decrease in quality of service immediately following deregulation.

We are also expected to believe that the same Government which starved Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd of vital capital, leading eventually to their privatisation, will meet the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation's billion dollar requirements in the future. We are asked to believe that a price drop in STD and international trunk charges will adequately compensate for allowing a competitor access to the infrastructure we have paid for.

We are asked to believe that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), in making his directions to the multimillion dollar foreign owned network carrier, will not be influenced by the relationship between the entrance fee and the Budget deficit. We are asked to believe that the 12,000 people working in the $3 billion telecommunications equipment manufacturing industry will not lose their jobs and their career plans when the Government allows unrestricted foreign products into this country. It does take blind faith to believe that the impetus to telecommunications reform did not come from the need to off-load the $600m loss-making satellite failure, Aussat.

We are asked to believe so much on so little evidence. We are asked to believe, when we do not know the pivotal piece of information-the price the new carrier is expected to pay to access Telecom Australia's infrastructure. This will determine the success or failure of this experiment. Interconnect fees will not be set until after this Bill has passed the Senate.

We are expected to believe that the new entrant will not simply cream skim the top of Telecom Australia's lucrative trunkline markets between central business districts and overseas when we have the British experience of the new entrant, Mercury, as evidence that this may in fact happen. We are asked to believe that competition will work when the Government does not have a national telecommunications plan for the new carrier network. The Minister is waiting for suggestions from the bidders for the new licence. We have no idea of its size, cost, geographic locations, its effects on the environment, or its effects on our cultural heritage or Aboriginal lands, yet we are being asked here tonight to grant this unknown new network carrier immunity from State and Territory laws.

We are being asked to grant the Minister absolute discretion unquestioningly in the crucial licensing section of the Bill. It is not that we do not trust the present Minister, or any future Minister, or the regulatory body, Austel. It is simply that at this point in time I think we are being asked far too much.

It is true-and I acknowledge this-that it is difficult to draw up legislation for an industry that is rapidly changing, innovative and dynamic. I understand that the Minister wants flexibility and choices to cope efficiently with the changing needs of society. The successful new bidder will need some kind of certainty as an incentive to invest the billions of dollars. We understand these needs. But why should the consumer take all of the giant leaps of faith? Why should the new entrant have the guarantee when the people of Australia have none?

The basic assumption behind these Bills is that competition per se will improve the quality of our telephone communication service or, at least, the quality will not deteriorate; after all, the force of competition should apply equally to services and customers. But competition does not apply equally to all services and/or all customers. There is a powerful incentive, called the profit motive, to allocate attention and resources away from the services where competition is weak to services where competition is new and strong. This package of Bills before us now has the single-minded objective of maximising the choice of a telecommunications carrier for the minority of customers.

In advanced mobile societies, access to the telephone can be regarded as an essential requirement of active citizenship. If these Bills go through the Senate unamended, Australia faces becoming a society divided into information and communications rich and information and communications poor as the fundamentals of telecommunications policy have been ignored.

Nowhere is this more obvious than in some of the omissions I referred to earlier. Where in these Bills or the accompanying press releases is there a national policy that will contribute to regenerating this alien economy and provide industrial competitiveness? Where is the strategy for telecommunications to contribute to cohesiveness in this vast landscape? The network roll-out plan, which is jargon for the geographic location of the new telecommunications carrier network, is still undecided. Since the network location will be decided by market forces, it is self-evident that, unless stringent licence conditions are applied, the new entrant to the market will compete only at the lucrative end, which is the multinational trunk line users and the multisite companies. They will benefit from major reductions in the prices of STD and international calls. But the majority of Australians, the 80 per cent who do not use telephones for data transmission or business trunk calls, may end up unwittingly subsidising these businesses.

There are good reasons why the interests of the majority, the 80 per cent of the population, need to be the focus of telecommunications policy. Each and every Australian has already made a fundamental investment in that network to the tune of $3,500 for every ordinary household. Ordinary Australians have already paid to establish a network and a satellite system from which big business in particular will gain an enormous profit at their expense. It is for this reason that I will move a number of amendments to even the odds for the majority of telephone users who have been ignored or have had less emphasis placed upon them by those who have formulated the policy of maximising choice for the minority.

Although the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Bill 1991 provide that Telecom Australia be the universal service provider and that Telecom alone will bear the burden of the 80 per cent majority of telephone users, it is difficult to see how the Government's stated goal of maximising the choice of the telecommunications network supplier can contribute to the maintenance of a universal service, given the inevitable concentration by the new entrant, or entrants after 1997, on those customers with the highest revenue.

I believe that the Government has been so busy tilting the level playing field heavily in favour of the new foreign owned entrant against the incumbent Telecom that the paying public's contribution and shareholding in the new AOTC is ignored. For perfectly sound economic reasons, Telecom's competitor is likely to be interested in only the profitable heavy trunk line traffic and the new mobile telephone network. It will be uneconomic for the new carrier to supply telephone services to homes. As a result, Telecom will be forced to compete and drop prices in the high density STD and international calls areas but, at the same time, will be expected to cater to the unprofitable 80 per cent.

The key issues which will determine Telecom's ability to provide a universal service have been omitted from these Bills. The interconnect fee, the price which the new carrier will have to pay Telecom to access Australia's $20 billion telecommunications infrastructure, has not been decided. Instead, the Government has left the starting date off the AOTC merger Bill as a spur to Telecom to set an accessible interconnect fee. The Democrats wish to break that nexus with an amendment which will put a start date on the merger otherwise, I believe that Telecom and OTC Ltd employees will suffer unnecessarily because of the extended uncertainty involved.

Other key elements which will determine whether Telecom can meet its universal service obligation have also been left out of these Bills. The Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1991, which merges the assets of OTC and Telecom into a new body corporate, does not include a capital structure for the newly formed AOTC. We have attempted to redress this with an amendment that leaves the board and the Minister plenty of scope to find creative solutions. Although a publicly owned company, denied the protection of the shield of the Crown, AOTC is unable to borrow funds to recapitalise its telecommunications network without what first seems to be like begging the Loan Council for permission. Since the Loan Council has withheld that permission for two years now, we have no guarantee that AOTC will have access to the massive capital it needs to upgrade. Without that capital to improve the network, the 80 per cent majority of telephone users-the ones we are talking about-will suffer deteriorating service and quality. I intend to move a number of amendments which will protect consumers just in case the vision fails and they are left with a deteriorating service. When and if the quality of service does decline, the majority of telephone users will not be able to do much about it.

In the Telecommunications Bill 1991, one of the functions of Austel, Australia's telecommunications regulator, is the protection of consumers from unfair practices of the carrier. This Bill does not charge Austel with the specific function of ensuring that the overall interests of the Australian community are taken into consideration in the development and the promotion of the telecommunications industry. The problem for domestic telephone users is that they are not a single, well organised interest group, unlike many of the other participants in this multi-billion dollar decision making process.

Consumers have no redress other than to the Federal Court of Australia if they do not like a decision made by the Minister, particularly pertaining to licence conditions for the new carrier. Clause 69 of the Bill provides that the Minister may request Austel to prepare a report in respect of proposed licence conditions under sections 64 and 65, but he is not obliged to do so. Austel may only participate in the process at the invitation of the Minister, since many licence conditions have the potential to impact significantly on both business and domestic telephone users as well as specific segments of the community. Although it will be possible to challenge a decision of the Minister in the Federal Court, in practice this option will be limited because of the prohibitive cost. A person who unsuccessfully challenges the Minister faces not only his own legal costs but also government costs.

I will move a number of amendments to the Bills to provide a mechanism which is both efficient and convenient for ensuring that the public interest is taken into account without delay in the decision making process. I will also move amendments which give Parliament the right to disallow decisions of the Minister with regard to licensing and which disallow decisions by Austel where the Minister has delegated his power. Not so long ago Queensland, my home State, provided Australians with evidence of what can happen when an executive ceases to be accountable to parliament. Those famous or infamous words, `Now, don't you worry about that', motivate me to take the necessary steps to ensure maximum parliamentary scrutiny.

In the unusual government initiated consultation process over these telecommunication Bills-a process which I want to commend to other Ministers who may find the necessary stamina-I have to say that I did come away with the distinct impression on some occasions that many lobbyists, staffers, bureaucrats and political journalists thought it was quite a bad idea to boost the ability of legislatures to curb executives. This is a profoundly worrying trend because it is based on the conviction that what this country needs is not more democratic checks and balances but more efficient-or some vague notion of what `efficient' to them means-government.

This attempt to bypass Parliament is something of which we are seeing more. It does not justify leaving major decisions involving our infrastructure to private deals between any Minister and a multi-billion dollar foreign conglomerate. I am not suggesting impropriety, but I do believe that Parliament's functions are to scrutinise legislation, to keep a check on the Executive, to oversee public expenditure and to be the ventilator of grievances. The Telecommunications Bill 1991 gives the Minister absolute discretion over the appointment of a new carrier, and declaring, varying and revoking licences.

Moreover, we are being asked to speculate on political futures. As events this week have shown, it is all too easy for a Minister to be returned to the back bench overnight leaving undone private promises, commitments, and a nod and a wink with undertakings to industry, businesses, consumers and other political parties. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Wednesday, 5 June 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson proposed:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight only briefly, primarily for the purpose of tabling, with the leave of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), a document which arises as a result of two legal opinions-presumably all opinions given by the Attorney-General's Department are legal-in respect of the National Health Act 1953 and the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1991. Both these Acts contain the standard secrecy provisions. The sensible interpretation given in the past has been that the Parliamentary Privileges Act prevails in respect of those matters. However, more recently, the Solicitor-General has given an opinion which goes to the heart of the powers of both the Senate and Senate committees, particularly in respect of privilege. The proposition that is proffered by the Solicitor-General is that, if a witness is subpoenaed before a committee of the Senate and under coercion is required to provide information to that committee and is in breach of the secrecy provisions contained within the Act, he would then be committing a criminal offence for which he could be sent to gaol.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Privileges Act itself makes quite clear the consequences for any witness that does not answer, does not appear and does not provide information as requested. I do no more than seek leave to table an opinion. I have asked the Clerks of the Senate to give me an opinion on the conflict between the opinion that the Solicitor-General has given and that which I have understood to be the previous case. I was proposing then with adequate notice to ask Senator Tate during Question Time to give me a considered opinion as to what the real position is in respect of the secrecy provisions and of the committees generally. I seek leave to table a letter to me by the Clerk of the Senate dated 3 June which simply sets out his view in respect of the Solicitor-General's opinion.
Leave granted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Regional Offices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the variables used in the formula that constitutes the Regional Staffing Model used to allocate staff to the regional office network.
(2) What are the parameters or weightings used for each of the variables when the formula was last used.
(3) How many times per year does the Department of Social Security intend to vary the regional office staff levels on the basis of re-running the model.

(4) If the department currently runs just one formula for the whole of Australia, does it have plans to run different formulas for each of the States and Territories or for metropolitan and non-metropolitan regional offices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The variables in the Regional Staffing Model are, by client type:
In addition, the following fixed adjustments are made to the outcome determined by (a) and (b):
* a statistical calibration factor set at the time of the work measurement to ensure that the measurement did not produce an outcome different from the then existing staffing levels;
* a factor which determines the number of managerial staff in Regional Offices; and
* a fixed addition for social work and welfare staffing.

(2) The parameters or weighting used for the variables identified above when the Regional Staffing Model was last used to adjust departmental allocations to each of its State administrations for workload changes in its regional office network were the following:
* Client population and new claims data were the best estimates existing at the time of the application of the model for average numbers for each benefit type for the 1990/91 financial year.

* Activity ratios are used to determine the workload associated with client populations. These ratios are a combination of historical and current activity data extracted from the Department's pension, benefit and allowance processing systems. These counts are weighted by standard times for each work category. The times are determined primarily by the results of statistical work measurement exercises and are agreed by the Departments of Social Security and Finance and the Public Sector Union.

(3) The principle the Department has used and will continue to use to determine when it re-runs the model to vary regional office staffing levels is one of balancing the need to match accurately resourcing levels to workloads with providing a degree of stability in the level of resourcing against which its regional management is required to budget.

In practice, the number of times that the re-running of the model will result in variations to staffing levels will depend mainly on the extent to which the projections of client numbers used in the previous run of the model have proved to be accurate. In this context, while client number projections are under continual review, there are three major points in any year where the projections and hence staffing levels are reconsidered. These are in the period immediately prior to the beginning of the financial year, immediately after a Budget is brought down and at the mid point of a financial year. It is anticipated that these will continue to be major review points.

(4) The Department allocates resources for its regional office network to each of its State administrations on the basis of the one model. (The exception to this is resources associated with workload variations arising outside the range of work covered by the measurements underlying the model, eg: adjustments associated with policy initiatives implemented after the model's work measurements.) While a single model is employed for this purpose, it takes account of variations between States in characteristics which affect workloads.

In addition, while exact arrangements vary between State administrations, each allocates resources to its Area administrations using formulae based on the Regional Staffing Model but which take account of local conditions. In turn, Area administrations take further account of local factors in distributing resources to each Regional Office.
The Department is undertaking two major adjustments to enhance these processes.

* From 1 July 1991, resources will be allocated nationally direct to the Area level of the Department's administration. This corresponds to the removal of the State tier from the Department's structure and will streamline the allocations processes.

* The Regional Staffing Model is being reviewed and restructured in association with the Public Sector Union. This will ensure that the model remains up to date. In the processes, the issue of recognising local factors which affect resource requirements will be addressed further.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) sample imported seaweed and kelp for compliance with Australian food regulations; if so: (a) when did the sampling begin; (b) how many samples have been tested; (c) who analyses the samples; and (d) have any samples failed; if so: (i) how many, and (ii) what were the analytical results of each.
(2) Do the Australian food regulations limit the total amount of arsenic to not more than 1 mg per kg and cadmium to not more than 0.05 mg per kg, in seaweed and kelp.

(3) Were several recent shipments of seaweed found to contain more than the permitted levels of arsenic and cadmium, including one which contained more than 100 times the permitted level of arsenic, and one which contained more than 40 times the legal limit of cadmium, and were these samples impounded.
(4) Did the Japanese Embassy make any representation to the Australian Government in relation to these shipments.
(5) Were the shipments released for consumption by Australians; if so, was the seaweed identified in any way so that Australian consumers could choose to avoid this food.

(6) Did the Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council meet on 15 March 1991 to consider conclusions on the levels of arsenic and cadmium in seaweed and kelp; if so, what was the result of this meeting.
(7) If the answer to (5) was yes, did this action occur before the meetings and deliberations referred to in (6).
(8) Is arsenic: (a) a known carcinogen; and (b) linked with a type of skin cancer associated with Bowen's disease.
(9) Do Australians have the highest rate of skin cancer in the world; if so, should the importation of a food that could risk the increase of skin cancer be permitted.
(10) Is the arsenic found in: (a) fish in the form of arsenobetaine; and (b) seaweed in the form of arsenofuranoside.
(11) What is the toxicological profile of the two forms referred to in (10) and is one form more hazardous than the other.
(12) What are considered to be safe levels of arsenic and cadmium in seaweed and kelp.
(13) If impounded consignments of kelp or seaweed have been released, can State authorities still prohibit their sale in their respective states.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is responsible for testing of imported seaweed and kelp for compliance with the Food Standards Code developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). Sampling commenced on 14 January 1991, and 18 samples have been taken for analysis by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL). Of the samples taken 17 samples had levels of total arsenic and/or cadmium in excess of the tolerance permitted under the `All other foods' listing of the Food Standards Code.

(2) ``There is currently no specific limitation on arsenic and cadmium in seaweed in the Food Standards Code. The `All other foods' category of the Code permits total arsenic to a maximum of 1 mg/kg and cadmium to a maximum of 0.05 mg/kg. Recommendations are going forward to the National Food Standards Council to amend the Code to permit the following standard for seaweed (85% moisture content)

(3) Several recent shipments of seaweed were found to contain more than the permitted levels of total arsenic and cadmium under the `All other foods' category including one which contained more than 100 times the permitted level of total arsenic. One sample was found to contain more than 40 times the permitted level of cadmium. The shipments were detained by AQIS pending the receipt of test results to determine the level of inorganic arsenic present and, then for advice from the Department of Community Services and Health about the implications for human health of the levels of arsenic and cadmium reported.

(4) The Japanese Embassy made representations to AQIS and the Department of Community Services and Health to establish the basis for Australia's concerns about the safety of seaweed and kelp products.

(5) On the basis of expert advice received from the Department of Community Services and Health most shipments were considered to have inorganic arsenic and cadmium levels within acceptable limits and were permitted importation. Because of that assessment, there was no necessity to identify the seaweed in the manner suggested.

(6) The Department of Community Services and Health advises that the Public Health Committee at its meeting on 15 March 1991 concluded that there was no immediate evidence of significant danger to health from the presence of inorganic arsenic up to 1.0 mg/kg or cadmium up to 0.2 mg/kg. These limits are the same as those applying for fish and fish products in the Food Standards Code. The Public Health Committee has now recommended to the National Food Standards Council that these revised interim standards be adopted.
(7) A number of shipments were released prior to the meeting of the Public Health Committee.

(8) The Department of Community Services and Health has advised that arsenic is classified as a human carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on the basis of epidemiological evidence in situations of high natural or occupational exposure to inorganic arsenic. It has been associated with basal and squamous cell carcinomas of the skin as well as with a pre-neoplastic form of dermatitis, known as Bowen's disease.

(9) The Department of Community Services and Health has advised that a Provisional Tolerable Weekly Intake for inorganic arsenic in food has been established by the FAO/WHO Joint Expert Committee on Food Additives and Contaminants (JECFA) on the basis of toxicological data presented to it. Results of analysis for arsenic levels in food conducted as part of the Australian Market Basket Survey show levels of arsenic to be very low in the diet, well below the JECFA recommended Provisional Tolerable Weekly Intake. It would therefore seem unlikely that there is an association between dietary intake of arsenic and skin carcinoma in Australia. The high incidence of skin cancer found in Australia is more likely to be associated with exposure to UV radiation in sunlight.

(10) I am advised that the arsenic found in fish and other marine organisms is in the form of arsenobetaine. In all of the seaweed varieties which have been analysed thus far the arsenic is in the form of arsenofuranosides.

(11) The Department of Community Services and Health advises that considerable evidence indicates that arsenobetaine is toxicologically inert and is excreted unchanged in both animals and humans. The evidence for the arsenofuranosides is more limited but indicates that partial metabolism to simpler organic arsenic compounds occurs followed by rapid excretion. There is no evidence of conversion to inorganic arsenic in either case and no indication of toxicity in humans.
(13) Yes, it is possible for State authorities to prohibit the sale of any foods which do not comply with State food laws.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Counter Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the rising number of unemployment beneficiaries, how many additional counter staff have been appointed to offices of the Department of Social Security in each State and Territory since 1 July 1990.
(2) Are there any offices of the department at which the number of counter staff has been reduced since 1 July 1990; if so, at which offices, by how many staff and for what reasons.
(3) Since 1 July 1990, has the department increased the availability of training programs for counter staff to enable them to better cope with the increasing number of clients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department no longer has staff who work only as counter officers. Alterations to the Administrative Service Officer structure following the introduction of the Second Tier Wage Agreement have resulted in counter and assessment work being combined into a new designation of Counter Assessor. This designation is at the Grade 3 level (AS03) and increases in the numbers of staff at that level since 1 July 1990 are set out below.

The increases do not reflect solely the increase to workload associated with rising numbers of unemployment beneficiaries. There is a range of other factors which have affected numbers of staff at various classification levels over the same period. Most particularly, the Department introduced a new on-line computer processing system in its offices which increased requirements for staffing resources at the AS03 level (but with larger reductions at lower classification levels).

It is not possible to separate accurately the impact that this change had on requirements for AS03 staff from that of rising unemployment beneficiary numbers. Decisions on resources to be deployed at particular classification levels are a matter for local managers and are influenced by local factors.
INCREASE IN NUMBERS OF STAFF EMPLOYED AT THE AS03 LEVEL IN REGIONAL OFFICES JULY 1990 TO MARCH 1991
(2) There are five offices where there has been a reduction in the number of ASO 3 positions since 1 July 1990. They are:
* STRATHFIELD (-1) where there was a small decline in the client populations in that region;
* CAIRNS (-2) where there was an internal staffing reorganisation resulting from efficiencies deriving from improved workflows together with a reduction in the number of seasonally employed staff;
* ROCKHAMPTON (-3) where there was a reduction in the number of seasonally employed staff;
* WOODRIDGE (-10) where staff were transferred to the newly opened BEENLEIGH office which assumed responsibility for part of the client workload dealt with at WOODRIDGE; and
* BROOME (-3) where staff were transferred to the KUNUNURRA office which assumed responsibility for part of the client workload dealt with at BROOME.

(3) Since 1 July 1990 the Department has increased and improved the range of training available for public contact staff. These have included training programs in respect of skills essential for public contact as well as technical training in the entitlement conditions applied to social security payments. In addition, over the same period there has been extensive training undertaken in respect of the introduction of new computing systems and the ``plain English'' Social Security Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Industries and Energy: Direct Marketing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please provide details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The department as a whole has no overall policy on the use of direct marketing. The department consists of seven principal operating groups which reflect the functions in the portfolio. These include, Agriculture and Forestry Group; Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics; Australian Quarantine &Inspection Service; Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics; Bureau of Rural Resources; Headquarters; and the Minerals and Fisheries Group.

Responsibility for management of programs has been devolved to these groups and to managers of programs in each group. Direct marketing has been used within some of these operating groups where the relevant program manager considers it will increase their clients' awareness of the availability of relevant information.

(2) No. The department does not anticipate direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details. As explained above, any direct marketing activities are carried out as an integral part of a particular program.

(4) The department as a whole has not undertaken any direct mailing activities. The following are direct mailing activities undertaken in this financial year and include publications that may have been distributed on a free basis:
Guidelines and application forms for the National Soil Conservation Program December 1990/January 1991
Distributed by direct mail to organisations with a known interest in soil conservation or land management
AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF AGRICULTURAL AND RESOURCE ECONOMICS (ABARE)
Clients on database indicating interest in farm survey data
Introduction of charging and subscription information
Minerals and energy publications and research information
Clients on database indicating interest in minerals and energy
Selection of clients on database indicating interest in fisheries
All subscribers to Agriculture and Resources Quarterly
Clients on the client database who did not subscribe in response to November mailing
Information on Livestock publications and research
Clients on database indicating interest in livestock
Information on fisheries publications and research
Commencement of a bi-monthly newsletter advertising new products including a market research questionnaire
Clients were asked to respond detailing which of BMR's free products they wished to receive
Regular circulation of brochures/flyers on new geoscientific data and interpretations to relevant client groups, incorporating an order form
Exhibiting at key industry conferences/exhibitions relevant to particular client groups
Facsimiles were sent to key industry companies world wide
Organising a number of highly specific seminar/workshops, both in-house and externally for particular client groups
Facsimiles were sent to key industry companies world wide
Distributed to overseas counterpart organisations, common interest bodies-both overseas and in Australia as well as the general public on request
Promotional material relating to the National Energy Management Forum (24-25 June 1991), Melbourne
Directed at a variety of audiences which have previously expressed interest in energy management issues
Petroleum News sheets covering news items on petroleum industry developments in Australia and giving details of offshore exploration acreage available for application
A comprehensive information package giving details of the offshore exploration acreage which included information sheets on relevant arrangements.

The Petroleum News sheets and the information packages were distributed using an extensive mailing list of some 800 entries, which covers petroleum companies in Australia and overseas as well as petroleum service companies, consultants and journals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Promotion of the Department's products and services in ionospheric prediction; analytical chemistry and microbiology testing; protective services; printing and publishing; mapping activities; and services provided by COMCAR.
Informing the public sector and industry of Government procurement policies and practices, and purchasing services.

(b) Greater customer awareness and increased market penetration; up-to-date information on the organisation's activities and new services; increased sales of Departmental products eg maps and Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) publications; the better targetting of potential clients; increased matching of services to future demands and increased consultancy work; awareness of buyers and sellers of changed purchasing regulations, and promoting Commonwealth business to Australian and New Zealand suppliers.
(c) Direct mailing, telephone canvassing and a 008 enquiries hotline.

(2) No. Given the comparatively small amounts spent on direct marketing in relation to overall marketing expenditure, its separation has not been warranted. However, AGPS intends to record direct marketing expenditure separately from 1 July 1991.

(3) i In the printing and publishing area, a database exists which comprises some 14,500 names and is separated into 24 subject listings and five market groups, namely, libraries, schools, academic, legal profession and commercial booksellers. A separate information database is also being implemented in respect of existing and potential contractors and clients. Clients are Commonwealth agencies, statutory authorities and government business enterprises.

ii A database of approximately 6,000 names consisting of Commonwealth, State and Local Government officers, educational institutions, private sector enterprises and conference organisers with commercial interest in Commonwealth purchasing has been developed for improving Commonwealth procurement services.
iii The Australian Protective Service (APS) has a list of names and addresses of senior management in Government departments.

iv Details of clients and enquirers who require topographic digital data are kept on a database. These clients are Federal and State agencies. A separate, limited, database comprising schools, libraries and map distributors is being extended continuously.

i Three regular regular newsletters, and two special editions, featuring the ``Purchase Australian'' Campaign (launched in September 1990) and ``Meet the Buyers'' exhibition (7-8 November 1990), were issued. These were accompanied by guidance material (Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and Commonwealth Procurement Circulars) and were sent to recipients identified in 3(ii) above. For the ``Purchase Australian'' Campaign, direct mail products were sent on nine occasions (during August and September 1990).
ii During the period November l990-April 1991, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories undertook direct mailing activities in-house in-
- Drug Testing in Workplace; 100 letters and 35 follow-up letters
- Occupational Health and Safety; 25 letters and 16 follow-up letters.
These letters were directed to potential clients advising them of the Laboratories' services.
iii Direct mail of a monthly newsletter called Profile by the APS to senior management in Government departments.

iv In the period July 1990 to April 1991, AGPS undertook 50 direct mailings for publications. Every two months the New Commonwealth Government Books from AGPS catalogue is mailed to 14,500 individuals and organisations. A weekly list of Departmental Titles is also produced and direct mailed to a limited mailing list of libraries and government organisations. In addition, AGPS has undertaken school and library mailings and subject mailings, as Australian Government publications or groups of publications are released. These mailings are to individuals and organisations that have expressed interest in the subject and other members of subject target groups whom AGPS regards as potential buyers.

v Details of common use contracts are sent to clients on a monthly basis through the mailing of a set of microfiche. A newsletter called Fichetales is sent with the microfiche. This advises clients of new contracts, contract amendments and general purchasing information. Hard copies of common use contracts, Buyer's Guides, are also mailed direct to clients.
vi A brochure detailing COMCAR's new rates structure was sent to clients. As well, all Ministers received letters which marketed COMCAR's services.

vii Maps and publications were direct mailed to State and lending libraries in August 1990. In November 1990, brochures, product catalogues and price lists on maps were sent to local government authorities in Australia and clients. A special offer on a topographic map was made to Australian secondary schools in March 1991.
