QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 9 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a monitoring program been initiated to gauge public response to The Energy Guide recently launched by the Prime Minister.
(2) What are the details of the program, in particular the: (a) total funding; (b) duration; (c) organisation(s) conducting it; and (d) aims and objectives.

(3) Is it a fact that the program is designed to gauge awareness of the guide and its information, and not the degree to which it changes purchasing decisions; if so, why has this approach been taken, considering that the effectiveness of the guide depends on its success in changing purchasing patterns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A monitoring program is being implemented to measure changes in community awareness of, attitudes towards and responses to greenhouse and energy issues, against a benchmark study carried out earlier this year.
(2) (a) Estimated cost of the monitoring program is $72 000 for telephone interviews of a stratified random sample of 2000 people.
(b) The monitoring is being undertaken in blocks of 8 weeks, extending over a period of 12 months.
(c) The organisation undertaking the monitoring is Quantum Market Research of Melbourne.
(d) Objectives of the monitoring are to:
* monitor trends in community awareness of, attitudes and reported responses to, energy and greenhouse issues
* track the impact on community awareness and response levels of individual initiatives undertaken as part of the Government's enhanced energy management program
* assist with evaluation of the program and fine tuning of specific community-oriented initiatives to maximise effectiveness

(3) No. A number of factors will have a bearing on the perceptions of the community at large about energy and greenhouse issues, including activities undertaken by governments and other bodies. Included among the Commonwealth's activities are the community-oriented initiatives of the energy management program, of which the Guide is a major component. The monitoring program addresses all of these influences and their relative importance in the community.

The Guide itself should not be interpreted as simply encouraging the purchase of more efficient appliances. It deals with all aspects of home energy efficiency, and monitoring is designed to identify the extent of reported improvement in all aspects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Are officers of the Minister's department regularly supplied with newspapers or magazines; if so: (a) which officer classifications are entitled to this facility; (b) what is each officer's entitlement; (c) which newspapers and magazines are supplied; (d) what was the cost of providing this facility in: (i) 1986-87, (ii) 1987-88, (iii) 1988-89, and (iv) 1989-90; (e) who supplies the newspapers and magazines to the department; (f) if tenders were called for the supply of the newspapers and magazines, how was the successful tenderer selected; and (g) if tenders were not called for, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) &(b) The Secretary, Deputy Secretaries and Chief Medical Advisor are entitled to any selection they require. Division Heads and State Managers are entitled to three daily publications and one weekly publication. Branch Heads and Medical Services Advisors can select one daily and one weekly publication.

(c) All senior officers entitled to newspapers and magazines are permitted to choose from daily newspapers and weekly magazines. The list varies from time to time with the main publications being The Australian, The Financial Review, The Canberra Times, Capital City newspapers, The Bulletin, The Business Review Weekly, The Newsweek, The Australian Society and the Economist.

(d) The Department of Community Services and Health was formed from the amalgamation of the Department of Community Services, the Department of Health and elements of the former Department of Housing and Construction, on 13 July 1987. As a result of this:
(i) Comprehensive records prior to 13 July 1987 are not available to the Department of Community Services and Health;

(e), (f) &(g) Tenders are not called and all newspapers and magazines are supplied by the newsagent to whom a specific territory has been allocated by the Newsagency Council under Trade Practices Determination A15605, A15421-23 and A14525-6 (7 February 1980), as amended on 26 April 1984-A30092 and A30093.
